HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- SoHo; 
Still Seeking Best Mix Of Style and Rents

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Albert Laboz was on the verge of leasing his two-story building at 454 West Broadway in SoHo to a high-fashion retailer when terrorists destroyed the World Trade Center. The deal never closed.
 The terms would have been so sweet -- more than $300 a square foot annually for the ground floor -- that Mr. Laboz, a principal in United American Land, had paid his existing tenant, a Rizzoli bookstore, to move out. 
 Mr. Laboz eventually found a new tenant, Barry Kieselstein-Cord, an accessories company that sells belts priced from $900 to $2,200. But there was a catch: Kieselstein-Cord's rent was tied to its sales volume. After 18 months, if the store reached its sales goal -- an amount that neither tenant nor landlord would disclose -- the rent would be fixed at about 20 percent below the 2001 asking price, said the company's broker, Candice Dobbs, president of Dobbs Associates.
The Kieselstein-Cord deal is unusual, but it reflects the changes that have rocked the SoHo retail market. The ground-floor retail vacancy rate for SoHo is about 14 percent, or twice the average for Manhattan, according to a mid-February survey by the brokerage company Cushman & Wakefield.
Five years ago, luxury retailers began replacing the art galleries that had fled to Chelsea because of rising rents. But SoHo as Madison Avenue South proved to be a short-lived trend. Yves St. Laurent, Cartier and Ermenegildo Zegna are among the uptown retailers that leased space in SoHo but occupied it only briefly or never moved in. Last month, the jeweler H. Stern abandoned plans to open a store in a new building at Prince and Mercer Streets.
SoHo suffered more than most other Manhattan retail districts from the repercussions of the Sept. 11 attack, the absence of foreign tourists and the economic downturn. But brokers also say that rents soared out of control for a neighborhood that did not stand a chance of drawing the quantity of affluent customers found on Madison Avenue. "Some of the stores that opened didn't have any business going down there," said Jeffrey D. Roseman, an executive vice president of Newmark New Spectrum Retail.
With for-rent signs dotting the cast-iron buildings that were once used for light manufacturing, some landlords are negotiating month-to-month or short-term leases while they wait for the market to improve. Gene P. Spiegelman, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, said that asking rents in the most desirable part of SoHo, from Broadway to West Broadway and from Houston Street to Grand Street, have declined to an average of $166 a square foot annually from $191 at the height of the market in early 2001. The highest asking rent, he said, has declined to $333 a square foot from $470. Fifty-seven retail spaces are now available, compared with 46 in early 2001, he said.
Brokers see SoHo as two retail districts. Broadway has chain stores that can be found in many malls (with a few exceptions, like Prada and its minimalist shop). A new Crate & Barrel store serves as the northern anchor, and Bloomingdale's plans to build its second Manhattan store in the Canal Jeans building to the south. H&M, a trendy but inexpensive clothing retailer, has leased space at 515 Broadway, only steps away from its store at 558 Broadway. Other new retailers include Levi's and Arden B.
West of Broadway, boutiques catering to young customers are taking space that was prepared in flusher times for marquee retailers. Recent arrivals representing well-known brands like Apple Computer, which moved into a former post office at Prince and Greene Streets, and Adidas, at 142 Wooster Street, have departed from their usual format to take advantage of the neighborhood's distinctive architecture.
New stores offering contemporary furniture and home furnishings are being added, particularly at the southern edge of the neighborhood, where rents are $75 to $90 a square foot, said Caroline P. Banker, an executive vice president at Douglas Elliman. Kartell, one of SoHo's first furniture retailers, is turning over its 1,800-square-foot space at 45 Greene Street to Catherine Memmi, a French home furnishings store, and moving into 3,500 square feet at 37 Greene Street.
Other new tenants nearby include Flou, a bed and bedding store, and Zollavari, which sells rugs made by nomadic tribes in Iran. At the northern edge of SoHo, Design Within Reach, a company that began as a catalog and Internet retailer of sleek home furnishings, opened its first New York retail store on Saturday at 142 Wooster Street.
Brokers who specialize in SoHo say their phones are ringing more often now that warmer weather is making the streets livelier. But most say rents should come down more.
"The asking prices are still high," said Bruce Sinder, the president of the Sinvin Realty Corporation, which represents both landlords and tenants. "If the price is right, there are tenants."

HEADLINE: Retail Group Downgrades '03 Forecast 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Citing "geopolitical risks," the National Retail Federation, which represents more than one million retailers, downgraded its forecast for the year yesterday.
 In January, the group estimated that retail sales would grow 5.6 percent; yesterday, it lowered that estimate to 3.8 percent. 
 "The drumbeat toward war with Iraq has stymied fundamental sectors of the U.S. economy," the group said in a report. 
"A number of adjectives, all meaning similar things, can best describe the current state of the economy: subdued, sluggish, soft, tepid, fragile, muted," the report said. "This economic malaise has been with us for at least the past six months. It is likely to persist until the second half of the year."
If the report was not dispiriting enough, several analysts said the retail picture for 2003 might end up even more tepid and fragile than the trade group had predicted.
Brian Tunick, a retail analyst for J. P. Morgan, questioned the report's assessment that shoppers would be more willing to spend in the second half of the year. 
"For the last three years, everyone always starts out the year by saying the recovery will occur in the second half," he said. "With gas prices 50 percent higher than they were a year ago, and consumer confidence at a 10-year low, which was sliding months before the war, people figure things will only get better."
Thomson First Call, which compiles analysts' estimates and analyzes earnings, expects first-quarter earnings growth of 2.1 percent for the 137 retailers it follows, down from the 12.5 percent projected at the start of the year.
"That's a pretty dramatic downward revision," Ken Perkins, an analyst at Thomson, said yesterday. "Obviously, retailers have been feeling the heat."
If you take out Wal-Mart's growth -- and average the other 136 retail companies -- Mr. Perkins said the projected earnings growth dropped to negative 0.6 percent. And First Call has already revised downward its earnings estimates for the second and third quarters.
To Arnold H. Aronson, a managing director at Kurt Salmon Associates, a consulting firm that specializes in retail companies, it is only prudent to lower estimates. Like many other analysts, Mr. Aronson said that while the war in Iraq had certainly worsened an already lackluster retail climate, the situation had more to do with the economy than the war.
Rosalind Wells, the economist behind the Retail Federation's estimates, acknowledged that her analysis was basically a rosy one.
"The assumption is that the war will be not be terribly long," she said, "and that we will prevail. Any forecast has assumptions built into it."

SUBJECT: RETAILERS (91%); ECONOMIC CONDITIONS (90%); RETAIL SALES (90%); COUNTRY RISK (90%); MILITARY WEAPONS (90%); BUSINESS FORECASTS (89%); BUSINESS & PROFESSIONAL ASSOCIATIONS (89%); INDUSTRY ANALYSTS (89%); COMPANY EARNINGS (89%); IRAQ WAR (89%); EARNINGS PREANNOUNCEMENTS (78%); ECONOMIC NEWS (78%); CONSUMER CONFIDENCE (78%); RETAIL TRADE FIGURES (78%); INTERIM FINANCIAL RESULTS (77%); RESEARCH REPORTS (76%); CONSULTING SERVICES (73%); MARKET RESEARCH & ANALYSIS (73%); WAR & CONFLICT (72%); CHEMICAL & BIOLOGICAL WEAPONS (72%); NUCLEAR WEAPONS (66%); OIL & GAS PRICES (51%) RETAIL STORES AND TRADE; SALES; BIOLOGICAL AND CHEMICAL WARFARE; ATOMIC WEAPONS; UNITED STATES INTERNATIONAL RELATIONS; UNITED STATES ARMAMENT AND DEFENSE; UNITED STATES ECONOMY

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Index Declines For the First Time in 5 Months 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Business at the nation's factories contracted in March for the first time in five months, suggesting that the war in Iraq may be causing companies to retrench, a private survey released yesterday indicated.
 The Institute for Supply Management said its manufacturing index fell to 46.2 from 50.5 in February. A reading below 50 means that manufacturing activity is decreasing. 
 Analysts had forecast that the index would fall to 49.
The institute said purchasing and supply executives focused on the war, soft demand and rising prices. Demand slowed in several industries, including chemicals and industrial equipment.
But the institute refused to release the survey's cutoff date, making it hard to gauge how the start of the war affected responses. It said manufacturers tend to know their business levels by the 10th of each month; the war started on March 19.
"This was really built around the threat of what was going to happen," said Norbert J. Ore, who oversees the survey.
Besides war jitters, unseasonably severe weather and a decline in payrolls were factors in the drop-off, said Dan Meckstroth, chief economist at the Manufacturers Alliance, a research group in Arlington, Va.
"Declining production activity in manufacturing means that the overall economy cannot hope to achieve anything better than tread water in the months ahead," he said.
New orders had been above the 50 level for six months, but dropped in March to 46.2 -- 6.1 points lower than the reading in February.
The group's production index fell 9.1 points in March, to 46.3, indicating a drop in business and ending 15 consecutive months of growth in production, the survey found.
Factory employment again failed to recover in March, coming in below 50 for the 30th consecutive month.
"Consumer confidence affects spending on a real short-term basis," Mr. Meckstroth added, "but for the most part, people spend based on income and the buy ability of their job, and right now, we're just not getting employment growth."
A report from the Commerce Department yesterday showed that construction spending dipped by 0.2 percent in February, pulled down by a sharp drop in government spending for public works projects. Spending came to a seasonally adjusted annual pace of $872.2 billion, still brisk and better than analysts' expectations.

HEADLINE: U.S. Raises Some Fuel Economy Rules 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 1 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that it would raise fuel economy regulations for light trucks -- S.U.V.'s, pickups and minivans -- by 1.5 miles a gallon, or about 4.5 percent, by the 2007 model year. 
 The administration called the plan, which has been working its way through the regulatory system for several months, one of the biggest fuel economy increases in years. 
Environmental groups criticized it as a minuscule step at a time when gas consumption is a national security issue. 
 "The Bush administration is committed to improving vehicle fuel economy while protecting passenger safety and American jobs," Dr. Jeffrey W. Runge, the administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said in a statement.
David Friedman, a senior analyst at the Union of Concerned Scientists, said the measure's oil savings would be more than offset by a decision to continue credits automakers receive for making cars that can use ethanol. 
Daniel Becker, the top global warming expert at the Sierra Club, said, "Our troops are risking their lives in the Middle East for a war that is in part about oil, gas prices are skyrocketing, and global warming pollution is more of a problem than ever."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Large airlines, faced with their worst of times, have stepped up advertising despite the war.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AIRLINES are slowly beginning to step up advertising despite the war, because the war may be the least of their problems.
 The slowdown in air travel since the war against Iraq began is only one difficulty confronting the airline industry, which is suffering through what is widely considered the worst time in its history. Advance domestic bookings have fallen 20 percent from a year ago, according to the Air Transport Association. That has left the supply of seats far above demand, which has been cut by the stagnant economy, the threat of terrorist acts, concerns about the financial health of many large carriers and now the war. 
 And to add illness to injury, there are increasing worries that air travel is helping spread a mysterious pneumonia-like disease, which led California officials yesterday to quarantine an American Airlines plane arriving at San Jose International Airport from Tokyo.
The additional ads in the last few days, from online sellers of airline tickets as well as the carriers themselves, reflect the industry's perilous condition. There is a widespread perception that, as the saying goes, in good times you should advertise, but in bad times you must.
"The war is having enough of a suppressing effect on bookings and traffic that we didn't need to compound it by making ourselves invisible," said David Messing, a spokesman for Continental Airlines in Houston, so the airline decided to continue "with our regular activities."
"We want travelers and potential travelers to know we're ready when they are," Mr. Messing said, unintentionally echoing an old slogan of a competitor, Delta Air Lines. The Continental efforts include print and outdoor ads by the Kaplan Thaler Group in New York, part of the Publicis Groupe, which carry a theme that seems particularly appropriate: "Work Hard. Fly Right."
At Delta, "because the war was slow-building, we developed a war contingency plan," said Carter Etherington, United States manager for marketing communications. The plan included television, radio and print ads in regional markets like Atlanta, Boston and New York.
"The majority of our advertising is geared toward how Delta is making travel safer, more efficient and more enjoyable," Mr. Etherington said, "and especially in New York, we're touting security and technology."
"If we were to stop our advertising, it would be a knee-jerk reaction," he added, "rather than to show support of the United States and the economy" by trying to stimulate business.
At Orbitz, the online ticket broker owned by a consortium of major carriers, "We started to see a definite decline in demand, especially in international travel, a couple of days before the war started, so we decided to pull back some marketing support," said Michael Sands, the chief marketing officer, in Chicago. Those cutbacks included newspaper ads and so-called pop-under ads on Web sites, he said.
"But now we see demand as coming back, so we're going to be aggressive in advertising," Mr. Sands said. "It's hard to countervail the American people's desire to travel, and people want to book their summer travel plans, particularly for early summer."
The pop-under ads on news Web sites, which were eliminated because "it would not have been appropriate to be there in the early stages of the war," he said, are returning this week; some came back yesterday.
That sensitivity to the national mood is prevalent throughout the industry.
"We may be taking a much closer look at consumer perceptions, hour by hour, so to speak, instead of day by day," said Eric Webber, a vice president at GSD&M in Austin, Tex., the Omnicom Group agency that has long created campaigns for Southwest Airlines.
"So far we're moving ahead and aren't making any changes," Mr. Webber said, other than "moving away our commercials from some news programming" after the war started.
"In fact, we just shot six new spots in the last couple weeks," he said.
Another low-fare carrier, JetBlue Airways, also filmed commercials in the last two weeks.
"JetBlue went off the air for 48 hours after the war started, then went back on with a regular schedule," said Brian Flatow, senior vice president at the Ad Store in New York, the JetBlue agency.
The new spots will be in the same humorous vein that has characterized the Ad Store's work for JetBlue, Mr. Flatow said, because "we feel our message is positive and uplifting." One commercial, meant to show "that you come off a JetBlue plane a happier person," he added, presents vignettes that include "3-year-old twins pushing their mom in a stroller and a dog kissing a cat."
Another carrier known for humorous campaigns is Virgin Atlantic Airways, part of the Virgin Group. Virgin Atlantic has continued its lighthearted pitches in "below-the-line channels like e-mail marketing, the Web and public relations, the sharpest tool in our marketing drawer," said John Riordan, the vice president for marketing in North America, in Norwalk, Conn.
Virgin Atlantic has not been running the more costly television and print ads, Mr. Riordan said, because the company is conducting a review for its creative and media account, with billings estimated at $12 million to $15 million.
"We have to balance market stimulation with cash conservation," he added. "We will choose the right time to get back in, and get back in we will."
Also husbanding its resources is US Airways, which emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy on Monday. The carrier is going ahead with limited ad plans, said David Castelveter, a spokesman for the US Airways Group in Arlington, Va. Those include e-mail marketing and newsletters for members of the US Airways frequent-flier program, called Dividend Miles.
As US Airways emerged from bankruptcy, American Airlines, the unit of the AMR Corporation that is the world's largest carrier, reached tentative concession agreements with three major unions, helping avert a bankruptcy filing.
American "put advertising on hiatus," said Tim Kincaid, a spokesman, "to monitor how things evolved," and plans "to resume sometime in mid-April."
United Airlines, part of the UAL Corporation, has primarily been communicating with customers through e-mail, though it is also moving ahead with ads to which it has made long-term commitments.
"Right now, we're somewhere between not running ads and needing to drive revenue by starting to get butts into the seats," said Alex Leikikh, worldwide account director on the United account at the carrier's agency, Fallon Worldwide in Minneapolis, part of Publicis. "We're monitoring this on a daily basis, and we plan a meeting with the client this week to figure it out."

HEADLINE: HealthSouth's Legal Problems Ripple Across Its Hometown 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO and ALEX BERENSON 

DATELINE: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. 

 BODY:
Towering cranes stand idle at a half-finished $300 million HealthSouth hospital that was to have been the lodestar of the future this city wants. The builder, afraid it will not be paid, has stopped work, save for adding a temporary roof to keep the rain out.
 While the construction crews have gone home, the building next door is bustling. There, at the headquarters of HealthSouth, F.B.I. agents have been searching computers and questioning executives about an accounting fraud they say went on for 15 years. 
 The flood of agents and Securities and Exchange Commission investigators comes as a shock to a city and business community that regarded HealthSouth, the nation's largest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, as the leader in Birmingham's effort to refashion itself from the steel-making capital of the South into a center for the health care industry. 
The problems at HealthSouth come on top of the legal troubles of another Birmingham institution, McWane, a big maker of sewer pipes, which is under federal investigation for deaths and injuries at its plants.
But McWane, an old-line manufacturer, is Birmingham's past, while the bigger and fast-growing HealthSouth is its future. That is why, even with a war going on, business and community leaders find it hard not to talk about HealthSouth.
"HealthSouth is what the city wanted for its future, with its nonpolluting, pacesetting medical services," said Edward S. LaMonte, a political scientist at Birmingham-Southern College. "McWane is an after-image of the industrial past."
For a decade, Birmingham has watched HealthSouth and its founder, Richard M. Scrushy (pronounced SCROO-shee), with a mix of pride, admiration and resentment.
As HealthSouth expanded from a regional operator of rehabilitation centers into a national company with 50,000 employees at almost 2,000 centers, the city's establishment appreciated the economic benefits. HealthSouth became one of Birmingham's largest private employers, with 3,500 employees in and around the city.
At the same time, as Mr. Scrushy's wealth swelled and as he used charitable donations to make his name ubiquitous across the city, Birmingham's old guard, including the elite running its powerful banks, never fully embraced him. Mr. Scrushy's obsession with security, his seeming lust for publicity and his large pay made him an even more controversial figure.
Almost every significant institution in the city, from the University of Alabama to the science museum (called the McWane Center), has accepted donations from HealthSouth and Mr. Scrushy. Mr. Scrushy's name is on libraries, stadiums and stretches of highway.
"There was resentment among some people," said Richard Arrington Jr., a former Birmingham mayor. "There were those who resented his wealth and those who resented his style." 
Mr. Scrushy could not be reached for comment.
Mr. Scrushy, 50, is probably the only chief executive of a large Birmingham company who is not a member of the Birmingham Country Club, one of the favored clubs of old Birmingham. (Mr. Scrushy's humble upbringing in Selma, 90 miles south, would have ruled out his chances of acceptance at the Mountain Brook Country Club, the most exclusive redoubt of the city's power brokers.)
A person who knows the workings of the Birmingham Country Club said the club had kept out Mr. Scrushy because he was not properly deferential.
"People who apply to be members of the Birmingham club have to obtain dozens of letters of recommendation, which Richard did," he said. "After that he had to pay a visit to each of the 15 members of the club's board of governors. 'I don't need to do it,' Mr. Scrushy said. 'I am the C.E.O. of HealthSouth.' To which the club leaders essentially replied, 'You don't need to be a member.' "
Last week, Mr. Scrushy said he would resign from the board of trustees of the University of Alabama System, one of the most prestigious positions in Alabama.
Publicly, other trustees said Mr. Scrushy decided to step down independently and did so because he probably thought it was in the board's best interests. Privately, people who know the board's workings, including one trustee, said trustees felt uncomfortable with having Mr. Scrushy on the board while federal investigators were claiming he oversaw a fraud.
While Mr. Scrushy's detractors quietly gloat, his supporters say that the charges of fraud, if true, are a tragedy for the city. Two former chief financial officers and the company's former assistant controller have already pleaded guilty to charges of inflating HealthSouth's profits by $1.4 billion and are cooperating with the federal investigation. The company and Mr. Scrushy have not been charged.
The effect of the HealthSouth crisis on Birmingham has some resemblance to the way the Enron scandal disrupted Houston last year. But Houston, which has a metropolitan area of 4.2 million people and is home to the core of the energy industry and Continental Airlines, is already by almost any standard a major-league city. Birmingham, with a metropolitan area of a million people, would badly like to become one, or at least make up ground on Nashville and Memphis, its regional competitors.
Instead, Birmingham and Alabama must now face the fact that their most successful company and most prominent business leader are under investigation for fraud.
"I was a great admirer of his," said Susan Matlock, president of the Birmingham Entrepreneurial Center. "He didn't have a silver spoon. He's certainly self-made. When you didn't know this was in the offing, it was a source of pride."
Tim Taylor, a venture capitalist in Birmingham who specializes in investing in health care companies, said he "connected with the story and thought it was very impressive."
The accusations against Mr. Scrushy have "particularly bothered me because I looked up to Richard," said Mr. Taylor, who grew up in rural Mississippi. "Down in the Deep South, a guy who's come from a public school, public education, respiratory nurse -- those are rare stories."
A one-time respiratory therapist, Mr. Scrushy founded HealthSouth in 1984. The company rapidly gobbled up competitors to become the largest provider of rehabilitation services in the nation. The company's growth was the most visible symbol of Birmingham's move away from its industrial past, though not its only driver.
Four of the nation's top 50 banks have headquarters in Birmingham, more than in any other city except New York, and the University of Alabama at Birmingham has become a center for health care research.
For more than a decade, Birmingham's economy has grown strongly. Last year, unemployment in the metropolitan area averaged 4.2 percent, compared with 5.8 percent nationwide. The new prosperity is evident in the crowded parking lots of recently built malls in the city's wealthy southern suburbs, where Lincoln Navigators and other luxury sport utility vehicles jockey for space.
HealthSouth's headquarters is an anchor in one of the city's fastest-growing areas, across from the new Marriott Hotel and on Highway 280 just down from the new Saks Fifth Avenue at the new Summit Mall.
No one thinks the company's problems will permanently derail Birmingham's growth, but the investigations have been unsettling, said Dr. Mark S. Williams, an anesthesiologist at the HealthSouth Surgery Center in Tuscaloosa, about 60 miles southwest. Doctors at HealthSouth hospitals and medical centers are scrambling to make other arrangements for their patients in the event that the company files for bankruptcy and disrupts scheduled surgeries. Nurses and other HealthSouth workers are worried about their jobs.
The accusations against HealthSouth and Mr. Scrushy are a setback, both real and psychological, for Birmingham, Ms. Matlock said.
"You always want to be able to talk about role models and entrepreneurial heroes," she said, "and we've just lost a significant one."
Mr. Scrushy's plan to build the $300 million hospital perhaps best captures how his style affected Birmingham. HealthSouth officials called the project a "digital hospital" that would be the first medical center to keep all its records on crash-proof servers and connect doctors with patients any time, anywhere. At the same time, the officials threatened to move the project to another state if the Alabama legislature did not quickly approve legislation to allow HealthSouth to bypass the state's permit process for new hospitals.
Competing hospitals said that the hospital would be nothing new and that HealthSouth simply wanted a new hospital in one of Birmingham's most affluent areas.
HealthSouth easily defeated its critics, and the bill allowing the company to bypass the state's permit laws was signed into law in September 2001. Not even the Sept. 11 attacks could derail the bill. The Alabama Senate stayed in session after the attacks to pass the legislation.
But last week, the only people working on the construction site were a handful of roofers. "The digital hospital is a real big showpiece for Birmingham," said Dr. Williams, the HealthSouth anesthesiologist. "And people are thinking for a time it will be a showpiece to corporate greed."

HEADLINE: House and Senate Panels Approve Aid forAirlines 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 1 

 BODY:
The appropriations committees in the House and the Senate each voted today to give the airline industry about $3 billion in emergency assistance, enough to provide modest relief but nowhere near the amount needed to cure the industry's most acute problems.
 "You cannot call this a bailout," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the House majority leader. "I believe the industry needs to work through their market problems on their own." 
 The House and Senate measures have significant differences, which will ultimately have to be resolved in a conference committee. But both would compensate airlines for additional security costs and both would impose limits on salaries and bonuses paid to airline chief executives. 
Administration officials vowed to push for a smaller package in the conference committee. "A considerable gulf remains between Congress and the administration regarding the amount and structure of this assistance," Norman Y. Mineta, the secretary of transportation, said.
Both measures were attached to bills to provide more than $75 billion to cover costs tied to the war in Iraq, which Congressional leaders want to pass before April 11, when the Congressional spring break begins.
White House officials originally opposed any additional money for airlines, saying that the industry's problems stemmed from overcapacity and high costs rather than from the war against Iraq. But administration officials have made clear that they will agree to at least some money, if only to ensure quick approval of money for the war.
Even so, analysts say the airline assistance pales in comparison to the problems of major air carriers like United Airlines, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, and American Airlines, which narrowly avoided bankruptcy on Monday by obtaining wage concessions from labor.
The Air Transport Association, an industry group, estimated that airlines were on track to lose nearly $7 billion this year and that the war in Iraq would probably increase those losses another $4 billion.
Passenger numbers dropped about 10 percent in the week the war began. Executives worry that anxiety about terrorist reprisals could depress revenue for some time to come. Despite those problems, the airlines received grudging sympathy, at best, here. Republican and Democratic lawmakers alike said the airlines' biggest problems were of their own making.
Among the criticisms: the big hub-and-spoke carriers like United, American, Delta Air Lines and Northwest Airlines failed to reduce their capacity enough; failed to control their labor costs; and wasted money long before the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, by buying back their own shares at what turned out to be inflated prices.
Adding insult to injury, some say, airlines like Delta awarded their chief executives generous bonuses at the same time they were losing money and cutting jobs.
"A lot of mistakes have been made by the industry," said Senator Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, who helped write the Senate's airline proposal. "I think they made bad management decisions, and they had a terrible record of caving into labor unions."
The hostility was bipartisan. 
"This is a let's-pretend industry," said Representative David Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the House Appropriations Committee. "They pretend they operate in the free market and they pretend they are standing on their own two feet. And then every couple of years they come to Washington and ask for dollars to help them out."
The House plan would provide about $3.2 billion in assistance. It would reimburse airlines for some of the security fees that passengers have been paying since February 2002. The Senate plan would provide about $3.5 billion over all. About $2.8 billion of that would go to extend the government's program of subsidized war-risk insurance; it would also relieve passengers from paying some of the additional security fees; and it would reimburse airlines for about $900 million for new security requirements like fortified cockpit doors.
But the biggest difference between the House and Senate plans is that Senate Republicans agreed to incorporate partof a proposal by Senator Patty Murray, Democrat of Washington, to provide additional unemployment benefits for laid-off airline workers and extra money to airports and airlines for security improvements. Those items brought the Senate plan's cost to $3.5 billion.
Regardless of the final details, Republican leaders in both chambers appear set on passing slightly more than $3 billion in assistance. That is much less than the $15 billion in aid to airlines that Congress passed shortly after Sept. 11, 2001.
It is also less than the airlines wanted. Earlier this year, the Air Transport Association suggested reimbursing airlines for about $4 billion in added security costs and perhaps giving them a one-year holiday from $9 billion in ticket fees and taxes that now go into a federal fund for airport infrastructure and operations.
But the airlines were reluctant to ask for big loan guarantees under the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which Congress authorized to provide as much as $10 billion in loan guarantees to airlines reeling from Sept. 11.
Airline executives would prefer to receive tax relief or reimbursement for security costs that they would not have to pay back.

HEADLINE: In Trenton, Some Propose Raising Taxes On the Richest 

BYLINE:  By LAURA MANSNERUS 

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 1 

 BODY:
In a day of discouraging forecasts about New Jersey's fiscal future, some Democrats in the State Senate publicly called today for consideration of a tax increase on high earners that could alleviate some of the pain in Gov. James E. McGreevey's proposed budget.
 The suggestions were tentative, and the governor and most other Democratic leaders still oppose any income-tax increase. But after the first round of public hearings on the governor's $23.7 billion budget, legislators are casting about for any new sources of money. 
 Today the Senate Budget Committee heard the state treasurer and economists from Rutgers and from the legislative staff describe a faltering economy and anemic tax collections. The Office of Legislative Services projected revenues $321 million below Mr. McGreevey's estimates for the next fiscal year, a difference that is smaller than 1 percent but that is enough to wipe out the anticipated surplus.
The treasurer, John E. McCormac, also drew a grim picture, saying that with no economic rebound in sight, "We must slam on the brakes and bring all but essential spending to a halt."
But some committee members seized upon a projection that President Bush's tax cut proposal, if adopted in full, would provide $24 billion to New Jersey taxpayers and "an opportunity" for the state to tap into the benefits that accrue here.
"Maybe a piece of that should go to helping the poor, disabled and elderly," said Senator Bernard F. Kenny Jr., a Democrat from Hoboken. "We have a heavy moral responsibility here." Senator Kenny stopped short of endorsing a tax increase, as Speaker Albio Sires of the Assembly has done, but citing the "new reality of a massive tax cut" from Washington, he asked, "Why is it so out of the question?"
Proposals to raise the state's top income-tax rate, which are collectively being called a "millionaire's tax," have been circulating in Trenton for months. Last week a coalition of labor unions, religious groups and social service organizations proposed an increase in the top rate of 6.37 percent on incomes starting at $400,000 a year. The plan, to raise the rates by steps up to 9.5 percent on incomes over $1 million, would yield about $1 billion a year.
No such legislation has materialized, however, and until today the Legislature had never publicly discussed the idea.
"It's now on the table, and I'm totally opposed to it," Senator Leonard Lance, a Republican on the budget committee, declared after several Democrats said the top 1 percent or 2 percent of New Jersey residents would benefit disproportionately from a federal tax cut. "The notion that some of that revenue should be seized by the government in Trenton defeats the purpose of a tax cut."
And Senator Wayne Bryant, the Democratic co-chairman of the committee, said, "I don't think this is the time for us to be thinking about increasing taxes."
Mr. McCormac said that he and the governor also opposed any increases.
The suggestion of a windfall from Washington was made by Joseph J. Seneca, a Rutgers economist and the chairman of the state's Council of Economic Advisers, who presented his annual report to the Legislature on the state's economic conditions. Mr. Seneca said that President Bush's proposed $726 billion tax cut, which has been approved by the House, would result in $24 billion in benefits to New Jersey residents.
Mr. Bush's request has been cut in half by the Senate, however, and the cuts would take place over a 10-year period.
Barbara Buono, a Democratic committee member, said she would prefer a tax increase on incomes over $1 million to the plan in the governor's budget to cut property tax rebates to those making more than $100,000 a year.
"In my district, 3,253 households would be cut off under McGreevey's plan," Senator Buono said. "These are middle-income people."

HEADLINE: Detroit on a Mission: No Slip in Auto Sales 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 1 

 BODY:
Auto sales continued their sluggish pace last month, according to figures released today, prompting the Big Three automakers to broaden their no-interest loan offers.
 Sales actually fell less than many analysts had expected in March, just 0.4 percent from a year earlier, and cars were still selling at a fairly healthy rate. But automakers are clearly worried enough to offer a new round of deals that General Motors called unprecedented, setting up a test for the industry in April. 
 G.M. announced Monday eveningthat it would expand its incentives even beyond what it offered in its Keep America Rolling marketing campaign after the Sept. 11 attacks in 2001. Today, Chrysler and Ford said they would offer similar deals. 
While zero percent financing has been part of the car-buying landscape for a year and a half, the deals were typically only on three-year loans or were longer-term deals used late last year to clear out 2002 models. G.M.'s new deals extend zero percent financing to loans of up to five years on all its vehicles except Hummers. Ford and Chrysler will offer five-year zero percent deals on many of their vehicles as well. 
Ford, which celebrates its centennial this year, has its own twist, saying it will offer $5-a-day leases on some Mustangs and Ranger pickups, with 10 percent down, as a way to commemorate the $5-a-day wage its founder, Henry Ford, started paying workers in 1914 so that they could afford to buy the company's cars. 
The new incentives recall those put in place after Sept. 11, when G.M. started a price war among the Big Three that led to record-breaking monthly sales in October 2001 and made the auto industry a rare bright spot in an otherwise stagnant economy. Once again, the economy is stagnant amid the backdrop of war. Reports this week showed shrinking manufacturing activity and sluggish retail sales.
"If a customer is in fear, they're afraid to buy," said Al Clements, a minister and auto salesman at Athens Chevrolet in Athens, Ga., which started offering G.M.'s new deals today. But he said that there was even more uncertainty before the war began. "It's like this," he said. "You still have a job. Gas hasn't gone to $4 a gallon. It went down. There's nothing to fear."
Analysts and economists are again divided about whether the industry can serve as an economic balm. Some contend that customers are taking zero percent in stride and that overall incentive spending is not increasing from its already high levels. But others say that they think that extending the zero percent deals to five years from three will allow some buyers to get far lower monthly payments and could push some others to buy more luxurious vehicles.
"What may be a little bit different this time around is that the industry has huge inventories, so they are not going to bump up production," said Robert Schnorbus, chief economist at J. D. Power. "But it will clean out inventories and sustain production when it was at risk of significant cuts."
Stephen J. Girsky, an auto analyst at Morgan Stanley, was more skeptical. 
"April will be modestly better than March," he said. "We've sold so many cars since 9/11 that anybody who wanted to buy a car has bought one. It'll give some boost, but it doesn't look like the consumer is in the position to carry the ball the way they were last time."
Sales in March decreased to a seasonally adjusted annual selling rate of 16.2 million vehicles from 16.7 million in the month a year earlier. Though not a bad performance, the sales this year have been well short of last year's rate of 16.8 million units.
"I don't think it's a stretch to say we'll see something in the high 17 to 18 range in April," said George Pipas, Ford's chief sales analyst. "I look for a very strong April."
Paul Ballew, chief sales analyst at G.M., was somewhat more cautious. 
"I can't say I'd be surprised if the industry ran 17 million units in April. Would I be surprised if the industry ran 18 million units in April? Yes I would." 
"What happens in incentives after April, we'll have to see," he said. "We'll see how it plays out."
For many buyers, there has been reason to wait. 
"I was ready in February, but then I had several other expenses come up and had to take care of them first," said Marty Jacobs, 40, an architect from Summit, N.J., who recently bought a Jeep Liberty after thinking about the more expensive Jeep Grand Cherokee. 
"It's a crazy time we are living in. The economy is sour, the job market is tough, the war could be going on for months," he said.
In March, sales in the critical United States market fell 3 percent for G.M. and Chrysler, a unit of DaimlerChrysler, and 4.3 percent for Ford, according to the AutoData Corporation. Sales rose 9.2 percent at Toyota and 20.7 percent at Honda, underlining the competitive weakness of the Big Three, which spend far more on incentives. 
There were some signs of a shift to more fuel efficient vehicles. Though overall sales of S.U.V.'s remain strong, the best sellers are the smallest ones, like the Ford Escape and the Vue from G.M.'s Saturn brand. But G.M. officials have emphasized that too much should not be read into such a shift, and some buyers agree. 
In Denver, one car shopper, Juan Alonso, out car shopping, said he thought gas prices would top $2 a gallon next month. 
"It does make a difference," he said, "but gas is still cheaper than bottled water."

HEADLINE: Doubts on Tobacco Funds Hurt State Bonds 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The market is faltering for municipal bonds backed by revenues from the states' settlement with the tobacco companies, posing the prospect of higher costs to cash-short states.
 The State of Virginia delayed the closing of a $767 million tobacco bond sale yesterday after the ratings on $18 billion in similar bonds were cut by Moody's Investors Service. 
 The downgrading followed warnings from Philip Morris that it could not afford to post a $12 billion bond to appeal a court decision in Illinois. Those warnings came after an Illinois state court issued a $10.1 billion judgment against Philip Morris on March 21 and ruled that it would have to post a $12 billion bond in order to appeal. 
Philip Morris and rating agencies have said it could face bankruptcy, though Moody's said that outcome was unlikely. On Monday, Moody's lowered the credit rating of Philip Morris's parent, Altria, and Standard & Poor's said that it could lower the company's rating below investment grade, or to junk bond status.
The Illinois attorney general's office said yesterday that public documents from Altria showed that it could handle a bigger bond than it has acknowledged and that it was using bankruptcy as a threat. 
"It is not what it can afford to pay, but what it is willing to pay," said Melissa Merz, spokeswoman for Lisa Madigan, the Illinois attorney general. After talks with the state produced little progress, Philip Morris is expected to file a motion today to have the size of the bond reduced.
Virginia said it faced no immediate financing problem from the postponed bond issue. But many states, including New York, are working to bridge budget gaps by selling bonds tied to some or all of the first 25 years of expected payments from the tobacco companies, under a pact signed with 46 states that has been valued at $206 billion.
The tobacco bonds have sold off on the uncertainty. The tobacco bonds generally have been backed by the stream of revenue from the cigarette companies and not by revenues from the states or municipalities or counties that have sold them. This is why the Philip Morris bankruptcy threat has been so unsettling for the tobacco-backed bond market.
The states that want to issue the bonds may now have to pay more to entice investors. New York officials have considered backing the bonds with some state revenue to reduce the yields the state has to offer.
The sell-off has been swift. Josh Gonze, a portfolio manager at Thornburg Investment Management who considers tobacco bonds too risky to buy, said that yields on longer-term tobacco bonds shot as high as 8.25 percent yesterday. That is well above the 6.78 percent yield that resulted when Virginia priced its 30-year tobacco bonds in March.
For the month of March, the tobacco bond portion of the municipal bond market had a loss of 4.16 percent, in contrast to a total return of 0.06 percent for the entire municipal bond market, according to Lehman Brothers.
Because Moody's reduced the rating to A3 from A1 on the Virginia issue, the lead underwriter, Morgan Stanley, told the state it could not close the sale. The bonds were priced in late March with a closing date of April 3. They allowed purchasers to decline the bonds in case of a rating change before the sale closed.
"This was sold as an A1, and it is now an A3 and that is a material change," said Jody Wagner, the treasurer of Virginia and of the special corporation established by the state to sell the tobacco bonds.
Ms. Wagner said that she did not know what would happen to the sale of the bonds, but said that the state had breathing room because proceeds from the sale were not to be used to help close a budget deficit. The financing was to be used to endow a commission charged with revitalizing the state's tobacco growing regions.

HEADLINE: Health Workers, 2002 Pataki Allies, Jam Into Albany to Denounce His Cuts 

BYLINE:  By WINNIE HU and JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 1 

 BODY:
More than 30,000 health care workers thronged the mall in front of the Capitol today to protest $2 billion in cuts Gov. George E. Pataki has proposed in health care programs, just a few months after their leader, Dennis Rivera, gave the governor crucial support in his re-election bid.
 The demonstration was the largest in at least two decades, and many longtime politicians here said they had never seen so many protesters descend on the Capitol. Organizers say at least 37,000 health care workers came to town on chartered buses from Long Island to Buffalo. The union rented out the largest stadium in the capital region, the Pepsi Arena, and it still was not large enough to hold the crowds. 
 The protest was organized and financed by Mr. Rivera's union, 1199/S.E.I.U., and the Greater New York Hospital Association, an umbrella group for 220 hospitals, mostly in New York City. The event was laced with paradox. Just a few months ago, Mr. Rivera and many of the same health care workers stood squarely behind Governor Pataki, a Republican, and helped him win a landslide victory over the Democratic candidate, H. Carl McCall. The support of the union came after Mr. Pataki had pushed a bill through the Legislature a year ago to provide money for raises for Mr. Rivera's members. 
Yet today many of those same union members said they felt betrayed, as hospital executives warned that the governor's proposed cuts would lead to tens of thousands of layoffs. 
"When they go for election, they promise you that they are going to give you everything," said Yolanda Carela, 45, a home attendant who voted for Mr. Pataki. "But when they get elected, forget about it."
Ms. Carela echoed the bitter views of many other marchers on the capital today, who roundly lambasted the governor at every turn. But Mr. Rivera, other union officials and hospital executives who spoke to the crowds were careful in their remarks not to attack the governor. 
Instead of vilifying Mr. Pataki directly, Mr. Rivera and his top union officials acknowledged the state's budget problems, but contended that a tax increase on the wealthy would be a better choice than gutting the health care system. The union has also decided not to name the governor in a series of blistering television commercials and mailings urging New Yorkers to contact "Albany" to block the cuts.
Aides to the governor said that he was not surprised at the protest, but that he remained convinced that raising taxes would smother the economy, and that he saw no other choice than to cut health care, one of the fastest rising costs in the budget.
"It's not as if we went into this thinking we aren't going to take some heat, and the governor is prepared to do it because he thinks it's the right thing to do for the state," one senior aide said, speaking on the condition of anonymity.
Mr. Rivera said the show of force was necessary to send a message to the governor. "On this one, we believe the governor is wrong, and we hope and we pray that we can persuade him to change his mind," Mr. Rivera said.
Kenneth E. Raske, the president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, said the intent of the protest was to educate the public about the effect of the governor's budget, not to hammer the governor. 
"I think we still want to maintain dialogue," Mr. Raske said. "But it could change at a minute's notice."
The demonstration wasa major logistical undertaking. The union spent about $2 million to charter 900 buses, which picked up protesters at hundreds of places around the state. There were so many buses that part of the Thruway was shut down temporarily as they tried to exit. Lines of buses snaked through downtown Albany for hours, dropping off people in an orderly fashion. 
Not all the protesters fit into the Pepsi Arena, which was crammed with 17,000 people, wearing T-shirts and buttons in purple and gold, the union's colors. Thousands carried noisemakers and whistles. They waved signs, stomped their feet and made a deafening noise that at times drowned out the speakers. The crowd chanted: "Job-killing cuts? They gotta be nuts," making fun of Mr. Pataki's oft-repeated vow not to raise "job-killing taxes."
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, both made appearances. Mr. Silver, who took the stage as the theme from "Rocky" blared, assailed the governor, saying he had made the "wrong choices" in his budget. Senator Bruno, a Republican who wore a purple-and-gold-striped tie in honor of the union, vowed to "restore what is critical to meet the needs of the people."
Later, Mr. Rivera and Mr. Silver led the throngs in a march to the mall in front of the Capitol for a noisy rally. On the mall, organizers had erected a stage with giant televisions and towers of speakers. As the weather worsened, the protesters tried to stay warm dancing to calypso, soca and other Caribbean rhythms, through speaker after speaker. 
Shivering in the cold, many workers expressed disgust with the fickleness of politicians, especially the governor. Yet very few were willing to criticize Mr. Rivera's leadership, saying he had successfully wrested money for raises from the administration last year. Some said Mr. Pataki had hoodwinked Mr. Rivera, betraying the union's interests after the election.
"This is his last term, so the governor thinks, what the hell," said Cyril Morgan, 52, a nurse's aide from Manhattan. "But if he wants the Republicans to get back in there, he's got to do something or it's going to hurt them."
Many in the crowd said they regretted voting for the governor. "The next time, I'm not going to vote for him," said Felicita Melendez, 54, a home health aide.
Others said the sluggish national economy was the culprit. Monica Afflick, 62, a clerk at Mount Sinai Medical Center, said the health care industry would probably be squeezed even if a Democrat had won the governor's office. But she added, "We put him in there, so we need him to reply, to do what needs to be done."
For Democrats like Mr. Silver, the huge protest was a vindication of sorts, another sign that the labor movement, after supporting Mr. Pataki in the last election, had come home to the Democratic Party.
"We all make mistakes," Mr. Silver said of Mr. Rivera's shifting allegiances. "He was happy to admit it. And now they are letting the governor know that they made the wrong choice."
Mr. Pataki stayed out of the public eye, meeting with legislative leaders behind closed doors while the protest raged outside. His spokeswoman, Lisa Dewald Stoll, said the protesters should recall that the governor had made enormous investments in health care programs during his first two terms.
Union leaders maintain that the cuts Mr. Pataki has proposed to Medicaid reimbursement rates, along with an increase in taxes on hospital bills, would shrink the revenues hospitals rely on to operate. Some hospitals will be forced to close, hospital officials and union leaders said. They also maintain that the cuts will eliminate more than 22,000 jobs.
What is more, they argue, the governor's budget does not take into account the extra hundreds of millions of dollars needed to prepare for possible chemical, nuclear or biological attacks from terrorists.
Mr. Pataki, however, has contended that every sector of society must become more efficient in these fiscally hard times. The state must find a way to close an $11.5 billion shortfall, and Medicaid costs are one of the fastest growing parts of the budget.

HEADLINE: Who Makes More Than Who in New York 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
Most New Yorkers know they make more money here than they would doing the same job almost anywhere else -- even if what they are making never feels like enough. But who knew that fitness trainers and aerobics instructors make almost as much as sociologists and nearly twice as much as preschool teachers?
 Chief executives, lawyers, surgeons and brokers make more than most other groups, according to a report released yesterday by the Bureau of Labor Statistics. And the people who park their cars, do their pedicures, deliver their packages and care for their children are among those making the least. 
 In between those extremes falls a wide array of New Yorkers: architects earning less than fashion designers but slightly more than telemarketers; butchers whose wages top bakers'; public relations specialists making less than half what dentists earn but more than paralegals.
The report, the first of its kind by the New York office of the bureau, found that workers here earn on average 29.4 percent more per hour than the national average in their professions. In sales, which includes certain jobs in financial services, earnings exceeded the national average by more than 50 percent. Even those in the lowest-paid group, food preparation and serving, were making 25 percent more than the national average for that category.
The only region with a higher average wage than New York's is the San Francisco region, said Michael L. Dolfman, the New York regional commissioner for the bureau, which is a division of the United States Department of Labor.
There, average wages when last surveyed were 35.3 percent above the national average. The metropolitan area with the lowest average wage was Miami.
"For the first time, we've been able to quantify the difference in wages from the national level to the New York region," Mr. Dolfman said.
"People have talked about this but we believe this is one of the first reports that quantifies what that is, not only in general terms but by specific categories of employment."
The report is based on an annual mail survey of 400,000 employers nationwide. Using data collected in 1998, 1999 and 2000, the bureau estimated average wages in 2001. Employers were asked to report the number of employees they had in each of 12 wage groups. The groups range from "under $6.75 an hour" to "$70 an hour and over."
"If you're making $8 million, you're not going to tell us that you make $8 million," Mr. Dolfman said, referring to the leeriness with which some people approach federal questionnaires about income.
"So, the highest level on our scale is $70 an hour." He added, "People are willing to say that they make X if they really makes 10 times X."
For that reason, the report contains little detail about incomes at the high end of the spectrum. In addition, because the data were collected before 2001, the report does not reflect the effects of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack and the recession.
According to the report, the broad occupational groups with the highest average hourly wages in New York, as well as nationally, are management and the law.
Among managers, chief executives top the list. In the legal profession, the bureau put the hourly wage of the estimated 42,450 lawyers in the region at $52.21.
People in the category of securities, commodities and financial services sales had an hourly wage of $51.70. Surgeons and several other groups of medical specialists were equally or more highly paid.
At the other end of the scale, the report estimated the hourly wage of fast food cooks at $6.35, manicurists and pedicurists at $7.33, home health aides at $8.50 and couriers and messengers at $9.64. The average for child care workers was $10.01, preschool teachers $13.50 and maids and housekeepers $13.66.
The bureau estimated the average wage of fitness trainers and aerobics instructors at $24.49, sociologists at $28.62, architects at $31.70 and fashion designers at $33.65.
The New York region studied includes New York City and Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties.

HEADLINE: Once a Home, Now a Museum of Fate Unknown 

BYLINE:  By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: MARTINSDALE, Mont., March 25 

 BODY:
This is not the kind of place where you would expect to find a Chippendale chair or Sevres china. The heads and skins of animals, stuffed and mounted on the walls, are more in keeping with local tastes in decor.
 But Martinsdale, which has about 60 full-time residents and is about 100 miles east of Helena, is home to one of this state's biggest fortunes, part of which was on display in the Charles M. Bair Family Museum, which holds more Hepplewhite and Louis XV furniture than a Manhattan antiques store. 
 "Was" on display because the museum, which was the home of Bair and his family until the death of his daughter Alberta M. Bair in 1993, is to be closed this year so the advisory board that controls her $40 million trust can consider ways to make the museum more self-sustaining. 
"The financials are very, very difficult for this museum," Wayne Hirsch, a board member and president of U.S. Bancorp's operations in Montana, said, noting that fewer than 5,000 people visited the museum last summer. 
"We're not trying to do something sinister here," Mr. Hirsch said. "We're trying to make a decision on a very, very difficult issue."
 The local community, which depends on the museum for tourism, is in an uproar over the decision of the five-member board, which includes two bank representatives.
 Residents say the bank controls the board and would rather manage money than Navajo rugs and crystal chandeliers. They say they believe that if the museum is closed, it will never reopen and that its collection, once valued at almost $10 million by Sotheby's, will be dispersed or moved so it will lack meaning.
 "It would be kind of like moving Stonehenge," said Kelsey Miller, a freshman at Carroll College in Helena whose high school class did research at the museum for a Montana Heritage Project.
 Barbara O. Roberts, conservator at the Frick Collection in New York, concurs. She spent several months with Miss Bair before she died to get the collection museum-ready. "They have wanted to disperse the collection from the very beginning," she said of the bank.
"It means a tremendous amount to this community," Ms. Roberts said. "I do feel very strongly that it was her money, she understood she was being advised to do something else with it, and she still chose to make a museum."
 But Miss Bair gave the board the option to close the museum after five years if it "became an extreme burden on the trust," Mr. Hirsch said, while refusing to disclose the trust's exact terms. "For those people who knew Alberta Bair, she was a very, very fiscally responsible person." 
 Local residents say Miss Bair was tight-fisted. Many said they recalled seeing her and her sister, Marguerite, stop their white Cadillac on the road and step out in full-length mink coats to pick up cans and bottles and return them for the deposits. 
 The museum does not make much of a dent in Miss Bair's trust. Charlie Bair came to Montana as a railroad conductor with, legend has it, 14 cents and seven green apples in his pocket. He parlayedthat into a fortune in minerals, finance and sheep.
 Marguerite and Alberta were brought up as ladies, but Alberta shared her father's interests: ranching, hunting and wheeling and dealing. She was seldom seen without a tumbler of vodka over ice and a cigarette. It was Marguerite who picked the antiques, Alberta who bargained for them. The house was built around the collection they amassed during trips to Europe, and those who knew them have no doubt they intended it to be a museum.
 "Alberta always told me she was going to give the house to the state to keep as a museum, and she was outraged when the state wanted her to give the money to do that," said El-Donna Pierce, whose husband was the ranch foreman. "She said she might as well do it herself if she was going to have to pay for it."
 It costs $250,000 a year to run the museum, including a $149,500 management fee to the C. M. Russell Museum in Great Falls, Mont., Mr. Hirsch said.
 That is 0.48 percent of the $52 million in Miss Bair's trust on April 30, 2001, the last year for which data is available, and 0.15 percent of the $167 million left by her family. Mr. Hirsch said those assets have fallen 15 percent to 20 percent since then. 
U.S. Bancorp recently spurned an offer from the Tenderfoot Foundation, an environmental preservation group, that included a $2 million contribution for the museum. The foundation has been trying to buy 8,000 acres northwest of White Sulphur Springs that is held by the Bair Ranch Foundation, another repository of the Bair fortune. But the bank, which controls the Bair foundation, was not interested.
 Mr. Hirsch said that the $7.5 million offered for the land was not what the bank had expected and that the bank was concerned that a sale would incite more community ire.
 But $2 million would have gone a long way toward building an endowment for the museum, which is what local residents say they hope to do. They say the local community could run the museum more cost effectively.
 Russell Van Lieshout, a graphic designer and desktop publisher who lives in White Sulphur Springs, about 30 miles west of Martinsdale, has done an analysis that suggests that the museum could manage on a budget of $130,250 if it had 9,000 visitors and raised ticket prices. "The problem with this museum is not that it costs too much," Mr. Van Lieshout said, "but that it hasn't been properly advertised."
 Promoting the museum fell to the C. M. Russell Museum, and residents say that for the first year or so, the Russell ran billboard and print ads in Billings and elsewhere in the state and promoted the museum to the elderly, who came on day buses.
 The Bair Museum attracted at least 9,400 visitors in its first year and at least 7,600 in the second year, setting off the closest thing Wheatland and Meagher Counties, neither of which have a stoplight, have seen to an economic boom in recent history. With only 4,100 residents between them, 20 percent of whom live in poverty, the extra purchases of gasoline and lunch made a difference.
 "If the museum closes, I'll lose between 50 and 75 percent of my business," said Cheryl Marchi, who with her husband, Peter, owns the Crazy Mountain Inn in Martinsdale, which is famous locally for its chicken-fried steak. "Five thousand visitors may not sound like much to someone in New York City, but it's huge to people like us."
 After the initial promotion, very little has been done, residents say. Brochures for the Bair Museum list only the Russell Museum's phone number and address, as does the AAA guide. 
 Myrna Conrad, the museum's first caretaker, was forbidden to distribute brochures to visitors. 
 Mrs. Conrad said she was directed to steer tours away from the museum's three paintings by the Western artist C. M. Russell, a friend of Charlie Bair. In the spring of 1997, the Russell Museum removed them to Great Falls. "The director of operations and security at the Russell Museum said they were restoring the frames, and one did have a fragile frame," Mrs. Conrad said. "But then they informed me that the paintings weren't coming back, that they would be replaced by same-size photographic reproductions."
 She said she was told not to say anything about the removal of the paintings, but she told Lee Rostad, a longtime friend of Miss Bair who sat on the first advisory board. The paintings were returned. 
 Now they are gone again, as are several Henry Sharp paintings and two large Paul Storr wine coolers that have been taken out of the house pending the museum's reopening.

HEADLINE: A RESPIRATORY ILLNESS: HONG KONG; 
Virus Imperils Commerce And Economy In Asian Hub

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, April 1 

 BODY:
In the nearly six years since its transition to China, this former British colony has endured two recessions, an outbreak of avian flu, slumping confidence in government and a collapse in government revenues. But these setbacks are being dwarfed by this year's explosive outbreak of a new respiratory disease, which is spreading panic and rapidly undermining confidence in the future of one of the world's most dynamic cities.
 In a sign of just how far public confidence has fallen, crowds mobbed supermarkets today to buy up rice and other essentials in response to a rumor, spread partly by an Internet hoax, that the entire city would be labeled an "infected area" and face an international quarantine. The stock market fell, and the Hong Kong dollar came under pressure in currency markets as government officials went on television to deny the rumor and appeal for calm. 
 But such scenes, damaging to any locality, are devastating for a city that exists as the crossroads of Asia and a gateway to China.
Hong Kong has Asia's busiest airport for international passenger departures and international air freight. Its port handles more freight containers each year than any other port in the world.
The city's modern health, transportation and communications systems have helped induce nearly 1,000 multinational companies to put their regional headquarters here, creating an enormous service sector for the 100,000 expatriates who live here and even more who visit on business.
But it is precisely Hong Kong's position as a transportation hub and a desirable headquarters location that is now threatened by the outbreak of SARS, the severe acute respiratory syndrome. The disease has spread far faster here than anywhere else, partly because officials were slow to quarantine patients who then infected visitors.
Countries from Australia to the United States are actively discouraging their citizens from visiting, and a growing number are having doctors meet flights from here to assess the health of each passenger. (Today, an American Airlines flight from Tokyo was quarantined on the runway in San Jose, Calif., after two passengers and two crew members complained of SARS-like symptoms. A baby girl in Massachusetts was also thought to be suffering with the disease.) 
At the same time, many expatriate business people and affluent local residents are sending spouses and children to less disease-ridden cities elsewhere. Mark Simon, an American businessman here, has been performing the same calculations as many people with the financial wherewithal to leave. His 18-month-old son briefly needed hospital treatment for a minor illness before the current outbreak, and he worries whether quality medical care would be available for his son at this city's increasingly overburdened hospitals if a similar incident were to occur now.
So Mr. Simon's wife and son have moved into a hotel in Manila, and he worries that some companies may be less eager to invest here if it becomes harder to persuade employees to move here. "My wife won't come back until this is cleared up," he said, adding, "The spouses say, 'You dragged me out to Asia, and it was supposed to be safe.' "
Making matters worse, anyone who does fall ill with SARS is likely to be stuck here, most likely in one of the city's increasingly crowded pneumonia wards, where rows of patients lie curled up in balls on their beds, battling fever and chills. Medical evacuation, long offered by multinationals for overseas employees, has become virtually impossible. Commercial carriers are refusing to carry SARS patients under any circumstances, and even air ambulance services are now warning that they may not be able to move people with SARS.
International SOS, one of the world's largest medical evacuation and corporate security firms and the main provider of evacuations in Asia, is actively promoting its services now in Kuwait because of the war in Iraq, but it is virtually ignoring Hong Kong, a company spokeswoman said. Because of the difficulty in persuading governments and hospitals to accept SARS patients, as well as the uncertainty of how to transport them safely by air without infecting others, she said, "such patient movements are therefore unlikely."
A steady diet of similarly grim health news has emptied restaurants, hotels and shops as tourists flee and residents stay home. That has hurt the Hong Kong economy more than it would most Asian economies because most of the manufacturing that used to take place here has moved across the border to low-wage cities in mainland China.
