HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: THE HOMETOWN; 
Rescue in Iraq and a 'Big Stir' in West Virginia

BYLINE:  By DOUGLAS JEHL and JAYSON BLAIR 

DATELINE: PALESTINE, W.Va., April 2 

 BODY:
Even today, Linda Davies was still clutching the note that Pfc. Jessica Lynch, her former kindergarten student, sent six weeks ago from the desert of Kuwait, set out on pastel paper in a schoolgirl's round handwriting and marveling at how far she had come from her home in rural West Virginia.
 "I can say I've been to places that half of Wirt County will never see," Private Lynch, 19, wrote with the wonder and awe of a country girl who had not visited Charleston, the state capital, until she graduated from high school but had now embarked on what she plainly saw as a great adventure. 
In just a few months, the private wrote on Feb. 21, she had visited Mexico, Germany and Kuwait and now, as a young Army supply clerk, was poised to set out toward Iraq as soon as President Bush gave the order.
"I will still be a teacher," Mrs. Davies said in summing up Private Lynch's plans for the future. "But I want to travel first." 
Private Lynch's friends and relatives never imagined that her travels would include days of captivity in Iraq, a daring rescue by American commandos, and a flight on a military transport plane that rushed her today to a hospital in Germany. Page B10. 
Her family said military officials told them that she has broken legs and gunshot wounds.
This morning, hours after Private Lynch was rescued from an Iraqi hospital, Ms. Davies and others here said they were sure she had been saved by the power of prayer and by the resilience fostered by her modest West Virginia roots.
"I know there were people all over the world who were praying for Jessi," said Ms. Davies, who taught Jessica Lynch in kindergarten 14 years ago and had remained close to her. "We know a miracle has occurred."
Outside the Lynch family's tin-roofed, white wood-frame home at the end of a single-lane gravel road, Private Lynch's father, Gregory Lynch Sr., 43, a self-employed truck driver in heavy boots and blue jeans, put it a different way.
"What she has learned growing up in the country and woods, and by what her brother put her through, that kind of prepared her for a lot," Mr. Lynch said.
Asked what he might tell his daughter, Mr. Lynch grinned through his exhaustion.
"The little brat's caused a big stir in this county," he said, adding: "As soon as she's capable, we're planning one heck of a big shindig." He got his chance to talk to her this afternoon.
Dozens of people, some traveling from more than 100 miles away gathered today outside the home, surrounded by woods and farmland in the heart of Appalachia, to congratulate the family. They listened to a radio on the hill tuned into a popular country music station in Charleston, WQBE-FM, that was playing dedications to Private Lynch all day. 
Private Lynch, the second of three children, joined the Army in 2001, not as a career but as a way station, her friends and family said today, a path to the college education that her family could not otherwise afford and, ultimately, to a job as a kindergarten teacher.
It is a route that is not unusual in Wirt County, about 70 miles north of Charleston, with a population of about 5,000 and an unemployment rate of about 15 percent. Private Lynch's older brother, Gregory Jr., 21, enlisted in the Army on the same day as his sister; her younger sister, Brandi, 18, now a high school senior, has also enlisted and is due to begin her military service in August.
But the speed, then the horror, and now the relief of Private Lynch's personal journey has left people in this community overwhelmed, first with shock and now with jubilation for a young woman who had seen little of West Virginia, much less the world, when she left for the Army.
"She kept saying that this is what New York City must be like," said Glenda Nelson, a family friend who took Private Lynch on her first visit to Charleston for a shopping trip, just before she left for her Army post at Fort Bliss, Tex.
The two spent several hours shopping for clothes and other items Private Lynch needed, and Ms. Nelson said the young woman was much impressed by the lights and buildings in the state capital, a city of about 200,000.
"She is nothing but a wholesome West Virginia country girl," Ms. Nelson said. "I told her that she needed to get out and see some of the world. I didn't mean Iraq."
Ms. Nelson and her husband, Donald, sat in their kitchen today, staring at their own letter from Private Lynch, which arrived on Monday. In the time it took the letter, dated March 18, to make its way from Kuwait, Private Lynch's unit, the 507th Maintenance Company, was attacked during some of the first fighting in Nasiriya, she was declared missing in action for five days and yellow ribbons began to pop up all over town.
"We just bawled like babies when we got the letter," Mr. Nelson said today. "It just tore us apart to think of how scared she was or what might have happened to her."
But on Tuesday, a day after the letter arrived, the Nelsons and just about everyone else in this community quickly learned that the Lynches had received a telephone call saying their daughter had been rescued.
The news sent Wirt County into a frenzy, with friends, relatives, teachers, politicians, state troopers, firefighters and other residents descending upon the Lynch house at the end of Mulberry Lane.
This afternoon, Mr. Nelson said the ordeal just re-emphasized the power of community, prayer and what a special woman Private Lynch is. "She was smart and gentle, a good country girl," he said. "I think the reason she survived through this is that she is a true angel and God knows that he wants her with us for some more time."
"I hope to God that the whole country does not forget about what a special hero we have in Jessi Lynch," Mr. Nelson added, making clear that he had in mind some antiwar protesters who he believes have been too hard on the soldiers fighting in Iraq.
At Wirt County High School this morning, in Elizabeth, the county seat, the 300 students gathered in a packed auditorium to sing songs like "God Bless America" in honor not just of Private Lynch but also of other soldiers, some of them the brothers and cousins of students.
"When students here get out of school," said Rodney Watson, the high school softball coach, "it seems like there are two things they can do, which is either hang on the corner or go off to college or the military, and college takes money."
He remembers Private Lynch as the feisty right fielder who played for four years on his team. "Being scrappy probably helped her get through this thing," Mr. Watson said.
Gregory Jr., an Army private home on emergency leave from his base at Fort Bragg, N.C., acknowledged he had not been enthusiastic about his sister's decision to join the Army, partly out of brotherly concern and partly because he wondered whether a woman of her small stature could succeed as a soldier.
But he said of his sister: "She's strong-headed, and now that I've seen Jessi do it, I realize that it's possible."
This morning both West Virginia University and Marshall University, also in West Virginia, offered Private Lynch financial assistance to attend college and pursue her dream of becoming a teacher.
"We've read about her reason for joining the military," said David C. Hardesty Jr., the president of West Virginia University, "and along with her love for her country and her concern for the plight of the Iraqis, she wanted to better her life through a college education."
Aides to West Virginia's governor, Bob Wise, a Democrat whose office sent an official to assist the Lynch family the day she disappeared in Iraq, said he was considering issuing a proclamation declaring a "Jessica Lynch Day." The aides said dozens of calls of congratulations from other states have come in for the Lynch family and for West Virginians.
"I really do consider this a miracle in the mountains," Governor Wise said.
Ms. Lynch, who will turn 20 on April 26, had been assigned at Fort Bliss with the 507th Maintenance Company. She had recently re-enlisted for another four-year stint and was scheduled to be reassigned to duty in Hawaii starting in November.
From Kuwait, where she arrived with her unit in February, she found time to write to friends like Mrs. Davies and the Nelsons about the decisions that had taken her so far from home. "I've been traveling so much, but it's cool, because I want to," she wrote to Mrs. Davies on Feb. 21, adding: "Keep me and all soldiers in your prayers and thoughts, and we will do our best to protect you all."
Apart from brief glimpses of her strapped on a stretcher in video footage on television this morning, Private Lynch's relatives had learned little more about her condition today beyond what they first heard on Tuesday in a 6:15 p.m. telephone call from an Army colonel whom they would not name: that she had been rescued.
Pamela Nicolais, a cousin of Private Lynch, said that a military official told the family that she had "limped to a hospital in Iraq" after her unit was ambushed, and had been turned over to Iraqi forces.
Senior military officials provided only a few details about the intelligence that led to Private Lynch's rescue, but family members said they were told that she was located because an Iraqi doctor handed a note to a Marine indicating that she was at a hospital, listed the room number and added that she was being tortured.
Family members said they were told that she had a gunshot wound in the leg that military officials believe occurred during the ambush of her unit. But the family members also said they were heartened by the images they saw on television that showed her looking clear-eyed. 
The military did not publicly disclosed Private Lynch's injuries, but one military official confirmed that she did have multiple gunshot wounds and broken bones. No further details about how the injuries occurred were provided.
Through the nine days when Private Lynch was missing, the family held nightly prayer gatherings at their home, relatives said, and her parents in particular had never abandoned their belief that she was alive.
Inside her cramped living room, where she sat on an overstuffed green loveseat, Private Lynch's mother, Deadra, 40, said a motherly intuition she felt earlier on Tuesday had given her confidence her daughter would be found.
"I was up and down, but I just knew yesterday was going to be the day," Mrs. Lynch said. "A mama knows."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 4, 2003

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about rejoicing in Palestine, W.Va., over the rescue of Pfc. Jessica Lynch, a hometown soldier taken prisoner in Iraq, misstated the name of her street and the population of Charleston, the city she visited for the first time before leaving for the Army. The address is Mayberry Run, not Mulberry Lane. The population of Charleston is about 55,000, not 200,000.
CORRECTING THE RECORD; The Articles; Witnesses and Documents Unveil Deceptions In a Reporter's Work

On Sunday, May 11, 2003, The Times published a two-full-page accounting of misrepresentations and plagiarism by Jayson Blair, who resigned on May 1 as a reporter. This article was among those described. The description:

Rescue in Iraq And A 'Big Stir' in West Virginia
APRIL 3, 2003

WHEREABOUTS -- Hotels in the vicinity of Palestine, W.Va., had no record of Mr. Blair. His co-writer, as well as a photographer who was stationed at the Lynch home for The Times, said they did not see Mr. Blair. Mr. Blair gave his editors and his co-writer a number where he could be reached on April 2, the day the article was written. The number belonged to Glenda and Donald Nelson, friends of the Lynch family; the Nelsons said that they never met or spoke to Mr. Blair. The Nelsons live in Marmet, W.Va., about a two-hour drive from Palestine.

PLAGIARISM -- Mr. Blair describedthe Nelsons' talking about Private Lynch and a letter they had received from her: "Ms. Nelson and her husband, Donald, sat in their kitchen today, staring at their own letter from Private Lynch, which arrived on Monday. In the time it took the letter, dated March 18, to make its way from Kuwait, Private Lynch's unit, the 507th Maintenance Company, was attacked during some of the first fighting in Nasiriya, she was declared missing in action for five days and yellow ribbons began to pop up all over town.
" 'We just bawled like babies when we got the letter,' Mr. Nelson said today. 'It just tore us apart to think of how scared she was or what might have happened to her.' "
In an Associated Press article that ran on April 2, Ms. Barker wrote: "Before the war started, Private Lynch wrote a letter to family friends Glenda and Don Nelson. The letter, dated March 18, arrived on Monday. 'She said she was ready to go to war and was just waiting on President Bush's word, but I could tell she was scared,' said Don Nelson. 'We bawled like babies when we read it. It tore us up.' "
Mr. Blair also used details and quotations about a shopping trip to Charleston that was recounted in an Associated Press article from March 25. 
In addition, Mr. Nelson's quotation about Private Lynch being "a wholesome West Virginia country girl" appears to have been adapted from a comment in the April 2 Associated Press article made by Lorene Cumbridge, a cousin of Private Lynch. "She's just a West Virginia country girl. Warm-hearted. Outgoing," Ms Cumbridge said.
Readers with information about other articles by Jayson Blair that may be false wholly or in part are asked to e-mail The Times: retrace@nytimes.com.

HEADLINE: Former Mayor of Asbury Park Is Accused of Bribery Attempt 

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 2 

 BODY:
A former Asbury Park mayor and a political aide were arrested today on federal charges that they had conspired to bribe a City Council member with the promise of "a seven-figure" payment in exchange for supporting a developer's bid to renew the city's oceanfront.
 Kenneth E. Saunders Sr., 58, who was mayor from 1996 to 2001, and Rayfield James Jr., 46, a local political operative, were arrested this morning at their homes in Asbury Park, a city in central New Jersey. The arrests brought to five the number of Asbury Park figures who have been charged with corruption by the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, in the last eight months. 
 According to the six-count indictment handed up by a grand jury, the two men tried in a series of meetings in the first six months of 2000 to persuade a council member to join a voting bloc supporting a redevelopment proposal for the city.
Prosecutors charge that the defendants told the council member that the developer would pay them for their votes through Mr. James in some instances, and in others give them an interest in the resulting project. The council member was secretly working with federal investigators and recorded many of the conversations, investigators said.
The indictment names neither the council member nor the developer.
Mr. Saunders, who also faces five counts of tax fraud, also promised that he would take steps to remove a local tax lien from a property owned by the council member, according to the indictment.
No money ever changed hands, said investigators, and the tax lien was never removed. But in recorded conversations, Mr. James, saying that he was acting as intermediary between the developer, Mr. Saunders, and the bloc of council members, promised that they would all be millionaires if they helped approve the $750 million to $1 billion redevelopment project, according to the indictment.
Mr. Saunders and Mr. James, in leg shackles and handcuffs, made their first appearance in Federal District Court here today. Magistrate Judge Mark Falk set $50,000 bail for each man and required Mr. James to undergo drug testing and drug treatment.
Mr. Saunders's court-appointed lawyer, Anthony Iacullo, said that his client had assured him that he had done nothing wrong. Mr. James's court-appointed lawyer, Kenneth Kayser, declined to comment, saying that he had yet to discuss the charges in any detail with his client.
Last October, an Asbury Park developer, Philip Konvitz, and a former city councilman, James Condos, were indicted on bribery and extortion charges in connection with the oceanfront redevelopment effort, and they are awaiting trial. Shortly after that, the Asbury Park city manager, Terrance Weldon, who was also the elected mayor of Ocean Township and a protege of Mr. Konvitz, was indicted on charges of accepting bribes from local developers in his role as mayor. Mr. Weldon pleaded guilty and is awaiting sentencing.
Mr. Christie, speaking after the court appearances, said, "Rest assured this office is not done in Asbury Park and Monmouth County."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Supreme Court Upholds State Law on Managed Care
States can require managed health care plans to accept any qualified doctor who wants to be a participating provider, the Supreme Court ruled in a unanimous decision that resolved a legal dispute over state health care regulation.
 The court upheld a 1994 Kentucky law that prevents H.M.O.'s from limiting the pool of doctors or from retaliating against doctors who recommend too many treatments or complain about working conditions. About half the states have enacted similar laws, known as "any willing provider" laws. Page A16. 

Insurance industry officials said they would not let the Supreme Court decision hobble managed care. A16.

Several employees of HealthSouth will plead guilty today in a growing accounting fraud investigation. C4.

British Cable Company Names Chief
Cable and Wireless appointed Francesco Caio, 45, left, chief executive, succeeding Graham Wallace, who resigned. Mr. Caio, who once ran an Italian wireless company, won praise from some analysts. But two investor groups challenged a proposed guaranteed first-year bonus of $580,000, equivalent to 54 percent of his salary. World Business, Section W.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation can proceed with its first big television venture in Continental Europe, the European Commission said. World Business, Section W.

Penguin Press Signs First Authors
Penguin announced the first group of authors signed to the Penguin Press, the new imprint founded by Ann Godoff, the former editor in chief of the Random House Trade Group, one of Penguin's biggest competitors. C6.

Predictions for Fall Ad Sales Are Cut
The ebullient forecasts for a record upfront market this spring -- when the television networks will sell most of their advertising for the 2003-4 season -- are being tempered by the war. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C6.

Fox News Channel and MSNBC are engaged in more than just a ratings competition over their war coverage. C6.

HEADLINE: Paul H. Boeker, 64, Dies; Former Ambassador to Jordan 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, April 2 

 BODY:
Paul H. Boeker, a former United States ambassador to Jordan and Bolivia and president of a San Diego research institution aimed at strengthening ties between North America and Latin America, died on Saturday at his home in San Diego. He was 64.
 The cause was a brain tumor, his family said. 
 In 27 years in public service, Ambassador Boeker helped broker meetings between Jordan and Israel and assisted in Bolivia's transformation to democracy in the 1970's.
Mr. Boeker's foreign service career included postings in Germany and Colombia and service on the State Department Policy Planning Staff under Secretaries of State Henry A. Kissinger and George P. Shultz. From 1980 to 1983, he was director of the Foreign Service Institute, which trains government employees in foreign affairs and languages.
He was appointed ambassador to Bolivia by President Jimmy Carter, and served there from 1977 to 1980. He received the State Department's Superior Honor Award for protecting American lives during a coup in 1979.
Mr. Boeker later helped Bolivia shift its government structure from a military dictatorship to a democratic system, said Alexander Watson, a former ambassador to Peru who worked with him.
Under President Ronald Reagan, he was ambassador to Jordan from 1984 to 1987. He was credited with brokering secret meetings between Jordanian and Israeli officials on many issues, including telecommunications, counterterrorism and water sharing.
For the last 14 years of his career,he was president of the Institute of the Americas, on the campus of the University of California at San Diego. The privately financed institute works to strengthen political, economic and social ties between North America and Latin America.
Mr. Boeker was born in St. Louis on May 2, 1938. He graduated magna cum laude from Dartmouth College and received a master's degree in economics from the University of Michigan.
His wife, Margaret Macon Campbell Boeker of San Diego, said he had decided to become a diplomat in high school when he was an exchange student in Germany.
Besides his wife, he is survived by two daughters, a son and two grandchildren.

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
That Rare Mix: Passion, Politics and Urban Vision

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
IT does not speak well of the sum of impassioned expertise on urban planning at the highest levels of government that much of it was buried Monday at Arlington National Cemetery.
 Daniel Patrick Moynihan was all but unique among the nation's most prominent elected officials in having a vision of the built environment. That is less an elegiac sentiment than a reflection of the fairly low political stature of urban planning,a necessarily long-range endeavor that suffers in a system churned by election cycles and driven by popularity polls. 
 "There's nobody now to step into that empty niche," said David M. Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, an architect whose career intersected Mr. Moynihan's at two important junctures: the planning of Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington in the late 60's and, more recently, the expansion of Pennsylvania Station into the James A. Farley Building across Eighth Avenue. 
Credited by admirers with having had a native eye for architecture, Mr. Moynihan, a four-term Democratic senator from New York, also benefited from sheer endurance. His most significant planning effort, the redevelopment of Pennsylvania Avenue, survived three presidential administrations. The transfer of Governors Island from federal to local control survived two.
And Pennsylvania Station has been gestating for a decade, through three mayors and two governors, though state officials say it will soon begin in earnest. (They have only been saying that since 1997.) Now scheduled for completion in 2008, it will be called the Daniel Patrick Moynihan Station.
"He said urban planning is not for the short-winded," recalled Alexandros E. Washburn, an architect who served on Mr. Moynihan's Senate staff and then as president of the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation.
Mr. Moynihan was not short-winded. In either sense. He badgered balky federal agencies and "dithering" city and state officials over whom he had little or no control. Fairly typical was his outburst 20 years ago when the General Services Administration seemed to be taking too long to renovate the landmark Custom House on Bowling Green.
"I got $29 million authorized and appropriated to get on with it," Senator Moynihan said at the time. "What do we have to do? Go to court and get a writ of mandamus? Fix up the building!"
But he played more roles than sideline agitator. He was largely responsible for the Intermodal Surface Transportation Efficiency Act of 1991, which broadened the ways in which states could spend federal transportation money.
And long before his election to the Senate, he was vice chairman of the President's Temporary Commission on Pennsylvania Avenue. In that role, he seemed to be heir to the planning hubris of the day.
"We might build the first fully modern, fully human inner city setting in the nation, possibly in the world," Mr. Moynihan wrote in his foreword to the plan. But the tone of the document -- even the graphics -- told a different story. In 68 illustrations, one could count only about a dozen recognizable people, all of them white, to depict a city that was by then 75 percent black.
Contemporary critics, among them Clifford L. Alexander Jr., who had been chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in the Johnson administration, deplored the focus on a ceremonial avenue when the city was trying to recover from the devastating riots of 1968. "Some of the scars are still there," Mr. Alexander said in an interview this week.
PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE does not have the vitality it could and should have had," said Mr. Alexander, who is now president of Alexander & Associates in Washington, a management consulting firm. "Mixed use doesn't mean a few grand spaces. It means jazz clubs and small townhouses and open parks where people actually come to play chess and basketball."
Though Mr. Moynihan was hailed as a preservationist, the 1969 plan called for demolishing the historic Willard Hotel and tearing down all but the tower of the cavernous Post Office Building. Both were saved and rejuvenated.
Ultimately, Pennsylvania Avenue was transformed into an imposing boulevard of plazas, squares, landscaping and new buildings. "The steadying hand of time weeds out some of the worst follies," said Mr. Childs, who was director of the plan. "Unfortunately, it also weeds out some of the best ideas."
One lost idea embraced by Mr. Moynihan involved relocating the Joe DiMaggio Highway from an elevated viaduct along the Hudson River, between 59th and 72nd Streets, to ground level. Invited by several civic groups in 1989 to tour the area, the senator took off zestfully into the rat-infested waterfront marshes.
"He's scrambling over the rocks, rattling on about the Peloponnesian War, DeWitt Clinton and chiding the labor guys about how much it costs to hire a bulldozer driver," said Kent L. Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, one of the groups. "At the end of it he decided, 'This highway ought to be moved.' Moynihan's instant ability to see value in things wasn't exactly democratic, but it was visionary."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Daniel Patrick Moynihan and President Bill Clinton in May 1999, with a model of the James A. Farley Building, which is to replace Pennsylvania Station and be named for Mr. Moynihan. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Doomsday Budget 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
For months Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who prides himself on his salesmanship, has used the soft sell when it comes to Albany. 
 The mayor has continued to heap praise on Gov. George E. Pataki even after the governor proposed a budget in January that would hurt, not help, the city. And while he flew Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, on his private jet to Bermuda for some golf last year, both officials, who are in heated state budget negotiations, say that they have not felt much pressure from him lately. 
 Now Mr. Bloomberg is preparing to let his April 15 budget do his talking for him.
The mayor is preparing a doomsday backup plan with $1 billion in further spending cuts, and as many as 15,000 layoffs in it, in case the city fails to get the help it is seeking from Albany. The implications are clear: if state officials do not approve a $1 billion commuter tax, and all the other help that the city is seeking to balance its budget, they could end up shouldering the blame for draconian cuts and layoffs. 
For the tacit threat to work, though, it must be believed. 
Asked if she thought the contingency plan that is being drafted was a pressure tactic or a real possibility, Diana Fortuna, the president of the Citizens Budget Commission, noted that the two possibilities are not mutually exclusive.
"If these new cuts put pressure on Albany and the unions to act, so much the better," Ms. Fortuna said. "It's not as if these cuts are unrealistic. The city is going to have to cut another billion dollars if the commuter tax doesn't go through. It's going to have to cut another $600 million if the union savings don't go through."
Mayor Bloomberg says that he is simply doing the sensible thing: coming up with a plan for balancing the budget in case Albany does not come through or the economy takes longer to recover. "To sit here and wait for a problem is not prudent," he said.
And Bloomberg administration officials say that even if the billion-dollar backup plan can be averted, the city is still looking at roughly 5,000 layoffs in its next budget. That kind of budget pain, they say, can hardly be called crying wolf.
But this is not the first time that the mayor has come up with contingency cuts.
Last year at this time, when the city was also seeking help from Albany, Washington and the city's unions to balance its budget, the mayor came up with a $500 million backup plan that called for closing eight fire engine companies, shutting 15 centers for the elderly and eliminating some youth programs. 
Although the mayor did not get all of the outside help he was seeking, and the city's economy continued to worsen, further driving down tax collections, those contingency cuts were never fully made. The mayor found a way to get the federal government to pay for some centers for the elderly. He continues to try to close firehouses, but a year later, the issue is still being discussed by a commission he formed. 
Instead the mayor ordered many other, less onerous cuts, and persuaded the City Council to pass an 18.5 percent property tax increase to keep the budget in balance.
The news that Mayor Bloomberg was drawing up contingency cuts came as some of the city's budget partners were wondering about his game plan. 
Mr. Silver said this week that the mayor should be applying more pressure to get the commuter tax reinstated. "I think he hasn't been as vociferous about that part of his overall financial plan as he has to be," Mr. Silver said. 
When Mr. Bruno was asked if he had been lobbied heavily by Mr. Bloomberg, he said: "No, I've talked with him, you know, regularly. But I wouldn't say that any more than you'd expect."
And a union official who met recently with the mayor said that he had yet to take the unions up on their offer to press the state for him. "We offered to be the orchestra, with him as the conductor," the official said. "He hasn't raised the baton."
Come April 15, city officials say, the mayor hopes to shout out his own message. Whether the state listens this time is another matter.

HEADLINE: Amid Balking in Congress, Bush Will Fight for Smaller Tax Cut 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2 

 BODY:
Administration officials acknowledged today that it would be difficult for President Bush to persuade a skeptical Congress to pass his entire 10-year, $726 billion package of tax cuts, even though they said he would continue to fight for as large a plan as he could.
 "We understand that the president proposes, Congress disposes," said Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, in recognition of the reality that while the House passed the president's version of the tax cut, the Senate voted to reduce it by half, to $350 billion. The Senate vote reflected unease in the president's own party about cutting taxes in the middle of an expensive war. 
 Although Mr. Fleischer insisted that he was not signaling an administration willingness to compromise with Congress on the plan, prominent Republicans on Capitol Hill said they were now assuming that Congress would end up splitting the difference between the House and Senate versions, and that White House officials had told them they were coming to the same conclusion. 
"Publicly, they're going to say $726 billion until the bitter end, as they should," said one Republican member of Congress. "But we can provide a significant economic growth package at a $500 to $550 billion level."
Even at $550 billion, the Republican said, the tax package would be large enough to accommodate, with some delays, all the main provisions sought by the administration, including the elimination of the tax on stock dividends.
An administration official acknowledged the logic of that, even as he said that a $550 billion package was not yet agreed on.
"We've got a dilemma here in that 350 won't pass the House and 726 doesn't have a home in the Senate," the administration official said. "Based on the realities, how do we move forward? I don't think anybody has a solution right now."
Publicly, the administration kept up a determined front today. This afternoon, the president met with 13 Wall Street economists who avidly agree with him on the tax cut. Afterward, some in the group extolled the virtues of the plan to reporters waiting in the West Wing driveway as Treasury Secretary John W. Snow stood by. A number of the comments closely echoed the White House talking points on the plan. 
John Rutledge, the chief investment officer for Rutledge Capital, said that the tax cut was "not a Wall Street event, it's a Main Street event," and that "most of the benefits will be felt in the coffee shops."
Lizann Sonders, the chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab & Company, said the tax cut is "the answer to the economy, is the answer to the stock market and maybe most importantly it's the answer to bringing back trust and fairness and faith in the system."
The group did not include any of Wall Street's most prominent economists, many of whom are lukewarm on the plan. Nor did it include representatives from Wall Street's most prestigious investment firms: Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch, Morgan Stanley and J.P. Morgan Chase.
Edward F. McKelvey, a senior economist at Goldman Sachs, said today that neither he nor anyone else from his firm had been invited.
Mr. McKelvey said he thought Mr. Bush's plan cost too much for the benefits it would provide to the economy. "Will it be stimulative?" Mr. McKelvey said. "Probably. Will it be greatly stimulative? Probably not."
Despite the White House public insistence that the Congress pass the entire $726 billion tax cut, Mr. Fleischer also said today that $3 billion proposed by Congressional committees to help the ailing airline industry was "excessive."

HEADLINE: Sour Mood Pervades the Economic Front 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 2 

 BODY:
While American optimism about the war in Iraq rose sharply today, American spirits about the economy are still being battered.
 Stock markets surged on hopes that American and British forces are closing in on victory in Iraq, but the mood among business executives and consumers is sour. 
 Every survey of manufacturers over the last month has shown a sharp increase in pessimism as executives complain about slumping demand for their own goods and higher prices for the materials they use to make them.
The Commerce Department reported today that factory orders dropped 1.5 percent in February, the steepest drop in five months. On Friday, economists predict, the government will report that unemployment rose again in March. 
Though the increase in joblessness is expected to be modest, the economy has already shed more than 600,000 jobs since November and two million since President Bush took office.
Consumers, whether because of anxiety about the war or because they have been preoccupied with the television coverage, have slowed their spending. Car sales declined last month, airline travel has dropped and retailers have reduced their expectations of growth for the year.
The trend is even worse in Europe and Japan, where growth has almost stalled entirely. As if that was not enough, tourism and travel through Asia are now being hurt by fears of the spread of the disease known as severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS.
In effect, President Bush is being forced to fight wars on two fronts. Anxieties about the war in Iraq have slowed the economy, with businesses still reluctant to invest in new factories or expand their work forces.
But a growing number of analysts are skeptical that the economy will snap back quickly after the shooting subsides. The aftershocks of the stock market bubble still appear to inhibit investor confidence and corporate spending. 
"We have had three consecutive quarters of below-trend growth," said William C. Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman Sachs. "To explain all that on the basis of the war in Iraq seems to be a stretch."
Initial data from retailers indicates that consumers slowed their spending noticeably in the first week of the war. But it remains unclear whether they will rush back into stores when the war dies down.
On Tuesday, Instinet Research's survey of chain stores found that sales dropped by 2.8 percent last week, compared with those in the week a year earlier, and that March sales were off 1.5 percent.
A significant part of that decline stemmed from unusually bad winter weather, as well as the fact that the Easter weekend fell earlier last year.
But consumer surveys suggest that Americans have curbed their urge to shop. The most recent poll by ABC News and Money magazine, released on Tuesday, showed that consumer confidence remained near its lowest point in nine years.
In a poll by The New York Times and CBS News, taken from March 20 to 24, about 49 percent of the respondents said the economy was bad while 50 percent said it was good. 
Those attitudes constituted an improvement over the month before and may have reflected the initial surge of optimism that the United States and Britain would defeat Iraq within days.
In follow-up interviews today, at least some participants had returned to their earlier pessimism.
"I would not make any purchases at this time," said Robert Micheo, a retired probation officer in Los Angeles. "The economy is going down day by day, and it's going to get worse."
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, has continued to express a comparatively sunny view that confidence will revive as soon as the "geopolitical uncertainties" abate.
But Fed officials say the uncertainties about the economy are so numerous that they cannot make any predictions. And the surveys of business sentiment by Fed regional banks have been extremely gloomy.
Earlier this week, the Philadelphia Fed's survey of manufacturers showed deteriorating conditions in several areas. Companies in the region reported that new orders and hiring declined sharply in March and that its broadest measure of manufacturing conditions had plunged.
The survey also relayed widespread complaints that the costs of inputs were rising while the prices for many finished goods declined slightly. The apparent conundrum stems in part from higher energy prices, but it may also reflect the effect of the dollar's decline, which pushes up the cost of imported goods.
The Fed banks in New York and Richmond, Va., reported similarly bleak assessments, while other surveys cast doubt on the chances for a quick rebound in industrial activity after the war. On Tuesday, a closely watched index of manufacturing activity by the Institute of Supply Management showed a much steeper drop than analysts had expected and reached its lowest level since November 2001. For the first time in five months, the index suggested that factories were contracting rather than expanding.
It remains unclear how much of this sluggishness stems from anxieties during the run-up to war. Analysts note that the economy has been hit by bad weather, the ripple effects of corporate governance scandals and the continued skittishness of investors who want to see stability rather than gangbuster growth.
Robert Mellman, senior economist at J. P. Morgan Chase Bank, said the war had almost certainly damped consumer spending at a time when consumer spending has been the only source of economic growth in this country.
"Consumer spending really has slowed down," Mr. Mellman said. "Part of it is because they're just staying at home and watching TV, but partly they are concerned."
Despite the economic woes right now, Mr. Mellman said he remained optimistic that the economy would speed up after the Iraq war. But that acceleration will probably not show up until at least midyear, he said, and unemployment is not likely to decline significantly before the end of this year.
Michael Prell, an economic consultant and former director of research at the Federal Reserve Board, said he was more skeptical. Even if the United States wins a quick victory in Iraq, he said, President Bush's strategy of pre-emptive action could create new tensions and political anxiety for multinational corporations and international investors.
"Even if the geopolitical outlook brightens, it could still take some time for the corporate sector to get up the nerve to increase investment and hiring," Mr. Prell told a conference in Washington last week.

HEADLINE: HOCKEY; 
This Fan's Fantasy Was Examining the Fine Print

BYLINE:  By RICHARD SANDOMIR with STU HACKEL 

 BODY:
When a Los Angeles Kings fan named Philip Propper read earlier this season that the Kings had lost $103 million since 1996, he thought the team had to be fiddling with its finances.
 "How could things be so bad?" wondered Propper, a portfolio manager and equity analyst with the Trust Company of the West, whose offices in Los Angeles are two blocks from Staples Center, the home of the Kings. 
 Propper thought it would have been easy for the Kings' owner, the Anschutz Entertainment Group, to manipulate profits into paper losses, then cry bad hockey economics, he said yesterday. "How could a team getting this many fans not be making money?" he said. 
Any fan, even one like Propper who is as savvy about profits and losses as he is about goals and assists, would feel whipsawed by wildly different financial figures. For example, Forbes reported that the Kings made $7 million in operating profits last season. To refute the report, the team let The Los Angeles Times look at its financial records late last year; a loss of $103 million, projected through the end of this season, was found in a seven-year period.
On a whim, Propper wrote a letter in February to Tim Leiweke, the Kings' president, volunteering to examine the team's financial statements.
"Mr. Leiweke, I am quite skeptical regarding this claim," Propper wrote, referring to the huge losses.
Rather than taking the conventional view -- that letting an outsider, a fan no less, audit the financial guts of a privately held corporation was a form of insanity -- the Kings embraced the idea, certain that even a skeptic like Propper would see what they saw: big losses. 
The team would not have opened its books to any old Kings fan with a jersey and a cap and a beer-cup holder, but they were comfortable with Propper's financial background. Leiweke told Dan Beckerman, the team's chief financial officer, to cooperate with Propper. 
"We wanted to set the record straight," Beckerman said. "We're not happy about losing all this money, and we're not bragging about it. But the flip side is we're also not complaining about it."
And so, Propper spent 10 hours over three days in February at Staples Center. "I went in with the bias that they were lying," Propper said.
Propper analyzed seven years of financial records, along with invoices that backed some expenses, and he peppered Beckerman with questions.
"Quite frankly, it was more thorough than most of the other audits we go through," Beckerman said. 
Propper emerged with surprising conclusions: that things were aslousy as the Kings said they were, that the team was not hiding money or shuffling it around the A.E.G. empire.
In a 21-page report he posted last night on a fan Web site, letsgokings.com, Propper estimated that the team's overall losses would be even higher than The Times's estimate. He said the team would post a cash loss of $12.5 million this season, bringing Anschutz's losses since acquiring the team to an unenviable $108 million. The biggest loss, $31.7 million, occurred in the 1998-99 season, he said.
Might fans eager to see him prove that the Kings were misers feel that Propper, their surrogate analyst, had betrayed them?
"At the end of the day, most intelligent people want to know the truth," he said. "They want to understand the numbers. But there are some who have emotional preconceptions that you can't change."
Propper, 42, grew up a Rangers fan on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, but after moving to Los Angeles in 1989, he slowly turned his allegiance to the Kings. His hockey-loving daughters turned him into a rabid fan, and now he splits a pair of season tickets in the back row of Section 119 at Staples Center.
"It's right on the blue line, where the Kings attack twice a game," he said.
A central conclusion of Propper's detailed financial analysis is that the rate of growth of the the Kings' payroll outstripped the team's increasing revenue. Over the past seven years, player costs grew 19 percent annually, while revenues increased 15 percent a year.
He estimates that if salaries had grown only 10 percent annually in the years since A.E.G. acquired the Kings, the Kings would have generated a $7 million cash profit last season.
"Why did Anschutz buy this team?" Propper said he had asked himself. "They figured that they'd build Staples, and knew what revenues would look like and thought salary growth would be about 8 to 10 percent. But salaries grew too fast. They may not have bought the team had they known this."
He said the Kings had not spent enough in marketing to fill the new arena with more than an average of about 15,000 paid customers each game.
Winning a Stanley Cup, of course, has also eluded the Kings.
Propper's sharpest criticism is reserved for the National Hockey League. He said that under Commissioner Gary Bettman, the league had needlessly overexpanded to 30 teams, forcing salaries higher and creating a wide revenue gap between the most affluent and poorest teams. His proposed solutions include eliminating four to six teams through contraction and consolidation.
A league spokeswoman, Bernadette Mansur, said of Propper's proposals: "A fan's look at the economics of one team provides a totally insufficient basis upon which to draw leaguewide conclusions. It appears the conclusions he drew were completely unrelated to the material he reviewed."
Although Beckerman would not comment on Propper's critique of the league, he agreed with one of Propper's fundamental points. "The current economic system," he said, "does not work for the Los Angeles Kings."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
Amnesia Closes One Door But Then Another Opens

 BODY:
"The Man Without a Past" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 2; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film, in Finnish with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan.
 Amnesia, at least of the kind that tends to afflict characters in movies and books, is both a terrifying condition and, at the same time, an appealing one. The title character in Aki Kaurismaki's lovely new comic fable, "The Man Without a Past," certainly does his share of suffering. A metal worker who arrives in a strange city by train, he is brutally mugged on a park bench and left for dead. His face shrouded in bandages, he stumbles out of the hospital and collapses on a riverbank. When he comes to, he has lost, in addition to his money and his shoes, his ability to recall anything about his previous life, including his name. (The final credits identify him simply as "M.") 
 But though he is estranged from himself and set adrift in an urban Finnish landscape that is shadowed by poverty and bureaucratic indifference, the man (played with soulful deadpan by Markku Peltola) is also liberated.
His hands are callused from work, and his handsome, double-thick pork-chop face has clearly weathered hardship and disappointment, but the new life he finds on the margins of society is touched by a peculiar kind of grace. He gains friendship among the homeless and destitute, a home in an abandoned shipping container, and love with a melancholy Salvation Army worker, Irma (Kati Outinen), who ladles out free soup by day and lies awake in her dormitory at night, listening to rock 'n' roll with intent, almost religious devotion.
Mr. Kaurismaki's previous film, "Juha," was black-and-white and silent. This one is full of bright color (including the glorious wind-scrubbed blue of the Nordic sky), exquisitely strange dialogue and music. As if struggling against an innate reticence, the people in "The Man Without a Past" speak slowly and formally, and the antic poetry they utter sneaks up on you after a beat.
The characters, in spite of their air of forlorn impassivity, reveal their quirks, their passions and the oddball dignity that unites them, with similar deliberateness. In addition to Irma, the man's new companions include an amiable drinker (Juhani Niemela) and his family, and Antilla (Sakari Kuosmanen), a security guard who is landlord of the shipping-container shantytown and who fancies himself a ruthless and fearsome enforcer of law and order.
The director is clearly a man very much enamored with the past: with old music and even older movies. The man, whose taste for what he calls "rhythm music" (meaning rockabilly, blues and vintage R&B) has survived his injury, transforms the Salvation Army band into a swinging combo, with the thrift-shop manager (Annikki Tahti) stepping in to sing lead when a woman's voice is required. The jukebox he salvages from a junk pile fortuitously reflects his preferences: the first selection it plays is "That Crawlin' Baby Blues" by Blind Lemon Jefferson.
Mr. Kaurismaki's cinematic reference points are similarly antiquarian, which is not to say that they are dated, or that his use of them is based on nostalgia or allusion for its own sake. "The Man Without a Past" has a sly, controlled silliness that recalls Preston Sturges, and a vision of resilience and nobility in hard times that suggests Charlie Chaplin without the sleeve-tugging sentimentality, or Frank Capra without the weakness for speechifying.
And like the great films of the 1930's and early 40's, it is at once artful and unpretentious, sophisticated and completely accessible, sure of its own authority and generous toward characters and audience alike -- a movie whose intended public is the human race. 
In a director's statement distributed with the publicity materials for "The Man Without a Past," Mr. Kaurismaki, with characteristically impish forthrightness, writes that "my social, economical and political views of the state of society, morals and love can hopefully be found from the film itself."
On the evidence of this hilarious and humane movie, these views are, like those of any great artist, at once perfectly clear and not easily summarized. His ethical ideals are perhaps most succinctly expressed in an exchange between the hero and a worker from the municipal utility company who runs a cable from a nearby power line to the man's makeshift home (and later helps repair the jukebox).
The electrician brusquely refuses payment, asking only the promise of future consideration in exchange for his favor: "If you see me lying face down in the gutter," he says, "turn me on my back."

HEADLINE: HAVENS; 
Drawn by Siren Call of Antiquing

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
MY husband and I sat down on an old Napoleon III settee and took in the view. Around the room were all the makings of a 19th-century salon on the Left Bank -- French chests and armoires, a large red velvet divan -- and two well-dressed men occasionally glancing our way, assessing our worthiness to be there.
 The men were the owners of this shop, Alain Pioton Antiques in Hudson, N.Y., and we were tired shoppers seeking refuge on their tiny sofa. They have watched an endless stream of shoppers -- and shops -- pass through town in the 18 years since they opened there. 
 "In and out, in and out, they go," Byrne Fone, an owner of the shop, said. "Lots of people think it would be great fun to buy and sell junk." 
And an increasing number of them seem to be doing it. Hudson is now home to more than 50 antiques shops and has gained a reputation for being the antique maven's equivalent of nirvana. 
For my husband and me, antiquing was never an activity that sprang to mind, other than in jest. But an unfurnished apartment after a long renovation and an eternally bleak winter can lead people to desperate acts. We had done some shopping in New York City, where we live, and a trip to Denton & Gardner in SoHo sent us over the edge. We loved everything in the store, and could not afford any of it. A small end table for $2,500 drove us straight out of the place. A friend urged us to take a weekend trip upstate, where prices and pressures were lower.
Shortly after, we found ourselves in a rental car barreling up the Taconic State Parkway toward Hudson, a city of 8,000 that lies in a tight cluster on the eastern side of the Hudson River. The town was founded by whalers from Nantucket, but when the whaling industry declined, so did Hudson. Then, like many towns in the Northeast, it had brief industrial successes interspersed with stretches of depression. In the 1990's, antiques dealers began appearing, and they found (and were found by) weekenders who, with the economic boom, had money to burn. 
The antiques shops are mostly on Warren Street, a milelong strip that begins at the river and rises up the riverbank, cutting through the center of town. It was 11 in the morning when we parked our car on the east end and plotted our attack. We would go all the way down one side of the street and up the other, dismissing any stores that did not immediately interest us. When we arrived at the first store and pushed on the door, it did not budge. The shop was dark inside, despite the hours stated on the door. So was the next one. We looked up and down the street. There were cars whizzing by, but no people, other than a man far down the street, sweeping the sidewalk. Soon we were zigzagging our way down the street, trying to find a store that was open. 
Could it be a holiday? Or were all the dealers away at an antiques conference?
"No," one shopkeeper told us. "It's just like thatin Hudson. They come when they like."
One store's hours were listed as "Fri-Sun 11-5 or by chance."
And the dealers are laid back when they are there. One shopkeeper stayed out of view in a back room while we walked around the store. Somehow, from where our footsteps halted, he sensed that we were looking at a pile of old mug shots. "You like the convicts, eh?" he called to us from his desk. (They were $40 each after haggling.) Few dealers give the hard sell. Generally, they respond to a shopper's presence more like a sleeping cat hearing a familiar noise. They shift position in their chair, nod vaguely or sigh. 
The dealers seem to fall into three categories, those who specialize in a particular period or country of origin, those who have eclectic tastes and may show Windsor chairs with a shag rug, and those whose stores are more like junk shops, piled high with things like Bakelite-handle knives, dolls and old milk bottles.
The period shops are like time capsules. As we strolled through a store called 20th Century Gallery, it felt as if we were walking through the set of "North by Northwest." There were sofas with low squared arms, tall brass lamps, chrome tables and plenty of blue and olive. 
Warren Street is wide, offering an expansive sense of the air and sky. For city dwellers, it felt like an escape to the country, with all the rejuvenating qualities we desired. Antiquing is a workout for the legs and the mind, too. It stirs up memories, gives ideas and calls into question design choices from the past. My husband, whose normal tolerance for shopping is about 10 minutes, was leading the way down the street, keeping a mental list of everything that interested us.
"I've noticed a pattern in these stores," he commented over lunch at Earth Foods, a bustling natural foods diner that smelled deliciously of sauteed onions. "The smaller and more unpleasant-looking the dog, the smaller and more expensive the antiques." 
In many stores we had to step over a dog to make our way inside. The dogs had learned long ago that it wasn't worth moving for every customer.
We saw just one cat in town. Its name was Blackie, and it reigned lazily over an odd and engaging shop called Keystone at the top of Warren Street. Blackie lay on a counter near a collection of male mannequins. Beyond them was a vast array of porcelain sinks ($150 to $1,200), old solid-oak doors, iron heating grates, worn butcher blocks ($225 to $350) and even a lamppost or two, should one be needed. 
Perhaps the most likable aspect of Hudson, other than Blackie, is its clash of cultures. Wedged between antiques shops at the top of Warren is Samuel Sutty & Son, a place that time forgot. Inside are a roasted-peanut cart and an old brass scale for weighing candy. The store is operating, we were told, but not when we were there on a Saturday afternoon. Down the street is an orthopedic shop with a window display that appears not to have been changed in 50 years. And sprinkled around the center of town are at least three old firehouses, or "hose companies" as their signs say, each boasting its company name.
Gallery East, a tiny store with walls painted celadon green and a brilliant selection of Asian antiques, is one of the newer arrivals in Hudson, having opened in May. The owner, Michael Corsentino, regularly travels to Asia on buying trips and keeps in his store a tailored collection, from a standing 16th-century Buddha for $11,000 to antique Thai silk bed quilts, which range from $125 to $250. It was here that we made our first big purchase, a Burmese prayer box with clawfeet and a slot on top for dropping in prayers. 
Our last stop was Kitchen. It was open, not surprisingly, way past its stated hours. As in most of the places we visited, we were the only shoppers, marveling at an old butcher table so worn that its surface was like a roll of waves ($850), white ironstone platters veined from age ($50 to $90) and a cabinet with sections marked "grocery clean," "grocery soiled," "meat clean" and "meat soiled" ($825). 
The next day, we decided to hit two smaller burgeoning antiques towns nearby. Millbrook, whose main street is more of a dash on a map, has a few shops that are worth a detour. Red School House specializes in early American furniture and art, and Red Coral, down the street, sells a selection of antique pieces reupholstered with high-energy modern prints. (The town is also home to the Tinhorn, a small low-key restaurant with a fireplace and a good chef who prepares dishes -- like Caesar salad, baby chicken over polenta and apple cobbler -- with restraint.) 
The antiques highlight was yet to come. On the way out of Millbrook, we stopped at Yellow Church Antiques. In the cavernous shop is a collection of magnificent antiques. It is difficult not to gasp like a yokel, as my husband did, at the prices -- a George II walnut bureau bookcase for $185,000 -- but then it's a treat to see such rarefied furniture. 
On our way back to Manhattan, we stopped in Cold Spring, where one store specializes in old clocks and another in vintage toys. And there is quite a good restaurant called Le Bouchon, with red lacquered walls and a marble hearth. Tired from shopping and all the fresh air, we ate quietly, nibbling a croque-monsieur and pork rillettes on toasts with a glass of Cotes du Rhone.
We were back by late afternoon. We had bought that French settee from Alain Pioton Antiques at what we considered a bargain price, and during the week that followed we decided to buy a Syrian mirror that we had seen, as well. There was no hurry. It is not like shopping at a store in Manhattan where if a shopper pauses to consider the purchase, the piece is gone.
We negotiated with a trucking company and had the settee and the mirror shipped to us. The settee looked better and worse than we had remembered. The shape worked perfectly in our den. But en route its base had cracked. So I guess we won't sit on it.

SHOPPING ON WARREN STREET
Start at the 20th Century and Go Back

HEADLINE: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

CLAUDIA ACUNA QUINTET, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, (212) 576-2232. Ms. Acuna, a young jazz singer from Chile, is committed to the idea of a jazz singer as an inseparable part of the band -- or better, as a bandleader. She is working with a great crop of New York musicians, including Jason Lindner, Omer Avital and Avi Lebovitch, and they play around with mambos, Middle Eastern scales and improvising that goes far beyond mere accompaniment. Tonight through Sunday night at 7:30 and 9:30; cover charge is $20, $15 on Sunday (Ben Ratliff).

ALBITA, Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, West Village, (212) 475-8592. Albita Rodriguez, a Cuban singer now living in the United States, brings a rocker's stage presence and a deep, gritty voice to old-fashioned songs filled with an expatriate's nostalgia and a lover's passions. Tonight through Sunday night at 8 and 10:30; $35 cover and $5 minimum at tables, or $20 admission at the bar (Jon Pareles).

* STEVEN BERNSTEIN'S DIASPORA SOUL, Leonard Nimoy Thalia Theater, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400. Best known for leading the raucous jazz-funk party band Sex Mob, Mr. Bernstein, the trumpeter, has done a little intuitive musicology and a little searching of his own roots to draw a connection among the cha-cha, Southern soul music of the 60's and the harmonic movement of the Jewish hora. The surprise is that the results don't sound too mixed up; the album "Diaspora Soul" (Tzadik) is full of stately moments. Tonight at 8:30; tickets are $21, $16 for members, $18 for students and 65+ (Ratliff).

* COMMON, GANG STARR, TALIB KWELI, FLOETRY, Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. Common's most recent album, "Electric Circus" (MCA), was hit and miss; it's now clear that he should leave the singing to the singers. But live, he remains one of hip-hop's most exciting performers, leading his band through long, loping phrases while hardly pausing for breath. He is to be joined by the traditionalist duo Gang Starr, the long-winded Talib Kweli and the sing-rapping act Floetry; it should be a great show. Sunday at 6:45; tickets are $31 (Kelefa Sanneh).

CORY BRANAN, Mercury Lounge, 217 East Houston Street, at Ludlow Street, Lower East Side, (212) 260-4700. Cory Branan, from Memphis, has women on his mind throughout his album, "The Hell You Say" (Madjack). His songs recall his crushes backed by raw-boned country rock or stripped-down acoustic guitar, with a blunt economy that hints at both Steve Earle and Loudon Wainwright III. Sunday night at 7, with Bottle of Justus, Freeloader and the Honorary Title opening; admission is $8 (Pareles).

GEORGE COLEMAN QUARTET, Smoke, 2751 Broadway, at 106th Street, (212) 864-6662. Mr. Coleman, the tenor saxophonist probably best known for the great couple of years he spent with Miles Davis's early-60's quintet, often plays around town with the pianist Harold Mabern. These two men, adept at the postbop rhythmic and harmonic vocabulary, are from Memphis and have a lot of history between them, and it shows. Mr. Mabern is on hand in this group, along with the bassist John Webber and the drummer Joe Farnsworth. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9, 11 and 12:30; cover charge is $20 (Ratliff).

DEICIDE, L'Amour, 1545 63rd Street, near 15th Avenue, Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, (718) 837-9506. The Florida band Deicide, for all its militancy -- lyrics vilifying Christianity, studded breastplates, beefy arms -- makes unremarkable meat-and-potatoes death metal: buzz-saw guitar themes in minor modes gave way to fast, narrow two-beat drum thrashing. Glen Benton, leader and demagogue, uses the genre's generic low growl; it's business as usual, no big deal. (He also prefers to present himself as being against organized religion rather than, uh, pro-Satan.) But here at L'Amour, the New York area's main metal club, the band stands a better chance of creating an interesting scene. Tomorrow night at 8; tickets are $18 (Ratliff).

DJ LE SPAM AND THE SPAM ALLSTARS, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940. This party imported from Miami puts a disc jockey together with live musicians, mixing Latin rhythms with electronic beats. Tonight at midnight, with music till dawn; admission is $12 (Pareles).

DORGON AND JAMIE SAFT, Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-8242. Dorgon plays the C-melody saxophone, and he's a bit of a practical joker; one of his recent albums gave no information other than to say that it was recorded in 1949 aboard a ship called the Bhutan, with the Lennie Tristano Big Band. (How far can you trust a guy named Dorgon?) But he makes modest, likable free jazz with different partners; tonight it's with the keyboardist Jamie Saft, who loves to add sound-warping effects to his Fender Rhodes. Tonight at 8:30; admission is $10 (Ratliff).

* GREEK MUSIC FESTIVAL, Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street, (212) 864-5400; Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 840-2824 or (212) 545-7536. The World Music Institute's fourth annual Greek festival reaches deep into Mediterranean traditions. The first night presents something rarely seen in New York: the Greek shadow-puppet theater called Karaghiozis, performing a tale of warfare and heroism that could have unexpected contemporary resonance. Athos Danielis leads a troupe that includes puppeteers and a full live orchestra with Greek instruments. Tonight at 8 at Symphony Space; tickets are $26, $21 for World Music Institute members. "Emigration Blues" presents a program that ranges across a century of urban songs, from the street-life tales of rembetika to laiko folk songs, performed by Petros Gaitanos, Sofia Papazaoglou and an eight-piece band. At Town Hall tomorrow at 8; tickets are $25 to $40. The festival concludes Sunday with music and dance from Asia Minor, where Greek and Turkish, European and Asian elements intertwine, performed by the Gledistades Ensemble from Lesbos and by a quintet of musicians with roots in Smyrna. At Symphony Space on Sunday night at 7; tickets are $26, $21 for World Music Institute members (Pareles).

VIVIAN GREEN, S.O.B.'s, 204 Varick Street, at Houston Street, South Village, (212) 243-4940. With songs like diary entries, Vivian Green surveys the emotional roller coaster of love. She's a neo-soul songwriter who's fond of slinky 1970's funk, and her tautly focused singing can hint at the specifics that her psychobabble lyrics often lack. Tonight at 8; admission is $15 (Pareles).

* FRED HERSCH AND NORMA WINSTONE, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8770. Mr. Hersch, the pianist, who has a rare command of the piano as a solo instrument or when backing up a singer, will appear with the vocalist Norma Winstone, playing music from a lovely, contemplative new record they've made, "Songs and Lullabies" (Palmetto). Sunday night at 7:30; cover charge is $15 (Ratliff).

FRANK LACY QUINTET, Jazz Gallery, 290 Hudson Street, below Spring Street, South Village, (212) 242-1063. Mr. Lacy is one of the most charismatic trombone players in jazz -- a pretty charismatic bunch to begin with -- and his music is raucous and funereal, frightful and happy and mournful, from bebop to rhythm-and-blues to free improvisation. For a long while in the 90's, he was a member of Roy Hargrove's sextet, and he was part of the incredible band that backed the rhythm-and-blues singer D'Angelo, playing honest-to-God jazz solos for crowds of thousands. Tomorrow night at 9 and 10:30; admission is $12 (Ratliff).

* LOSER'S LOUNGE TRIBUTE TO THE MAMAS AND THE PAPAS, Fez, 380 Lafayette Street, at Great Jones Street, East Village, (212) 533-2680. The pop archivists of the Loser's Lounge revisit the mid-1960's hits of the Mamas and the Papas, the transplanted Greenwich Village folkies whose chiming harmonies helped define California pop. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; admission is $20 (Pareles).

THE LOST CHAMBERS OF THE FIFTH ELEMENT, CB's 313 Gallery, 313 Bowery, at Bleecker Street, East Village, (212) 677-0455. Onomatopoeia turns into hip-hop rhythm when the microphone is in the hands of beatboxers like Doug E. Fresh. He is presenting dozens of human beatboxers at this show. Tonight at 6:30; admission is $8 (Pareles).

HUGH MASEKELA, Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. The South African fluegelhornist Hugh Masekela has more to offer than his international hit "Grazing in the Grass." For decades, he has brought together the three-chord lope of South African pop with the zigzagging possibilities of jazz. He's leading a band featuring South African musicians who performed in the documentary "Amandla!" and the La Guardia High School Symphonic Choir. Tonight at 8; tickets are $23 to $74 (Pareles).

* THE NOTWIST, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Introspection meets programming in the songs of the Notwist, a band from Bavaria. Markus Archer sings gently about his doubts and estrangement over backdrops that might mix a lone banjo or piano with computerized ticking and pulsations. The easy comparison is Belle and Sebastian meets Stereolab, but the songs reveal their own brittleness and depth. Tonight at 10, with James Yorkston and Styrofoam opening; tomorrow night at 10 with Styrofoam and the Burnside Project opening. Tickets are $12 in advance, $15 the day of the show (Pareles).

OF MONTREAL, Europa Night Club, 98-104 Meserole Avenue, at Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 383-5723. Of Montreal, part of the Elephant Six collective of neopsychedelic bands in Athens, Ga., plays giddy, optimistic, harmonically rambling songs by Kevin Barnes, who is clearly a Beach Boys and Beatles fan. It shares the bill with Cory McAbee and Marshmallow Coast. Sunday at 9; tickets are $10 (Pareles).

WILLIAM PARKER'S LITTLE HUEY ORCHESTRA, the Center at Old St. Patrick's Cathedral, 268 Mulberry Street, Little Italy. There have been as many as 27 members in this big band, playing in the language of free jazz even if they're actually playing compositions, and it's full of sustained ferment; the sound of the music has connections to Charles Mingus's most pugnacious work of the 1950's, with musicians piling into the fray one by one and fighting for space. Also on the bill both nights are a duet of Hyoshiko Chuma and Frank London, and Patricia Nicholson's PaNic. Tonight and tomorrow night at 8; admission is $20 (Ratliff).

* HOUSTON PERSON QUARTET, Rose Center for Earth and Space, American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, (212) 769-5100. Mr. Person, a veteran tenor saxophonist, keeps things pleasurable. His background is in the 1950's, when a good deal of jazz was completely submerged in rhythm and blues, and he's one of the few mainstream jazz performers today who can routinely find access to the deep language of pleasure from that time. (Most of the others became session musicians, went deeper into the studiousness of jazz or into the meat and potatoes of rock 'n' roll or disappeared.) Mr. Person has an elastic, sequential solo-building style that links him to Sonny Rollins, and occasionally a fat, breathy tone that links him to Ben Webster. Enjoy him. Sets are tonight at 5:30 and 7. Suggested admission: $12; $9 students and 60+; $7 ages 2 to 12. (Ratliff).

PROJECT OBJECT, B. B. King Blues Club and Grill, 243 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212) 997-4144. Frank Zappa's music was never easy to play. It called for players who loved both basic three-chord rock and all the whizzing, swerving, whimsical complexities that Zappa could devise. Musicians are still willing to devote themselves to its wayward intricacies, and Project Object has been working its way through the Zappa repertory for years; it has material from a new CD. Tomorrow night at 8, with Homunculus opening; admission is $20 (Pareles).

* WILLIS ALAN RAMSEY, MALCOLM HOLCOLMBE, Village Underground, 130 West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 777-7745. Willis Alan Ramsey made his self-titled, one and only album in 1972, but his bluesy voice and jovial eye influenced countless sly, down-home songwriters, notably Lyle Lovett, who went on to collaborate with him on songs like "That's Right (You're Not From Texas)." A song he tossed off, "Muskrat Love," became a hit for the Captain and Tenille and left him financially secure. Asked if he would make a follow-up album, Mr. Ramsey reportedly replied, "What was wrong with the first one?" Still, hopes remain. But since the album's rerelease in 1999 (on Koch), he has been giving rare performances outside Texas. Sharing the bill is Malcolm Holcombe, whose grizzled, slurred voice sounds completely convincing in folky songs about endless, uncertain wanderings. Sunday night at 6; admission is $10 (Pareles).

* RUSTED ROOT, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. The neo-hippie spirit lives on in Rusted Root, a jam band with the supposedly tribal sound of a drum circle at its core. Tonight at 9; tickets are $24 (Pareles).

SCENE CREAMERS, MIIGHTY FLASHLIGHT, Europa, 98-104 Meserole Avenue, at Manhattan Avenue, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 383-5723. Scene Creamers is the new band from Ian Svenonius and Michelle Mae, who made a joyless noise together in the faux-gospel group the Make-Up. The debut Scene Creamers album is "I Suck on That Emotion" (Drag City), a batch of cagey, stylized songs that draw from a wide range of late-60's rock. Miighty Flashlight is a mysterious (and often compelling) folk-rock solo project from Mike Fellows, formerly of the pioneering emo band Rites of Spring. Tonight at 9, with the Holy Ghost; admission is $8 (Sanneh).

SUSAN TEDESCHI, Irving Plaza, 17 Irving Place, at 15th Street, Manhattan, (212) 777-6800. The singer and guitarist Susan Tedeschi stirs together blues, soul and funk, singing about love troubles in a clear, forthright voice and leading a first-rate band that can carry the songs into jam-band territory. Tomorrow night at 8, with Paul Rishell and Annie Rains opening; tickets are $22.50 in advance, $25 tomorrow (Pareles).

* 2 MANY DJ'S, FC/KAHUNA, Pianos, 158 Ludlow Street, near Stanton Street, Lower East Side, (212) 505-3733. The Belgian duo 2 Many DJ's never disappoints: its approach -- juxtaposing and remixing familiar songs in unexpected ways -- may be obvious, but it's also just about foolproof. FC/Kahuna, a British duo, recently released a CD called "Machine Says Yes" (Nettwerk), a seductive album that moves from grimy electro to glamorous disco. This should be a euphoric night of dance music, provided you can get in, so arrive early and be prepared to stay late. Tomorrow night at 10, with Errol Alkan and many other DJ's; admission is $10 (Sanneh).

WADADA LEO SMITH, Tonic, 107 Norfolk Street, near Delancey Street, Lower East Side, (212) 358-7501. An icon of 1970's jazz vanguardism and one of jazz's great mystics, Mr. Smith is originally a trumpeter, but in performance he can be a poet or a flute player or whatever he wants to be that day. Tonight he performs with Ikue Mori, on electronic percussion; tomorrow with the saxophonist Anthony Braxton, another great cult figure of the same vintage. Both nights at 8 and 10; admission is $15 tonight and $25 tomorrow (Ratliff).

JAMES SPAULDING AND SOUND SPECTRUM, Up Over Jazz Cafe, 351 Flatbush Avenue, at Seventh Avenue, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 398-5413. The saxophonist and flutist James Spaulding has often worked as an unheralded sideman: in the World Saxophone Quartet and in bands led by David Murray, Max Roach, Horace Silver, Wayne Shorter and on back to a Sun Ra band in the late 1950's. Tonight and tomorrow night at 9, 11 and 12:30; cover charge is $20 (Ratliff).

TRIBUTE TO LIONEL HAMPTON, Iridium, 1650 Broadway, at 51st Street, (212) 582-2121. The vibraphonist Terry Gibbs leads the tribute, with David Newman, Joey DeFrancesco and Howard Alden as guests; the Eugene Maslov Trio will also appear. Tonight and tomorrow at 7:40 and 10:30, Sunday night at 7:40 and 10; cover charge is $25 tonight and Sunday, $27.50 tomorrow (Ratliff).

* THE WAIFS, Joe's Pub, 425 Lafayette Street, at Astor Place, East Village, (212) 539-8778 or (212) 239-6200. The Waifs are a young, frisky Australian band in love with older American music like folk-rock and the blues, fronted by two women who sing about trains and city life and huff up a storm on harmonica. Tonight at 7 and 9:30; admission is $15 (Pareles).

* JAMES YORKSTON, the Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street, TriBeCa, (212) 219-3006. Mr. Yorkston, from Scotland, writes ballads that are both gentle and pointed. On "Moving Up Country" (Domino), his excellent debut album, he sings about anticipation, disappointment and -- not coincidentally -- drunkenness, accompanied by the occasional lap steel or accordion. Tomorrow night at 8 and 11; admission is $10 (Sanneh).
