HEADLINE: SOCCER; 
Women's Season a Lead-In to World Cup

BYLINE:  By JACK BELL 

 BODY:
The Women's United Soccer Association was created from the astonishing success of the 1999 Women's World Cup, which was played in and won by the United States. In the euphoric aftermath a handful of media conglomerates recognized the potential of an eye-popping demographic and launched the eight-team league. 
 Now the W.U.S.A. has come full circle. Its third season leads into the 2003 World Cup. 
 "This year is going to be different than any other, having a professional league prior to the World Cup," said Mia Hamm, the most recognizable star of the women's game and FIFA's 2002 female player of the year. "But these challenges are exciting ones. Not only the U.S., but teams across the world are stronger because of their participation in the W.U.S.A." 
For example, last season France sent little-known Marinette Pichon to Philadelphia, where she finished as the league's second-leading scorer, with 14 goals. She later helped France qualify for the World Cup, which is being played in China starting Sept. 23. Norway and Germany each have five potential national team players in the W.U.S.A.; Australia and Brazil each have four; and Canada has three. 
Perhaps the pivotal difference this year, particularly for the United States team, is the absence of the full-time residency program that was in use before the previous three Women's World Cups. In the past, national team players gathered at the IMG Academy in Bradenton, Fla., for intensive training periods of a month or more. This year, the Americans have no such luxury. Instead, they will be limited to playing one exhibition match each month of the W.U.S.A. season. 
The Chinese, who are playing host to the World Cup, have recalled players like Sun Wen for their own residency camp. Last year the league had nine Chinese players; this season there are only three: Bai Jie and Gao Hong in Washington, and Zhang Ouying in San Diego. 
"Residency was nice in that you got to play with teammates every day, but it wasn't really realistic because in the long term you're not developing players," said Julie Foudy, the San Diego midfielder and national team veteran. "Where once the pool of players was 25, now the pool is 125 who are training and playing at the highest level. There's more depth, and it's not a coincidence -- it's a product of the league." 
Tom Sermanni, the New York Power's new coach, directed the Australian national team in the 1990's and had to cobble together a team with minimal preparation. 
"I took over the Australian team for the 1995 World Cup and we barely had a game in two years," Sermanni said. "But really, the issues were different then. I think this league gives an enormous benefit to the U.S. national team, because players are playing against high-level competition every week and they are training full time with the best players in the world. My only concern is the large number of games at a high level we are asking them to play in." 
The Power has five players whose time with the club could be affected as their nations begin to prepare for the tournament: Tiffeny Milbrett and Christie Pearce of the United States, Cheryl Salisbury and Joanne Peters of Australia, and Anita Rapp of Norway. Leaguewide, nearly 50 players could be on their nations' rosters in China. 
"The World Cup will have an effect on the league, but it does not have to be detrimental," said April Heinrichs, coach of the United States national team. "In a way, the W.U.S.A. has helped American players gain more respect for other players like Birgit Prinz and Sun Wen. The women will get more attention in a World Cup year, and the public support in America, China and elsewhere will bind us all together in an even grander form to help promote the women's game around the world." 
Although Heinrichs probably has more than 90 percent of her roster set, that does not preclude the emergence of players like Boston midfielder Angela Hucles, who had played for Heinrichs at the University of Virginia but was selling plumbing fixtures when she was drafted in the 12th round, and San Jose goalkeeper LaKeysia Beene. 
"When you have a team in residency it's hard for a player to break in who might be playing well," said Tony DiCiccio, the W.U.S.A. commissioner and Heinrichs's predecessor as national team coach. "Players are getting the opportunity to play in this league, and you want them playing on the cutting edge." 
Off the field, some difficult economic realities led to months of negotiations between the players and the W.U.S.A., a single-entity operation in which the league owns all player contracts. 
The women from the '99 United States World Cup team, also known as the founding players, are entering the third year of five-year guaranteed deals and have agreed to take a 25 percent pay cut, to $60,000 from $80,000 to $85,000. In addition, the average salary this season will be about $37,000, nearly a 20 percent decline from 2002. Roster size was trimmed from 20 to 16, with two reserve players and two developmental players. 
"We had to take a good hard look, and if you look at the economic environment that is going on right now, it is something that had to be addressed," Hamm said. "For us to think that this doesn't affect us would have been naive." 
The league's TV landscape has also changed a bit from last year, when the relatively obscure cable network PAX TV broadcast W.U.S.A. games in direct competition with Major League Soccer matches at 4 p.m. Eastern on Saturdays. This year, ESPN2 will televise four games: tomorrow's match between Washington and Carolina, the All-Star Game (United States vs. the World) on June 17 in Cary, N.C., a playoff game on Aug. 17 and the championship game (Founders Cup III) on Aug. 24 in San Diego.

HEADLINE: DRUGS; 
Anti-Doping Executive Plans to Prod Pro Leagues

BYLINE:  By BILL PENNINGTON 

 BODY:
The man who helped devise a new uniform standard for banned substances and drug testing in all Olympic sports says he plans to ask North America's four major professional sports leagues why they have not signed on to the new regulations.
 Dick Pound, the chief executive of the World Anti-Doping Agency, the organization that devised the comprehensive code, said he intended to contact the commissioners of Major League Baseball, the National Football League, the National Basketball Association and the National Hockey League to ask them to adopt the new guidelines and penalties, which include a fixed, two-year suspension for steroid use. 
 More than 1,000 Olympic, political and sports leaders representing nearly 200 countries convened in Copenhagen early last month to adopt the new world doping code, a 53-page pact detailing banned substances, strict penalties and uniform drug testing rules for all sports -- from badminton to basketball -- under the International Olympic Committee umbrella. 
Now, Pound said, he would like to turn his attention to the North American leagues, each of which has its own anti-drug regulations. "I'd like to meet with each and ask, 'Why not adopt a code approved by a worldwide group of countries, federations and national organizations?"' Pound said in a recent interview. "In the interest of the integrity and health of your sport, and understanding the influential role American athletes have on American youth, why wouldn't you want to join an alliance trying to get serious about banning drugs in sport?"
But pressuring the American professional sports into change is going to be exceedingly difficult. There is a long history of indecision on the subject, not to mention issues of worker rights. And the I.O.C. has no jurisdiction over play in those professional leagues, and little leverage.
American professional players who have competed in the Olympic Games have been subject to drug tests as will those who compete in the 2004 Olympics in Athens. But those tests were administered over a short period. The new world doping code calls for year-round testing and, most important, a two-year ban from competition for certain violations, like steroid use. A second offense can bring a lifetime suspension.
Imagine George Steinbrenner's reaction if he were to lose one of his highly paid players for two years because baseball wanted to adhere to the global doping code. Imagine a Pro Bowl quarterback lost for the same period. Imagine a player barred for life after a second offense.
American professional leagues are not the only ones that have balked at joining with the new global code. European professional soccer leagues have not agreed to the strict penalties adopted under the I.O.C. umbrella. Cycling officials have also been reluctant to sign on.
"It's true that it is not just the American leagues," said Pound, who is a lawyer in Montreal and an I.O.C. member. "In the soccer leagues they test, but many sanctions tend to fall in the four-to-six-month range, cycling even less, and they might let them serve the penalty in the off-season."
Also, in some sports worldwide, testing has been spotty and extremely selective. An entire team, for example, may not be tested.
Still, ever since Mark McGwire hit 70 home runs in 1998 while taking androstenedione, an over-the-counter supplement frequently called a steroid precursor and banned by the I.O.C. as well as the National Collegiate Athletic Association, there has been an international focus on American professional athletes. When a major sport like baseball does not try to enforce a prohibition on steroids, amphetamines or ephedra with extensive testing regulations and strict penalties, the impression of American pro athletes as cheaters widens. Particularly in Europe, American athletes are depicted as artificially crafted behemoths thumbing their noses at well-intentioned, if flawed, international drug policies and tests.
As Jacques Rogge, the I.O.C. president, said recently of the American professional leagues: "There is a little bit of a feeling that double standards have been used in the past. If a U.S. track and field athlete or U.S. cyclist can't use ephedra, why would a professional baseball player be allowed to?"
Pound said: "I plan to go to the American leagues and say, 'You can lead the way for the rest of the world. Are you serious about banning drugs in sports, or are you not?'
"An American baseball player has enormous influence on youth, so the focus is on him. The fact is, he has a responsibility that is greater than it is for a Bulgarian weight lifter. Again, why not lead the way?"
Officials of the four major North American leagues were largely noncommittal on the new international doping regulations. Some, like the N.F.L. -- which already tests periodically for ephedra, steroids and andro, and has a penalty structure for offenders -- insisted they already had a strong anti-drug program for their players.
N.B.A. officials reacted similarly, saying the league tests its veteran players in the preseason for steroids, amphetamines and marijuana and has had talks with the N.B.A. players' union about adding ephedra to the list of banned substances.
"We understand that the I.O.C. has a different drug program that may be appropriate for them, but we don't think it necessarily is applicable to the N.B.A.," said Russ Granik, the N.B.A.'s deputy commissioner. "We don't see any reason why they should be asking the N.B.A. to alter its drug program. The I.O.C. has to deal with different athletes -- weight lifters and cyclists -- sports that deal directly with raw strength and endurance.
"We have a drug program we are very comfortable with that has worked very well for us. Obviously, when our athletes are in the Olympics we comply with their guidelines, and our N.B.A. athletes have had no problems."
Major League Baseball, which does not test for amphetamines or ephedra and has just launched an experimental and anonymous steroid survey testing program that has, as yet, no finite penalties connected to it, indicated that it would be happy to meet with Pound or Rogge.
"But whatever changes considered would have to be negotiated through the collective bargaining agreement," Rich Levin, a spokesman for Major League Baseball, said. 
Asked if baseball management would support additional drug testing for steroids and other drugs in future negotiations with the players' union, Levin said: "That would be a difficult thing. We've just started a new process. We'll evaluate it after this year and deal with it from there."
Minor league baseball players are banned from using certain drugs -- ephedra was banned shortly after the death last month of Baltimore Orioles pitcher Steve Bechler -- but the union for major league players has opposed most drug testing.
The N.H.L. does not test for any I.O.C. banned substance unless a player is identified as part of the league's substance abuse program. The current collective bargaining agreement expires after this season; talks over a new agreement are expected to be contentious, an atmosphere that might make the creation of a new drug testing program even more thorny.
Still, N.H.L. players who competed in the 2002 Olympics were tested by the I.O.C. Bill Daly, the N.H.L. executive vice president and chief legal officer, said the league had kept in close contact with those responsible for drafting the new worldwide doping code.
"While we strongly believe in the importance of maintaining our independence to tailor a program that meets the specific needs and circumstances of our business," Daly said, "there is no doubt that we agree with the stated purposes underlying the new code and the stated reasons for its adoption."
As for Pound's personal efforts to coax the leagues into adhering to the new code, representatives of each of the leagues said they would have to wait to see what Pound proposed.
"We would be glad to listen and would consider any invitation brought to us," Levin said.
Greg Aiello, a spokesman for the N.F.L., said the league had no position on the new doping code. Asked if the N.F.L. was considering change in its drug policies, Aiello said: "We have a very strong program and continue to monitor it as warranted. It is an evolving, on-going process."
Pound is undeterred in his zeal to press the issue on the big business of North American professional sports.
"If they have players taking drugs to improve their performance, then that's cheating," Pound said. "If one player has 14-inch wrists from taking steroids, he is stealing from the players who have 7-inch wrists who don't take steroids. That is an economic crime. Well, now we have a code, adopted by a world of groups, that can do something about that.
"I plan to go to the commissioners of the major American sports and ask them to be come and be a part of that. I may be Pollyannaish, but to me, that's an invitation that is hard to ignore."

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Queens: 43 Arrested In Drug Raids 

BYLINE:  By Shaila K. Dewan (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 After a yearlong investigation, New York City law enforcement agents moved to break up six drug rings in Ozone Park and Howard Beach, Queens, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said yesterday. The police arrested 43 people and confiscated illegal drugs, 7 guns, 10 luxury cars and nearly $150,000 in cash, the officials said. 
Most of those arrested, Mr. Brown said, were "unemployed mob wannabes" who spent time dining at expensive restaurants and visiting tanning salons. Among those arrested were three people believed to have ties to the Gambino crime family, and the actor Richard Maldone, the police said. Mr. Maldone, who played Albert Barese in several episodes of "The Sopranos," was charged with one count of selling ketamine, a drug popular in nightclubs. Shaila K. Dewan (NYT)

HEADLINE: S.E.C. Asks 3 Food Makers About Dealings With Dutch Chain 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The federal investigation into Royal Ahold, the Dutch grocer, appeared to broaden yesterday when three of the largest food manufacturers in the United States said that they had been contacted by regulators about their dealings with Ahold's distribution business.
 General Mills, H. J. Heinz and Kraft Foods said they had been asked by the Securities and Exchange Commission to furnish investigators with documents regarding their transactions with Ahold's U.S. Foodservice division. The companies said they were cooperating with investigators, but declined to provide any further details about what information regulators were examining or what they are seeking to learn. 
 Royal Ahold said in February that it had overstated earnings by $500 million for the last two years because of accounting problems connected to payments made to U.S. Foodservice. The problems involved the inflation of promotional payments from suppliers, falsely increasing the unit's profit.
Two top Ahold executives have resigned, and others from U.S. Foodservice have been suspended. The Justice Department and the S.E.C. are now investigating the company's accounting. 
The payments in question are paid by the manufacturers to distributors like U.S. Foodservice as incentives for putting their products on grocers' shelves.
Last week, ConAgra Foods, Sara Lee and Tyson Foods acknowledged that they had been contacted by federal regulators regarding the investigation of Ahold and its subsidiaries.
At a conference with industry analysts yesterday, Stephen W. Sanger, the chairman and chief executive of General Mills, said his company would continue to supply products to Fleming, the food distribution company that filed for bankruptcy protection on Tuesday after losing its biggest customer, Kmart.
The S.E.C. is investigating how Fleming accounted for payments to suppliers and how it reported its revenue and earnings. Analysts and other industry experts are concerned that Fleming's suppliers will halt shipments or demand immediate payment.
"We're working actively with Fleming to ensure that we can continue to supply products," Mr. Sanger said in a statement.
Neither the troubles at Ahold nor Fleming are expected to affect General Mills' previously released financial statements or its 2003 earnings, Mr. Sanger added.

HEADLINE: Bush Is Planning to Give States Control of Housing Vouchers 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 3 

 BODY:
The Bush administration wants to give states control of federal vouchers that help nearly two million families pay their rent, which would be a major change for one of the government's largest housing programs.
 Administration officials say states could more efficiently manage the vast program, known as Section 8, which covers 2,600 local housing authorities. About $1 billion in vouchers went unused last year, roughly 8 percent of the program budget. 
 "Section 8 is sort of broke," Housing and Urban Development Secretary Mel Martinez told a Senate subcommittee recently.
Critics of the proposed shift, mainly Democrats and advocates of low-income housing, say they fear that states would establish different standards for who could qualify for the subsidies. They also say the change would further burden states. 
"The voucher program could use some improving," said Irene Basloe Saraf, legislative director for the National Low Income Housing Coalition. "But not to the extent and the type of change that the Bush administration is proposing."
The Section 8 program was started in 1976. Families that make less than 50 percent of an area's median income are eligible for vouchers, with some exemptions available for the elderly and disabled.
People apply for vouchers locally and can use the money to rent private housing. Typically, participants pay no more than 30 percent of their monthly income in rent, with vouchers covering the rest. 
Barbara Thompson, executive director of the National Council of State Housing Agencies, said the proposal could improve the program if there is limited federal regulation and adequate financing for states.
Some cities have long waiting lists for vouchers. Federal rules require that three-fourths of families who get vouchers after waiting be from the lowest income brackets.
Critics say they fear that states would not be required to abide by that rule if HUD makes the switch. The administration is not proposing enough money to keep pace with rents, said Beth Cooper, of the National Association of Housing and Redevelopment Officials.
Mr. Martinez envisions a Section 8 program that works with state welfare systems. Congress overhauled the nation's welfare programs in 1996, letting states institute tough eligibility rules and work incentives. 
Full details of planned shift have yet to be released, but critics fear states may be allowed to limit the time someone receives vouchers. 
Mr. Bush proposed the change in his 2004 budget, which includes $13.6 billion for the vouchers, $1 billion more than 2003. That would cover the 1.8 million families on vouchers now, plus a reserve of 100,000. 
Under the plan, which is subject to approval by Congress, money would go to the states, which would distribute the vouchers to local housing agencies that apply for them.

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer; 
To Imagine Iraq After Saddam Hussein, You Must Think Like an Iraqi

BYLINE:  By ETHAN BRONNER 

 BODY:
Every journalist abroad wants to tell his readers at home two contradictory things. The first is: "The people here may look and sound strange, but they are no different from you and me. They want security and dignity; they seek a better life for their children. What you share with them far outweighs your differences." The second message is the opposite: "Yes, people here hunger and hurt and love; yes, they enjoy ice cream and action movies. But if you think that by knowing that, you know them, you are mistaken. These people are very different from you."
 In eight years of reporting from the Middle East, I found myself whipsawed by these two perspectives and never more so than in the five reporting trips I took to Iraq during the 1990's. Since Saddam Hussein had led his country into two disastrous wars and his people live under harsh international sanctions in a pariah state, it was natural to assume that most Iraqis despised him and would dance in the street at the prospect of his removal. Yet that is not necessarily what I found. 
 Since the start of the current American-led war, it has been widely noted that celebration by Iraqis has been muted. The most common explanation is that Iraqis are afraid -- both of government goon squads and of the possibility that we will withdraw prematurely, leaving them at the mercy of whoever comes next.
This is clearly true. But what I found during my visits is that many Iraqis, perhaps a majority, seemed to believe in and identify with Mr. Hussein. While they feared their ruthless leader, what they feared even more was life without him.
I know this seems unfathomable. How could any people support a leader of such cruelty and megalomania? Don't Iraqis, like other people, thirst for freedom? Maybe, but political freedom is such a foreign concept that most Iraqis have no context in which to thirst for it. The contours of debate within Iraq are so narrow that there is no meaningful way to discuss negative feelings about Mr. Hussein. Indeed, the language of Iraqi politics has been so degraded that it provides no framework for opposition, let alone for what might be imagined as an alternative. It is, as one diplomat put it to me, "like a church -- people don't stop to ask if the God they are praying to is good."
This is not to say that Iraqis would not want to live one day in an honest, decent, free society. But it is to suggest that they are likely to misinterpret everything about such a plan, at least in the short term. They believe that the United States, which has led the international boycott of their country, has been keeping them down for the past 12 years. Tell them the same country has decided to spend billions and risk its young people to liberate them, and they will probably have no idea of what you might be talking about. 
Wherever I went during my visits to Iraq, often without a government minder at my side, I kept finding people who said Iraq's problem was the United States, not Mr. Hussein. Washington was responsible for sanctions, and Americans clearly feared a strong, independent Arab power, they said. That's why the United States opposed Mr. Hussein.
I also found the opposite: former government officials and professors, whose sadly elegant homes on the Tigris River were crumbling as their fixed salaries grew worthless. They despised what had become of their once-cosmopolitan lives, and they blamed Iraq's leadership more than Washington's.
An art gallery owner I met, a woman with impeccable English, said that without Mr. Hussein, factions within the Kurds and Shiites would be at each other's throats, and that fundamentalists would take over the government. She cited the modernization of roads, the economy and education, and the progress made by women under him. Iraq had a bloody history, she said, and without someone strong, even brutal, at the top, it would descend into chaos. 
In 1995, Mr. Hussein held his first popular "referendum" and "won" more than 99 percent of the vote. Everybody abroad dismissed it, but my sense was that an honest poll would still have given him a victory -- with 55 or 60 percent.
Part of the explanation is the nature of totalitarianism: millions of Soviets wept when Stalin died. Part of it is the nature of being held hostage. Iraq is a nation of Elizabeth Smarts. But part of it seems to have to do with the current state of the Arab world -- and here we face the "they are like us; they are different" conundrum. Regardless of how any of us feel about our political leaders, we do not worship them, nor do we consider it appropriate to do so. Iraq, on the other hand, is immersed in a cult of personality, and it is not the only Arab country where that is true. 
Nearly every state in the region develops what is to us a bizarre and harmful devotion to its ruler, hanging his portrait on every corner and considering criticism of him an insult to the entire nation. And this extends beyond the state's own borders. One can understand why Iraqis are afraid to criticize Mr. Hussein, but how to explain why Egyptians, Bahrainis and Palestinians have not made him the special target of contempt? Who has killed more Muslims in the modern world than Mr. Hussein? Yet there is no Arab literature devoted to his misdeeds. 
All of this suggests that when the war is won, engaging the Iraqi nation in the project of building an open society could prove extremely challenging. Public service has no meaning in Iraq. Each layer of bureaucracy lords its power over the one below it.
This does not mean we shouldn't try. But we must do so with eyes open to the nature of the task. If there is a ray of hope, it comes perhaps from the fact that one of the most clear-minded critics of Arab and Iraqi politics over the past 20 years -- Kanan Makiya -- is also among the strongest advocates of this war. Mr. Makiya, an Iraqi dissident, has been unflinching in his criticism but remarkably determined as he looks ahead. And indeed, it may be true that once the dictator is gone, his support will vanish with him.
Mr. Makiya wants a federal, demilitarized, democratic Iraq. "We have gone down one road as far as any group of human beings can," he says of the horrors of the Iraqi state. "Now we must try to go down another." That makes sense. Will Iraqis get it? I hope so. But very little from my time there gives me cause for optimism.

HEADLINE: Spanish Premier's Support for War Is Hurting Him Politically 

BYLINE:  By EMMA DALY 

DATELINE: MADRID, April 3 

 BODY:
Only a few weeks ago, the Spanish Prime Minister, Jose Maria Aznar, was basking in the glow of international attention, a privileged visitor to George Bush's ranch in Texas, an A-list participant in Anglo-American meetings on Iraq.
 But two weeks into the war, with little to show for his fervent support of the American-led operation and local elections looming, Mr. Aznar is under intense criticism. Millions of Spaniards have taken to the streets to protest the war and to condemn Mr. Aznar as an imperialist lackey (and worse); he is trailing in the polls and cracks are appearing in his party's united front. 
 "War sinks Aznar's popularity," proclaimed El Pais, Spain's leading daily newspaper and a critic of the Aznar government. A poll taken for the paper five days into the invasion showed Spaniards citing the war as the second main issue of concern, after unemployment. Mr. Aznar's approval rating, already flagging after seven years in power, had fallen 10 points in three months.
"The electorate demands that the PP change course," was the headline on a recent editorial in the daily El Mundo, which argues that the Popular Party will fare badly in local elections called for May 25, in part because of the war.
Florentino Portero, an analyst with the Strategic Studies Group in Madrid, said, "Spain is now facing an election campaign, so Aznar will try to speak less about the war and try to regain all the ground lost over the past few months." 
Mr. Aznar has long argued that supporting the war was the right thing to do, emphasizing the issue of terrorism to a country beset by the violent separatist group ETA. He plans to step down before general elections next year, which, until recently, the Popular Party was expected to win. Now potential successors are said to be afraid that voters will stay home to punish the party.
"They will not say so publicly, but many senior members of the PP disagree with Aznar's handling of the war," said Felipe Sahagun, a political commentator for Spanish state television. "They think he is jeopardizing the interests of Spain and the party for an action that is illegal."
He added, "If Baghdad falls soon, and the end of the war comes quickly, it will limit the damage because it will clearly be an American victory."
In the last two weeks, the party has lost Manuel Pimentel, a former minister, who resigned his party membership because of his opposition to the war. Almost every day, local officials follow his lead. Perhaps more significant, Felix Pastor, a senior party official, castigated the official line from a conservative perspective: "The idea of the PP as moderate, humanitarian and Christian has been blown away," he told El Mundo. "The Christian vote will be lost because of the government's complete indifference to the positions of Pope John Paul II." The Catholic right has been irked by the pope's anti-war pronouncements. Mr. Aznar has used the Iraq crisis to fulfill his desire to see Spain as a global player, but critics say he has been unable to display any tangible benefits.

HEADLINE: Big Board Abandons a Plan To Restrict Some Press Access 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
The New York Stock Exchange backed away from a plan yesterday to stop Wall Street analysts from talking to newspapers, television networks or other media outlets that do not disclose the analysts' potential conflicts of interest in their reports.
 The exchange also said yesterday that it had nominated William J. McDonough, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who has announced plans to retire in July, to be a public representative on its board. 
 Richard A. Grasso, the chairman of the exchange, is moving to quell a pair of controversies at a time when the Big Board's position as the world's dominant stock exchange appears more secure than it has been in years. While the Nasdaq stock market has fallen 72 percent since the technology stock bubble burst in 2000, the Big Board has lost less than one-third its value. 
The exchange dropped plans to bar Wall Street analysts from talking to journalists who do not disclose that the analysts, or their firms, have potential conflicts of interest concerning the stocks the analysts rate. When the exchange's proposal was disclosed last fall, newspapers complained that the Big Board had no right to try to regulate whether its members could talk to them and said the proposal might violate the First Amendment.
Edward A. Kwalwasser, the Big Board's group executive vice president for regulation, said at a news conference yesterday that analysts would be required to tell journalists about potential conflicts of interest between their firms and the companies they rate. The conflicts could include bids for investment banking business, other securities-industry-related business or even services provided by corporate affiliates of the investment bank, he said. For example, an analyst for Smith Barney, which is owned by Citigroup, would have to disclose that he had a potential conflict if a mortgage on the headquarters of a company he rated was provided by another Citigroup subsidiary.
But analysts will not be penalized if the journalists who are interviewing them do not disclose those conflicts in their reports, Mr. Kwalwasser and Mr. Grasso said.
"What the media does with it, that's entirely up to them," Mr. Grasso said.
The nomination of Mr. McDonough to the exchange's board comes less than two weeks after Sanford I. Weill, the chairman of Citigroup, withdrew from consideration for the same board seat. Mr. Weill's nomination was criticized by people who said that as the head of a giant financial institution, he could not fairly represent the public's interest at the exchange. The sharpest complaints came from Eliot Spitzer, the New York State attorney general, who said that Mr. Weill's nomination was a "gross misjudgment and a violation of trust," and promised to fight the nomination.
Mr. Grasso said at the news conference that if he had anticipated the response to Mr. Weill's nomination, "I would have counseled in a different direction."
He said the exchange planned to review its rules for nominating directors, which have not been changed substantially in more than 30 years. The exchange board now has 12 directors who are supposed to represent the public, 12 directors who represent the securities industry and 3 exchange executives, including Mr. Grasso. But under the exchange's convoluted rules, Mr. Weill could not qualify as an industry representative, Mr. Grasso said.
The Big Board also said it had nominated Robert B. Fagenson, vice chairman of the specialist firm Van der Moolen, to join the board as a securities industry representative.
In response to questions from reporters, Mr. Grasso also provided an update on the Big Board's disaster contingency plans. The exchange has decided not to have two trading floors operating simultaneously, he said. Instead, it will keep all trading at its heavily fortified headquarters complex in Lower Manhattan, while maintaining a smaller backup floor.
For cost and logistical reasons, Mr. Grasso said, the exchange decided against running two floors. In addition, moving traders away from downtown would further damage the city's economy, and the exchange did not want to do that, he said.
Finally, Robert Zito, the exchange's head of communications, said that the Big Board planned to continue to talk to journalists from Al Jazeera, the Arabic-language news network, whom it barred last week from its floor. The exchange revoked the journalists' credentials because of concerns about Al Jazeera's coverage of the war.
While the move has generated some complaints of censorship from outside the exchange, many Big Board members have strongly supported the decision, Mr. Zito said.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Luxury Rentals on Yonkers Waterfront

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
The first residential development in downtown Yonkers in more than 30 years, a luxury rental complex with 266 one- and two-bedroom apartments, is nearing completion on the city's burgeoning waterfront. Called Hudson Square, the $60 million complex includes 22,000 square feet of office, retail and restaurant space.
 For Yonkers, the opening of the apartment complex represents a major step in the rebirth of its downtown waterfront, a former industrial site that fell into disrepair in the 1950's and 1960's. According to Edward A. Sheeran, the Yonkers director of economic development, Hudson Park is the single largest private investment in the waterfront in the city's history. 
 Larkin Center, the new 200,000-square-foot home of the Yonkers Public Library and the city's Board of Education, opened in October across the street from Hudson Park on the former site of the headquarters of Otis Elevator, which left in 1972. 
Next to the apartments, the Metro-North Railroad station is undergoing a $35 million renovation of its historic Beaux Arts structure. The revived waterfront also features the newly opened Esplanade Park, a 1.5-mile promenade with unobstructed views of the Palisades on the opposite shore.
The developer of the Hudson Park complex is Collins Enterprises, which is based in Stamford, Conn. Collins, which specializes in the redevelopment of urban properties, has built a number of residential and office projects in Connecticut. The latest is an $18 million, 75,000-square-foot office complex on the site of a former American Cyanamid factory on the Stamford waterfront. 
Collins, in a joint venture with Avalon Bay Communities, built the Avalon, a 110-unit, $26.5 million rental complex completed in 1998 in Bronxville in Westchester County. A year and a half ago, Collins sold its interest in the project to Avalon Bay. Arthur Collins II, president of the company, said his concern, which also has several housing projects in Norfolk, Va., was actively considering other sites in Westchester.
Because Hudson Park is situated next to the Getty Square Station on the Metro-North's Hudson line, the apartments are being marketed to professionals in their 20's and empty nesters, many of whom want to be close to Manhattan, Mr. Collins said. The express train from Getty Square to Grand Central Station at rush hour takes 28 minutes. But with the location convenient to major highways, Mr. Collins said he was also focusing on renters working in Westchester.
The new apartment complex is comprised of two brick buildings, each of which are staggered in height from four to nine stories to maintain views of the waterfront for the public from other vantage points in the city. The apartments range from 697 square feet to 1,147 square feet, with rents beginning at $1,575 a month for a one-bedroom apartment and going up to $2,936 for a two-bedroom, two-bathroom unit with a den on the ninth floor with a full view of the river.Tenants are being offered the first month's rent free.
Included in the rent are amenities like membership in a fitness center, use of an on-site business center and concierge service. All apartments include washers and dryers. Parking in a covered area costs $75 a month; in outside areas, it is $50 a month.
The architect for the project, Do H. Chung of Stamford, who has worked with Collins Enterprises since 1975, said he designed Hudson Park so that as many apartments as possible had views of the Hudson. Because of the manner in which the buildings are massed and the way their heights are staggered, at least 80 percent of the apartments have at least partial river views, he said.
Brick was used for the facade of each building, in four different colors and sizes to give the impression of many separate buildings, Mr. Chung said, and the style of the eaves and trim varies.
He said his firm, Do H. Chung & Partners, followed design guidelines for the Yonkers waterfront established by Ehrenkrantz Eckstut & Kuhn, the firm that produced the master plan for Battery Park City.
Under an agreement with the Yonkers Industrial Development Agency, Collins is leasing the two and a quarter acres of waterfront land on which its buildings sit from the city. The developer will make payments in lieu of taxes to the city for the first 15 years; for the first 10 years, these payments will be $70,000 a year, after which they will increase in steps to about $1 million. After 15 years, Collins will be responsible for about $1 million in annual property taxes.
A rental office is open at the site, and occupancy is to begin on May 15.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Arthur Collins II, president of Collins Enterprises, the developer, looks over the Hudson Park complex. (Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: TV SPORTS; 
Cablevision Provision Could Benefit YES

BYLINE:  By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
For all the bitterness that existed between the YES Network and Cablevision over the past year -- and that still exists, despite their finally signing a deal on Monday -- they agreed on a provision in which Cablevision essentially becomes a financial defender of YES.
 The provision in the one-year contract involves indemnification. It requires that Cablevision reimburse YES for lost subscriber fees, advertising revenues and legal costs under two conditions: if other local cable operators claim economic loss because Cablevision is not carrying YES as an expanded basic cable channel, or if those cable systems follow Cablevision's lead by selling YES only in premium packages or as an a la carte service. 
 The issue was first raised at about 10 a.m. on March 12, about eight hours before Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced a tentative deal between the companies at Gracie Mansion. That deal fell apart on March 28, but was resuscitated three days later. 
From March 12 to the March 31 signing of the contract, the financial fundamentals of the deal remained the same: Cablevision will pay YES a monthly subscriber fee of $2.12 for every customer who receives the channel, and it will guarantee payments based on 51 percent of its 2.9 million local subscribers.
But because Cablevision is selling YES only as a premium channel -- unlike all other cable operators in the metropolitan area, as well as DirecTV -- Cablevision felt it had to make a serious concession that could prove costly.
James L. Dolan, the president of Cablevision, suggested that he would indemnify YES against losses, as a tradeoff for the agreement by YES to permit Cablevision to carry the sports channel as a premium channel instead of on expanded basic; that means that YES will not automatically be seen by the vast majority of Cablevision's local subscribers.
Dolan vehemently expressed his belief that Cablevision should make the offer, believing that Cablevision would end up paying YES little or nothing, according to several executives at the meeting. Yet, one Cablevision official said, Dolan could live with paying as much as $20 million. 
That payment would come on top of the minimum $37.6 million that Cablevision must pay YES this year for the right to carry the Yankees' channel. The indemnification is based on what the cable operators serving the inner markets that are closest to New York City do, along with DirecTV. 
The inner markets, which are called Zone 1, include 5.2 million TV households, more than half of which are in Cablevision territory. That leaves between 2.2 million and 2.3 million households served almost entirely by Time Warner and Comcast, as well as homes with DirecTV's satellite service.
Dolan is betting that those cable operators who have carried YES on expanded basic since last year will not take the chance of enraging customers by triggering a clause in their contracts (called a "most favored nation clause," or M.F.N.) that would allow them to switch YES to a premium tier or to sell it as a stand-alone channel. If they do not take advantage of that opportunity, these operators could argue that they have been economically hurt and seek the damages that Cablevision has agreed to finance.
Mark Harrad, a spokesman for Time Warner, said yesterday, "We're looking at the M.F.N., to see what the ramifications are for our agreement. There's no way to see how this will come out right now."
Michael Thornton, a senior vice president of DirecTV, said it was likely that the satellite service would seek damages "based on the economic advantage that Cablevision has in tiering YES." He said that taking YES off DirecTV's version of expanded basic would be unfair to subscribers.
All losses would be determined through arbitration or litigation; until those determinations are made, Cablevision would have to pay YES.
But asserting their rights does not mean that Time Warner, Comcast or DirecTV would get their way. If they claim economic loss, YES could challenge them on Cablevision's behalf. 
This is the fun part: first Cablevision pays damages for YES, then YES plays Perry Mason for Cablevision.Theoretically, cable operators would love to put YES, along with every other regional sports network and ESPN, on a premium or sports tier. They are aghast at the price of carrying sports, and would love to reduce the increasing (and unregulated) price of basic cable by selling sports services only to those subscribers who want them.
Some officials of large cable operators insist that the sports cable economic model is broken; once upon a time, sports networks were cheap enough to keep on basic cable. 
But now, they say, the rise in players' salaries have forced teams to seek increasingly higher rights fees from cable channels who in turn force cable operators to pay more, passing that cost along to all expanded basic consumers, including those who do not want those services.
"What's broken is the relationship between distributors and content providers," James O. Robbins, the president of Cox Cable, said recently. "The rise in cable rates are predominantly driven by sports programming costs."

HEADLINE: Visions and Revisions of Child-Raising Experts 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA COHEN 

 BODY:
Parents have never lacked for expert advice. "Kissing the baby after it has been fed is very likely to cause it to vomit." "Never let them sit on your lap." "Shake hands with them in the morning." "It's your problem, not your child's." 
 Ever since the science of child development was invented in the beginning of the 20th century, experts have offered parents a goulash of advice on how to raise the little marvel (or monster), creating as much anxiety and confusion as they are supposed to assuage. "I try to do just what you say," one 1920's mother complained, "but I am a nervous wreck just trying to be calm." 
 Given the proliferation of books about how Americans should raise the baby, it was inevitable that scholars would eventually turn to the question of why Americans are so obsessed with raising the baby. In a string of new books, social and cultural historians are trying to figure out just what it is about American parents that makes them so anxious -- and so eager to turn to the experts. Their theories differ, but what they do agree on is that there's a lot more to child care advice than simply child care. 
Views on family values, cultural trends, social developments and economic conditions have often turned out to be more important than any research. (The time-consuming child-centered approach wouldn't have had a chance in the 1950's if affluence hadn't made washing machines and vacuum cleaners commonplace in middle-class homes). "It wasn't firm data that drove child rearing expertise," Ann Hulbert points out in her forthcoming book, "Raising America: Experts, Parents and a Century of Advice About Children" (Knopf), "but changing social concerns that seemed to dictate its swerves and emphases."
The very development of "modern" child rearing practices was prompted by industrialization's disorienting shifts. As far back as 1909, Margaret Mead declared that "so longstanding and so rapid have been these processes of change that expectation of change and anxiety about change have been built into our character as a people."
She continued, "We have become correspondingly more anxious that they" -- our children -- "should be perfectly equipped before they go."
With these unsettling and rapid turns, early reformers declared it was time for science to take over and produce well-adjusted children who were prepared for the brave, not to mention complex and unpredictable, new world. The Progressive Era was fascinated with science and professionalization, and child-rearing trends, not surprisingly, mirrored those obsessions. 
Intellectuals, too, were preoccupied with replacing hoary traditions and religious practices with rational logic and science. Scientific education got further impetus after World War I, when army recruits were given I.Q. tests for the first time, Julia Grant writes in "Raising Baby by the Book" (Yale University Press, 1998). Half were graded at below-normal intelligence, causing an uproar that America was raising half-wits and incompetents. 
The creation of the child development field also proved a socially acceptable path for the increasing numbers of women who were earning college degrees. "Educators defined motherhood as valuable work requiring extensive knowledge and training," writes Ms. Grant, an associate professor at James Madison College at Michigan State University. Meanwhile, she continues, "the notion that the proper practice of motherhood demanded esoteric knowledge allowed women to reconcile their intellectual interests with their everyday lives in the home."
Anxiety over women's roles was not the only impetus for standardizing child-rearing practices. So were racial fears. Child-rearing advice became part of a larger project of Americanization, a way to assimilate immigrants and African-Americans more quickly, Ms. Grant argues. 
Soon bringing up baby was seen as too important to be left to amateurs. "It is beyond the capacity of the individual parent to train her child to fit into the intricate, interwoven and interdependent social and economic system we have developed," Ray Lyman Wilbur, the president of Stamford University, told a White House conference on children in 1930. 
Yet even after the novelty of industrialization and immigration faded, parental anxiety and the advice industry remained. Some scholars pointed to the cultural and geographical isolation that accompanied the move to the suburbs, when aunts, grandmothers and cousins were no longer nearby for kitchen klatches.
Others offered a different analysis. In the 1950's, the influential psychologist Erik Erikson argued that the loosening of religious strictures had left some parents without an outlet for their self-punishing impulses and therefore psychologically predisposed to feel anxious. "In certain cases and at certain times, whatever you say will be interpreted in such a way that a sense of guilt is produced in order to gratify a need to feel guilty," Erikson wrote.
Many researchers accused the media of fanning anxiety with sensational reporting of violence, freak accidents and health scares, says Frank Furedi, a sociologist at the University of Kent and the author of "Paranoid Parenting" (Chicago Review Press, 2003). Mr. Furedi argues that an even bigger culprit is "the breakdown of adult solidarity," or the notion that everyone shares responsibility for children (the it-takes-a-village approach). 
And most recently, Janna Malamud Smith, in her book "A Potent Spell: Mother Love and the Power of Fear" (Houghton Mifflin, 2003), argues that society has exploited maternal anxiety, tying mothers even closer to the home in order to avoid governmental responsibility for child welfare.
The expert advice that has fed -- and been fed by -- that parental anxiety has seesawed between two poles at a dizzying speed: what various scholars have called hard and soft, strict and permissive, nature and nurture, parent-centered and child-centered, Lockean and Rousseauean. Proponents of each approach can be found in every era, but if you want to know which has had the upper hand, take a look at what is happening outside the home.
Cultural critics in the 1920's, for example, warned against cloying motherly love, fearing it would fail to prepare children for the impersonal industrial world they were to enter. This concern paved the way for behavioralists like John B. Watson, who boasted of being able to program children as if they were microchips. 
During World War II, when the draft and the growing numbers of working women disrupted family life and fears of fascism ran high, the pendulum swung the other way: child experts now fretted about insufficient motherly attention. Coercive child-rearing produced frustrated, aggressive children, some experts argued. This was the period when the philosopher Theodore Adorno, a refugee from Nazism, wrote "The Authoritarian Personality," in 1950, arguing that stern, unloving homes produced prejudiced and authoritarian children. "A determination grew," Christina Hardyment writes in "Perfect Parents: Baby-Care Advice Past and Present" (Oxford Univerity Press, 1995), "to allow the children of the free world to be more free than children had ever been." 
It was into this atmosphere that the most celebrated child expert of all, Dr. Benjamin Spock, introduced the best-selling baby guide in history. Dr. Spock's warm and friendly approach offered more freedom to parents and children. The collaborative thinking that he endorsed was part of a cultural trend. As Ms. Hulbert points out, in 1946, the same year that Dr. Spock published his first edition of "Baby and Child Care," the political scientist Peter Drucker published "The Concept of the Corporation," which argued for more worker-management partnerships and more worker autonomy.
By 1968, though, Dr. Spock's outspoken opposition to the Vietnam War caused many critics to equate his politics with what they believed was his permissive brand of parenting. "The politics of child rearing and the politics of the nation had rarely been so clearly linked in the popular imagination," Ms. Grant writes. 
And until the 1970's, experts warned working mothers about the damage they were inflicting on their children by their absence. Only after the women's movement shifted public opinion did the experts shift too. (Dr. Spock himself switched positions frequently over the years as fashions changed, on everything from working women to drinking milk.) 
Subtle -- and not-so-subtle -- ideological agendas can also be discerned in the current brain research, as a new crop of baby experts use neuroscience to argue that children's personalities and abilities are either determined before they're out of diapers or remarkably malleable.
Yet among parents' obeisance to the books, there has been a subversive strain that has bridled at the tyranny of the expert. Even Arnold Gesell, one of the most famous child experts (who reassured us that "it's just a phase"), was told by his daughter-in-law, Peggy, after the birth of her second child in the 1940's, that "science is as nothing to me compared to a few minutes more sleep." 
That all-in-the-family skepticism has continued to spread. By the time of the 1950 White House conference on children, expert advice had so proliferated that overdependence on it was now the chief topic of concern.
And now one can read books with subtitles like the one Mr. Furedi put on his: "Why Ignoring the Experts May be Best for Your Child." "Parents are no more ignorant than the experts," Mr. Furedi declares, so "we might as well ignore them and act on our instincts." 
But why should the run-of-the-mill parent accept that advice? 
Because an expert tells them so.

HEADLINE: Creating a New Lure to Catch Crowds for Classical Music 

BYLINE:  By ANNE MIDGETTE 

 BODY:
In the current economy classical music is often said to be in trouble. Selling tickets in New York is a competitive business. Organizations are struggling with the question of how to attract wider audiences. 
 Jacqueline Taylor and Omus Hirshbein, longtime classical music presenters and administrators, have come up with a way to offer their art that addresses these problems. 
 They're giving it away.
"Free for All at Town Hall," their new concert series, opens tomorrow with a recital by Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg and Anne-Marie McDermott, the noted violinist and pianist, playing Schubert, Faure and Beethoven. Tickets will be distributed at the Town Hall box office, starting at noon on the day of the concert. Cost: nothing.
The point is to make great music available to an audience that cannot afford a high-priced ticket. Ms. Taylor, 38, who for six years was executive director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, and Mr. Hirshbein, 68, who for 20 years oversaw a cultural renaissance at the 92nd Street Y, have cast their nets wide. They have placed ads in a host of publications that presenters often overlook. 
The catch: none, beyond the obvious difficulty of raising money during an economic downturn. Ms. Taylor's and Mr. Hirshbein's nonprofit organization, Twin Lions Inc., has amassed money from private donors, foundation grants and their charter corporate sponsor, WQXR, which is owned by The New York Times Company. But with the costs of renting the hall and paying the artists they still need to raise $100,000 to complete their four-concert season. "If it's meant to be, it's going to happen," Ms. Taylor said last week, sitting in Mr. Hirshbein's elegant West Side apartment, where Twin Lions has commandeered a spare bedroom. "It's God's work." 
The idea had its seeds in "Beethoven 2000," a cycle of the Beethoven quartets that the Chamber Music Society offered in Ms. Taylor's final season. During a Lincoln Center council meeting about ways to mark the year 2000, one director mentioned his dream of filling the halls of the complex with a kind of public open house, and Ms. Taylor promptly went to David Shifrin, the Chamber Music Society's artistic director, who was planning a Beethoven cycle with the Orion String Quartet. "I said, 'We should make it free to the public, in celebration of 2000,' " Ms. Taylor said. "Everyone around me thought I was crazy," she added, "because you can sell out the Beethoven quartets at Lincoln Center, so why would you give them away?"
One answer: because of the long lines snaking down Amsterdam Avenue before every concert. "They were of all ages, races and dress codes, exactly the target audience classical music organizations everywhere are trying to attract," Anthony Tommasini wrote in his review in The New York Times. "And when the final quartet ended, the players were greeted with a standing, whooping ovation."
Ms. Taylor said the experience had been unforgettable. She had already announced that she was leaving the Chamber Music Society and going back to graduate school. But she said, "All I could think about was what I had just experienced, how to keep doing more of that."
Ms. Taylor's excitement touched a spark in Mr. Hirshbein, her former boss and mentor at the Y. After subsequent stints at the National Endowment for the Arts and the New York Chamber Symphony, Mr. Hirshbein was "loose," as he put it, and ready not only to listen to Ms. Taylor's vision of a nonprofit organization to present free concerts, but to act on it. "Without him, it would have just been talk," Ms. Taylor said.
Mr. Hirshbein approached Patti Cadby Birch, an art collector and philanthropist, and convinced her of the idea's merit. Mrs. Birch committed $100,000, and the project was under way. In its first season, "Free for All" is presenting four major New York recitals. Edgar Meyer, the bassist, will appear on May 11; David Finckel and Wu Han will play all of Beethoven's cello sonatas on June 8; and Joshua Bell, the star violinist, appears on June 29. 
In addition to the appeal of its mandate, the series offers the lure of Town Hall, once an obligatory station in a musician's career. "I feel like I'm making my debut," Wu Han said. 
The music is not in question, but the future is. Fund-raising has been tough: "It's a mess out there," Ms. Taylor said, and it is not as if the team can look forward to a boost from the box office. Nor are there advance sales to help estimate the turnout. Mr. Finckel, the Emerson Quartet's cellist and Wu Han's husband, said it was up to the artists to make it work. "I put a lot of responsibility on us," he said. "Hopefully a lot of people will come that have not heard a classical concert before, so the quality of performance has to be as great as any performance can possibly be." 
Ms. Taylor said, "The point is to have excellence." She added: "When I'm sitting in the fourth row of the Metropolitan Opera listening to some of the most exquisite music that exists on the planet, all I can think is, 'Who is this for?' Humanity has given the world incredible gifts, and I just want more of it to be available to more people without any connection to their ability to buy a ticket."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Anne-Marie McDermott, left, and Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg. (J. Henry Fair)(pg. D15)

HEADLINE: Alcoa Says Its Profit Fell 30% in the First Quarter 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Alcoa Inc., the aluminum producer, said yesterday its first-quarter profit fell 30 percent because of higher energy costs and softness in the aerospace and commercial building markets.
 Alcoa, the first Dow component to report earnings, posted net income of $151 million, or 17 cents a share, down from $218 million, or 26 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. 
 Excluding special items, the company posted earnings of 23 cents a share. Analysts had expected earnings of 15 cents to 24 cents a share, with a mean forecast of 19 cents, according to the tracking firm Thomson First Call. 
Alcoa is cutting costs and restructuring its businesses as oversupply and slowing demand in the aerospace and energy industries have hurt aluminum prices.
Fewer airline passengers and falling ticket prices have led to a decline in new aircraft orders, while low wholesale electricity prices and the poor credit quality of many energy companies have forced the cancellation or delay of new power plants.
But new acquisitions and strong demand from the automotive sector helped increase revenue 4 percent, to $5.11 billion in the quarter.
The company, based in Pittsburgh, also cited aggressive cost-cutting for its quarterly earnings. Alcoa said it had now achieved $808 million of the $1 billion in cost savings it is aiming for by the end of 2003, and it remained "solidly on track to meet that challenge."
It said in January that it would eliminate 8,000 jobs, or about 6 percent of its work force. Most of the jobs will be cut this year from smelters and from businesses serving the aerospace, gas turbine and auto industries.
Alcoa said it achieved $52 million in cost savings in the first quarter.
Shares of Alcoa rose 13 cents yesterday, to $20.04, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Alcoa announced its earnings after the close of regular trading. The shares rose as high as $20.75 after hours.

HEADLINE: The Fragility of Iraq 

 BODY:
The good news about the looming humanitarian crisis in Iraq is that it is not yet a crisis. There are pockets of desperate need but no widespread suffering. Ifsufficient military power can be brought to bear quickly to guarantee the security of aid workers, it should be possible to supply all the food, water and medical supplies needed. 
 Allied officials and nongovernmental organizations have been surprised and relieved that no major humanitarian shortages have yet developed. There has been no mass movement of war refugees fleeing from desperate conditions in southern Iraq, and the exodus of thousands of residents from Baghdad is driven more by fear of being caught in the midst of a battle than by deprivation. 
 Supplies of food and water are clearly short in some areas. The first relief trucks into towns in southern Iraq triggered near-riots as residents scrambled to grab food rations and water bottles. But over all the food supplies in Iraq are mostly adequate. The Iraqi government distributed enough food before the conflict began to last the average family to the end of April, so it will be a few weeks before the situation becomes desperate.
Strenuous efforts by the allies to avoid bombing water pumps and treatment plants, and the electrical systems they rely on, have mostly succeeded, guaranteeing most Iraqis a clean supply of drinking water. The worst potential problem -- a water crisis in Basra when a pumping station was knocked out by the loss of electricity -- has been largely solved through the heroic efforts of the International Committee of the Red Cross, whose engineers put the plant back on line. A water crisis in Umm Qasr has been mitigated by opening a water pipeline from Kuwait, though distribution remains chaotic. There has been no major outbreak of disease in Iraq.
Still, the situation is extremely fragile. The port of Umm Qasr, which was declared open with great fanfare this week when a small British relief ship delivered its supplies, is still threatened by mines, in need of dredging and short of the skilled manpower needed to unload large relief ships. The overriding problem throughout the south is that the same armed resistance that slowed the military thrust to the north continues to render most areas too dangerous for civilian aid workers.
The supplies and money for large-scale humanitarian assistance are being assembled. This week, the U.S. Agency for International Development pledged to contribute $200 million in cash to the United Nations World Food Program to buy emergency food for Iraq from other countries in the region, thus short-circuiting the need to wait for shipments from the United States. The U.N. itself has taken temporary control of an Iraqi oil-for-food account to pay for humanitarian aid, and some supplies trickled into the south yesterday. But all this will go for little unless the military devotes enough resources to suppress the armed resistance quickly and make all areas of Iraq safe for humanitarian workers to perform their lifesaving jobs.

HEADLINE: New York's Horror Budget 

 BODY:
Albany's three top leaders are circling one another warily, trying to figure out who will be the first to admit the hard truth: New York State's budget is in such horrendous shape that it will take a mix of taxes, cuts and borrowing to fix it.
 Until recently, Gov. George Pataki was virtually useless in responding to the fiscal crisis, which includes both a monstrous $11.5 billion gap and the possibility that the state could actually run out of cash later this spring. So far, his main concern seems to be making sure that his name is not wedded to any increases in what he calls "job killing" taxes. But this is a sham -- his own budget includes $1.4 billion in fees and sales taxes, which particularly touch the middle and working classes. His cuts in school aid have already forced local communities to start raising property taxes, in some cases more than 30 percent. 
 Mr. Pataki has finally begun to get engaged. Sometimes, however, it is not the engagement we need. Petitioning Washington at the last minute to try to wrest federal funds from New York City is the wrong move on every count. It makes the governor look petty and the state look disorganized.
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, the lone Democrat in Albany's trio of leaders, spends much of his time offering comfort to groups of aggrieved citizens who want the governor's cuts restored. But Mr. Silver must know that many of those people are going to have to be disappointed. He has to establish priorities, with education funds at the top.
The speaker deserves credit for coming up with a reasonable plan for borrowing money because Mr. Pataki's idea of using proceeds from the tobacco company settlement to secure bonds is no longer very secure. But Mr. Silver apparently wants more company before he publicly adds taxes to the mix. The Senate majority leader, Joseph Bruno, a Republican like Mr. Pataki, is trying to be the deal maker for this trio. Like Mr. Silver, he recognizes that the leaders must make unpopular decisions this year, not next year when there are legislative elections.
As budget experts warn about the state's running dry of cash in May or perhaps even June, Mr. Pataki, Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver will have to work fast to come up with answers. Closing corporate tax loopholes would help, as would a commuter tax for the city. The most reasonable solution for balancing the budget would be a broad-based income tax increase that would be phased down over a few years, coupled with across-the-board cuts that would be phased in over much the same period. Borrowing, as bad as it is, will have to be done, but as minimally as possible and over the shortest term available.
Mayor Michael Bloomberg has been mild-mannered and mostly uncomplaining in public about the fact that Mr. Pataki, his fellow Republican, has been offering less than zero help to New York City, the state's economic engine. The mayor has been trying to use honey to placate the grizzlies in the Capitol, but it is time for something less subtle, like a two-by-four, to get the Albany crowd's attention.

HEADLINE: A NATION AT WAR: DISSENT; 
The Rural Opposition: Protesting Where Everybody Knows Your Name

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: HARMONY, Minn., April 3 

 BODY:
When Eva Barr called the county courthouse to ask about a permit for an antiwar protest, the clerk on the other end of the line went silent.
 "Well, I don't know that I've ever dealt with such a phone call before," Ms. Barr, 36, recalled the clerk saying after a while. "I don't even know who to ask." 
 That was in January, when Ms. Barr concluded that "it's not exclusively for urbanites to be opposed to the established order" and decided not to drive an hour to Rochester, or two to the Twin Cities, to wave a sign. 
Instead, she and a band of protesters calling themselves Rural Peacemakers have spent Saturday mornings since then tromping around this corner of southeastern Minnesota, where cattle outnumber people and yellow ribbons are far more visible than "Stop War" bumper stickers.
In what old-timers say are the first street marches in these parts -- other than on Memorial Day -- the protesters paraded past the marquee proclaiming "United We Stand" outside Harmony AgriServices and the "Support the Troops" signs in the pharmacist's window in this village of 1,081. They marched through the downtowns of Canton, population 343; Chatfield, 2,394; Mabel, 766; Rushford, 1,614; and Spring Valley, 2,518. Nine people stood in Preston, population 1,426 and the county seat, the weekend before the war began, and a crowd of 81 descended on Feb. 15 on the artsy hamlet of Lanesboro, 788, where a church potluck followed the march.
"We're just little fishes in little ponds -- all you can do is speak out, speak up," Peggy Hanson, 52, a Lanesboro City Council member, said at Chat & Chew. "A person's a person, no matter how small.'
"Ever read about Horton?" Ms. Hanson added, citing Dr. Seuss. "The Whos, they just made this noise, but somebody heard them. We're like Whos in Whoville."
It is one thing to speak up in a large crowd in a big city and quite another to do it amid the farm fields. The antiwar movement here has already learned that politics are intensely personal in communities where people do not pass each other without waving and the woman at Harmony's Village Square restaurant recognizes the voice of the caller ordering a pizza.
The anonymity of chanting among several hundred thousand in New York or San Francisco is unavailable on Lanesboro's Parkway Avenue, where Lydia O'Connor, whose son-in-law is in the 101st Airborne Division in Iraq, stood silently writing down names as the protesters passed. Some small-business people who say they oppose the war have not joined the marches, they say, for fear of alienating customers; others who have protested report receiving nasty looks and letters. 
In Ely, a town of 3,724 in northern Minnesota, the City Council passed an antiwar resolution and then rescinded it 10 days later after the mayor was deluged by 200 calls.
So while Rural Peacemakers has helped link like-minded individuals from across Fillmore County, it has also left an unspoken tension in the quilting circles and coffee-shop dice games where people stick to safe gossip, avoiding difficult issues.
"That's the difference between city and country -- there are always consequences, social, political and economic consequences, to what you do here," said Peter Denzer, 82, a potter who lives near Rushford. "When you protest in Washington, D.C., when it's over, it's over. Here it stays with you.We see our fellow protesters all the time. We live with them. And we live with the people who see us."
Which is why Ms. Hanson, who owns a bed and breakfast, took the "Say No to War With Iraq" sign off her lawn after the missiles started falling on Baghdad.
"I don't want Lydia to have to drive by my house and see that sign," she said of Mrs. O'Connor. "I don't want to make her daily life any more difficult than it already is."
But Mrs. O'Connor's husband, Joe, who retired after 26 years in the Army, said he could not help but feel insulted by the "War is Good Business -- Invest Your Son" sign that Frank Wright -- Ms. Hanson's companion, who makes wooden spoon sculptures -- has in his studio.
At big-city demonstrations, Mr. O'Connor said, you see placards; at small-town protests, you see faces.
"When you stand up for an issue in a small town -- was it Aristotle who said every action has a reaction?" Mr. O'Connor said over beers at the Lanesboro American Legion Post No. 40, which has 109 members. "Once hostilities start up, you're responsible as a citizen to think about more than just your views. You've got to think about your neighbors."
The Rural Peacemakers are echoed by pockets of protest in the nation's small towns, but they represent a small minority, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll, which showed that the strongest support for the war was in rural areas, where large percentages of people have relatives deployed in the Persian Gulf region. In the poll, 82 percent of rural residents approved of the invasion, compared with 69 percent of city dwellers.
The small thread of dissent along the country roads here has roots in the upper Midwest's farmer-labor populism that has long questioned international entanglements. But it also reflects the growing rift between natives and newcomers -- anyone without grandparents in the cemetery -- as this area, like others, tries to revive the dying farm economy with tourism, drawing artists and telecommuting yuppies.
Consider Harmony, about 17 miles south of Lanesboro: "so small we don't even have a town drunk so we all have to take our turn," according to Myron Scheevel, 67, one of a dozen men who took part in a dollar dice game at Harmony House, the local cafe. As the story goes, the town got its name when residents were bickering over various options and an elder banged a gavel to quiet them, demanding, "Let's have harmony."
Joy and Bob Johnson, who have lived in Harmony since the early 1970's, used to distribute 10-page political pamphlets through the window of the A & W drive-through they owned, so no one was surprised to see them leading the local peace march.
Mrs. Johnson, 69, said that when she invited the women in her Monday kaffeeklatsch to join her on Saturdays, they always had something else to do. But that might just be the Harmony way of disagreeing.
"I think it's a joke," Ada Austin, a farm owner, said of the protests. "We've got our boys over there."
Referring to the Johnsons, John Ryan, a retired hog buyer, said, "When you've got a Republican regime, we've got some hard-core Democrats that protest anything."
Fillmore County, in which Harmony is located, voted 49 percent for Al Gore in 2000, 46 percent for George W. Bush and 4 percent for Ralph Nader. But the legislators who represent the area in St. Paul and Washington tend to be conservative.
Elton Redalen, a retired Republican legislator and state agriculture secretary, comes from a family that has farmed here for six generations. Every Memorial Day, Mr. Redalen, 77, takes his American flag and marches through Lanesboro. So when he heard about the Rural Peacemakers, he took his flag and planned a counterdemonstration.
"I needed to make sure that when the story was written that it wouldn't only be the anti-Bush, antiwar protesters," he explained.
"I don't hate them, I love them," he added of the peace demonstrators. "We live here. We have to get along with them."
In New York and San Francisco, rallies supporting and opposing the war compete for crowds and scream at each other across police cordons. Not in Lanesboro. Mr. Redalen, carrying his flag, and Mr Wright, with a "Wage Peace" sign, walked arm in arm at the head of the line, down Parkway Avenue and to the Lutheran church, where Mr. Redalen led those gathered for the potluck in a prayer.

HEADLINE: Siebel Warns of Lower Software Sales 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Siebel Systems Inc., a software company, warned yesterday that its sales in the first quarter would be much lower than expected after major deals were postponed. 
 The news sent Siebel shares down to $7.37 in after-hours trade, after closing down about 5 percent, at $7.75, on Nasdaq. 
 The company, the largest maker of customer sales and service software, said that it expects to have revenue of $330 million to $335 million. Analysts expected $368.9 million.
The company said software license sales would be about $112 million, compared with previous expectations of $130 million to $150 million. 
The company, based in San Mateo, Calif., said it expected first-quarter net income of $3 million to $5 million. 
The chief executive, Thomas M. Siebel, blamed the changes on an environment of "continued global economic deterioration."
