HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Hotels; 
Bookings Are Down, but Properties Keep Opening

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
DESPITE a decline in bookings attributed to economic softness and the uncertainties of the war in Iraq, hotel operators have been showing confidence in the future of travel to New York by opening new projects and refurbishing older properties.
 "You have to take the long view," said Vijay Dandapani, the chief operating officer of Apple Core Hotels, a privately owned company that operates five hotels in Manhattan. "A downturn is a good time to do construction projects." 
 One such project is a $2.5 million refurbishing of the lobby of the building at 17 West 32nd Street, which was designated as a La Quinta Inn last December, after being operated for several years as a Best Western. It is the only outlet in Manhattan for La Quinta, a midprice chain based in Dallas. 
A few large hotels have opened since attacks of Sept. 11, including the Westin New York at Times Square, with 860 rooms, and the W Hotel Times Square with 509 rooms, but most have been smaller projects. These include the Hotel 41 at Times Square, 206 West 41st Street, which has 47 rooms, and City Club at 55 West 44th Street, which has 65 rooms.
"It is a tough environment right now, with bookings slowed to a crawl and cancellations up 20 to 30 percent" since the beginning of the war, said Sean Hennessey, director of the New York hospitality practice for PricewaterhouseCoopers, an accounting and consulting firm. "But New York will come back."
According to NYC & Company, the city's travel and promotion operation, some 2,100 hotel rooms have been added since the attack on the World Trade Center, either through renovation or new construction. Projects already under construction are continuing and those in the planning stage appear to be proceeding as well, said Christyne L. Nicholas, the group's president. "I have not heard of a single cancellation" of a project, she said. 
The reopening of the 561-room Millenium Hilton at 55 Church Street, now scheduled for May 1, will bring back into service the last of the hotels temporarily closed because the Sept. 11 attack, she said. The attack led to the closing of 1,528 rooms in all. 
She said most promotional efforts are aimed at attracting visitors from no more than 500 miles away -- a distance considered close enough for a family to drive.
INTERNATIONAL visitors are not considered good prospects while hostilities continue, although the city may benefit from American travelers who decide they do not want to visit Europe this year, she said.
One foreign market that is being subject to serious promotion, however, is Japan, in connection with sporting events, Ms. Nicholas said. The presence of the slugger Hideki Matsui, a former home run leader in Japan, on the Yankees is one lure. A planned preseason game between the Jets and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers in Tokyo on Aug. 1 may whet Japanese appetites for football. "It makes sense to try to lure the Japanese," she said.
The falloff in visitors to the city since the war began follows the pattern of the Gulf War in 1991, she added, although not so badly thus far. The occupancy rate is currently just below 70 percent, while in 1991 the rate fell below 60 percent, according to Ms. Nicholas.
Most executives say it makes sense to complete projects that are under way, despite the drop in occupancy and advance bookings. The Westin Times Square, which is part of the E-Walk development of Tishman Realty & Construction, opened last October with 400 of its 860 guest rooms ready for occupancy. The hotel will be fully open by the end of the month despite "a temporary but not insignificant drop in call volume," said William J. Sales, the president of the Tishman Realty Corporation, a management unit of the parent company. 
He said changes in the neighborhood of the hotel, which is at the corner of 43rd Street and Eighth Avenue, had altered the mix of visitors from what was expected when Tishman signed the lease for the site in 1996. "We have had a lot more corporate visitors than we originally planned," he said. 
Since the Durst Organization announced the plan to build what is known as 4 Times Square at the northeast corner of 42nd Street and Broadway, Times Square has become a magnet for large corporations. These include the publisher Conde Nast, the anchor tenant at 4 Times Square, along with Reuters, the news and financial information company, and Ernst & Young, the accounting firm.
"We have 5 million square feet of office space in the area now," Mr. Sales said. "It was part of what we hoped for the future, but it was not in place at the time."
ANOTHER project that is going forward is the Gansevoort, a 13-story 187-room hotel that is under construction at 13th Street and Ninth Avenue, in an area that was best known for its meatpacking operations. "We will be topped out by the end of April," said Michael Achenbaum, a principal of WSA Management Ltd., the developer of the project.
He said the area, which retains remnants of its industrial past,is "one of the most interesting in the city, like SoHo was in 1990." He said construction during a slack period was less costly than when business is booming and said the opening this fall might be timed to meet an upsurge in travel.
"We don't build at the height of the cycle, so we can expect an upside," he said. The hotel, whose distinctive feature will be a 45-foot outdoor pool on the roof, will be operated as a high-end boutique, with a basic room rate of about $300 a night. It will be managed by Henry Kallen, who developed such boutique properties as the Giraffe and Library hotels. 
Mr. Achenbaum said Mr. Kallen was chosen because of his emphasis on service for guests. "Service is very important in a high-end boutique hotel," he said, "We want people to come back."
The barriers that must be surmounted before building can proceed in New York are so formidable that anyone who has overcome them has an incentive to push a development to conclusion, said hotel industry consultants. "From the original concept to completion of a hotel is a least a two- to three-year process," said John A. Fox, a senior vice president of PKF Consulting, which specializes in hotels. "So we will see the opening of anything that is in the pipeline."
Mr. Dandapani of Apple Core Hotels said the purpose of the lobby remodeling at the La Quinta Inn is to give business travelers the same sort of feeling that they would have at the 350 or so other hotels in the chain. This is a more challenging task in a 1904 building with a landmarked exterior, however, than with a new building in the chain's home markets in the southwestern United States.
To add to the impression that everything is up to date, despite the Beaux-Arts facade with its columns and keystones, Apple Core is installing a wireless Internet access system that will be available free to guests, he said. "It is like the free continental breakfast we offer," Mr. Dandapani said. "It is for the business traveler who wants to do his work, have breakfast and get going."
The property was built as the Aberdeen Hotel, a residential hotel, at a time when the Herald Square area was the city's leading entertainment district. Over a century the bright lights faded and the neighborhood became best known as a home for crime-filled welfare hotels, including the notorious Martinique at the corner of 32nd and Broadway.
The Martinique is now a Holiday Inn, and the neighborhood is now home to a large concentration of Korean restaurants and stores. "What a difference 10 years makes," Mr. Dandapani said. "When we took control of the property in 1993, it was a single room occupancy place with a few transient guests. Now it is very safe with a lot of nighttime activity."
He said that despite the current downturn, Apple Core is building a La Quinta Inn near McArthur Airport on Long Island to take advantage of the chain's ties with Southwest Airlines, which uses the airport as an entryway to the New York market.
"People have written New York off time and again," he said. "But they always come back."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Refinancing Fever Also Strikes Commercial Owners

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN 

 BODY:
JUST as homeowners are being blitzed by e-mail offers to refinance their homes at "50 year" and "all time" low rates, commercial real estate property owners are also being pitched offers that once would have seemed too good to be true -- and seizing on them.
 "We closed on two refinancings this week," said Alexander von Summer III, managing principal of the Parsippany real estate firm Alexander Summer, which owns commercial property all over New Jersey. "We have another one just about to close. There are another two properties where we are looking at refinancing. 
 "The interest rates truly are at a historic low, and this is the time to harvest opportunities," he said. "Everybody in real estate that I talk to, if there is any opportunity to secure a mortgage, they're pursuing it." 
The Gale Company, based in Florham Park, closed last month on a huge refinancing, gaining it a reduction of two percentage points on the rate of interest on a mortgage covering 37 properties, mainly in New Jersey. The $418 million mortgage is for the Bellemead portfolio, purchased in 1997 from Chubb Insurance in partnership with UBS Paine Webber and Morgan Stanley. 
Negotiating over 18 months with the original lender on the purchase, the General Electric Capital Corporation, "we entirely recast the loan," said Gale's president, Mark Yaeger. The mortgage was extended for three years, at a floating rate tied to various economic indices, he said; he did not disclose the current rate.
Mr. Yaeger said Gale was considering an additional step to keep the interest rate down -- one that is not generally available to a homeowner with a floating rate mortgage. "We are contemplating acquiring a couple of interest rate caps," he said. "Those are insurance policies that protect from an unforeseen spike in interest rates."
Jon Mikula, a senior director with the commercial real estate finance company Holliday Fenoglio Fowler, an Edison-based firm that acts as an intermediary for commercial property owners in arranging financing, noted that rates have crept up a bit over the past couple of months. But, he added, "They are still ridiculously low."
Fixed-rate financing that locks in a low interest rate for an extended time continues to be the best option. So, why are many companies pursuing floating-rate loans? "Generally, because they have to," Mr. Mikula said. "They have a mortgage coming due, and they know interest rates are not expected to rise rapidly for at least a year, so they go with the lowest rate available now, realizing they may have to refinance again when rates go up significantly."
Mr. Mikula said he had refinanced his home three times in the last 20 months, starting with adjustable-rate loans, because "I don't expect to be there all that long, and the rates were better," and most recently obtaining a 4 percent fixed-rate, seven-year loan because "that's an amazingly good deal."
Mr. Mikula said there is a "bubble" of three-to-five-year floating-rate loans coming due now, loans that were taken on properties that had substantial vacancy rates at the time of purchase by buyers who believed they could turn that around. But many commercial property owners found that impossibleamid exceedingly sluggish market conditions in the past 18 months. Nationwide, Mr. Mikula said, approximately $12 billion in floating rate loans on commercial property is coming due in 2003.
"Some companies in New Jersey bought buildings that were 50 percent leased with a game plan of trying to stabilize the property in three years -- and now it's three years later, and unlike Gale's scenario, there has been no leasing," he said, "The property is still 50 percent vacant."
Mr. Mikula said those property owners would face "a challenging time" attempting to refinance their properties.
On the other hand, he said, companies that have made successful turnarounds of commercial properties are welcomed at mortgage bank "swap desks," where floating-rate mortgages can be converted to fixed-rate, and vice versa. Denholtz Associates of Rahway, a firm that focuses on purchasing properties it can improve and lease up, for example, was able to refinance five properties valued at $90.5 million in the last year.
IN Newark, the Heritage Management Company announced it had recently refinanced the mortgage on an office building at 550 Broad Street -- purchased only 18 months earlier -- after renovating the building and increasing its occupancy from 50 percent to 90 percent.
Heritage Management bought the 282,000-square-foot building for $20.5 million in June 2001, putting up $2 million in equity and taking a three-year acquisition loan at 6.86 percent interest for $18.5 million, said Heritage's president, Steven M. Greenberg. When an offer to purchase the refurbished leased-up building came in at $38 million last fall, Mr. Greenberg said, Heritage decided to hold onto 550 Broad instead of selling -- and to borrow at a better rate against the property's increased value. 
Heritage refinanced the mortgage for $27 million at a rate of 6.6 percent with the Bank of New York, Mr. Greenberg said, and took $2 million in cash away from the deal. "The refinancing allowed our company and investors to realize the full benefits of an effective turnaround at the property," he said.
Mr. Mikula said he continuously gets calls from property owners with older fixed-rate mortgages who would like to refinance, but who worry that prepayment penalties -- known as yield maintenance penalties by lenders -- make it a bad idea. "But if you do the math, and roll over the penalty and the balance, cash flow increases significantly," he said. "Refinance really becomes a no-brainer." He offered the following hypothetical case to illustrate:
"Let's say you have a property which had a $10 million debt on it, purchased eight years ago. For a 10-year loan with 25-year-amortization, a good rate at that time was 8.5 percent, which would give you annual debt service of $965,000 and a loan balance of $8.7 million.
"In order to refinance, you will have to pay the yield maintenance penalty to the original lender to provide him with the return he would have gotten if you stayed with him. You calculate this by looking at alternative investments he might make with the money -- Treasury notes, more often than not. The difference between the mortgage interest on $8.7 million, and $8.7 million invested in treasuries paying 1.8 percent, is $1.1 million," over the two years left on the original loan.
"You might say: '$1.1 million! That's 12.8 percent as a prepayment penalty!' 
"But if you take the $8.7 principal balance, plus the $1.1 million penalty, for a total balance of $9.8 million, and you get a new 10-year loan, with 30-year amortization, and a 6 percent interest rate, your new annual payment is -- holy cow! -- only $705,000." With an annual saving of $260,000, the prepayment penalty would be covered in less than five years.
Alternatively, Mr. Mikula added, if his hypothetical owner wanted to keep his annual debt service at $965,000, he would be eligible for a mortgage loan of $13.4 million at 6 percent -- and could legally take the $3.6 million extra that was borrowed tax free. The $1.1 million prepayment penalty might be tax deductible as well, he said, if claimed as interest payment. 
But maybe, Mr. Mikula said, that course of action does not work for a particular property owner. Perhaps, refinancing a year or two from now makes more sense. In that case, the lending specialist said, it is possible to "block in a forward permanent loan." In other words, a commercial owner can obtain a commitment from a lender for a loan at today's rates that will be activated a year or two down the line.
"Most lenders are comfortable with blocking in 12 to 18 months," he said, "and in some cases, 24 months."
Also, stepped-down prepayment penalties are available, Mr. Mikula said, so that if a borrower refinances within the first year of a loan he pays a certain percentage as penalty, a lower percentage the second year, and so on. "This is so darn smart for property owners," he said. "Once the payment drops, then you close on the new loan."
Mr. Mikula says he tells clients to pore over their portfolios, analyzing every prepayment opportunity and seeking any possibility of obtaining a locked-in low rate of interest on a new loan.
Mr. von Summer quoted his advisers as saying, "Take on all the debt you can right now." Alexander Summer is currently buying out a long-term ownership partner for a warehouse in Carteret. The partner, an individual investor who is engaged in estate planning, sought the buyout, according to Mr. von Summer. The company is happy to proceed, he said, since it was able to secure a nine-year loan at just a fraction over 5 percent. "With interest rates like these," he said, "it's definitely win-win."

HEADLINE: Executive Life; 
Captains of Industry Still Yearn for Yachts

BYLINE:  By PHIL PATTON 

 BODY:
THE assets of L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco International, have been frozen as he awaits his trial in September on charges of enterprise corruption and grand larceny. But exceptions have been made.
 Justice Martin Shulman of New York Supreme Court agreed that the crew of the Endeavour, Mr. Kozlowski's classic racing yacht, had to be paid. So he unfroze $200,000. 
 The judge ruled that Mr. Kozlowski cannot use the yacht himself without the court's permission, but you can: the Endeavour is available for charter at $22,000 a day, plus a $5,000 a day delivery charge, crew included. The Endeavour has been steadily booked, said Marcia J. Whitney, who supervises the yacht for its chartering company, J-Class Management in Newport, R.I. "She's in Antigua right now."
Its availability offers a rare opportunity for the merely wealthy to experience the ultimate plaything of business tycoons. The yacht turns captains of industry literally into captains and gives substance to their sometimes swashbuckling image. It also provides an escape from the pressures of the job, and from the news media.
The Endeavour, a 130-foot yacht that was launched in 1934, has become perhaps the most striking example of Mr. Kozlowski's wealth. It was to the Endeavour that he retreated after his legal problems became public, and where he held a wine-tasting party on the Fourth of July. Ever since he bought it in 2000, the yacht overshadowed other trappings of his privileged position in corporate America -- his Nantucket estate, Sea Rose farm, with its $5 million, 7,000-square-foot mansion set on 3.8 acres by the sea; his retreat in Boca Raton, Fla., which people close to the company said was paid for with a $19 million no-interest loan from Tyco that was later forgiven; his residences in New Hampshire and Manhattan; even the infamous $2 million birthday party he threw for his wife in Sardinia, featuring waiters in togas and an ice sculpture replicating Michelangelo's "David," from which Stolichnaya flowed into crystal glasses.
As status symbols, yachts have had their rivals for the affections of the barons of American business and banking. In the 1890's, they were eclipsed by a land equivalent, the private rail car. J. P. Morgan enjoyed his yacht, the Corsair, but said he was never so happy as when crossing the Continental Divide in the shower bath of his rail car.
More recently, the private jet topped the list. In 1998, Nathan P. Myhrvold, then the chief technology officer of Microsoft, waxed eloquent in the pages of Vanity Fair about the pleasures of a customized Gulfstream V private aircraft, for which he paid $38 million.
But, over time, nothing has matched the mystique of the yacht. In his 1999 book, "Luxury Fever: Why Money Fails to Satisfy in an Era of Excess," Robert H. Frank, a Cornell economics professor, placed the return of the yacht ahead of mega-mansions, private jets and luxury S.U.V.'s as a manifestation of 1990's conspicuous consumption. Total sales of yachts -- pleasure craft of more than 100 feet in length -- more than doubled from 1988 to 1998. Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of WorldCom, played to the free-spending image when he named his yacht Aquasitions.
Though their appeal is universal, yachts seem to have especially captivated Americans. According to Professor Frank, they own about half the 5,000 yachts on the planet. Yachts can have hot tubs and fireplaces, gyms and even basketball courts; they can desalinate seawater and pump the Internet through fiber-optic networks. Maintaining a yacht and paying its crew runs from about $750,000 to $2 million a year.
High-technology stars are among those who have bought yachts. In 1996, Lawrence J. Ellison, co-founder of the Oracle Corporation, treated himself to a $10 million, 192-foot, five-deck yacht, renamed it the Sakura and outfitted it with a teak deck, a chrome-and-white living room and an onboard gym.
And James H. Clark, the founder of Silicon Graphics and a co-founder of Netscape, built his computerized dream boat, the 155-foot sloop Hyperion, which has its own digital network, 22 touch-screen displays and 30,000 pages of blueprints in its memory to ease repairs at sea.
DUTCH shipping merchants of the 17th century are credited with creating the yacht as a pleasure ship. The first notable American yacht, according to the social historian J. C. Furnas, was built in 1816 for the merchant George Crowninshield Jr., who, evoking an ancient precedent for pleasure craft, named it Cleopatra's Barge.
Cornelius Vanderbilt, the 19th-century shipping and railroad magnate, built a sumptuous steam yacht, the North Star, in 1853. It was lined with rosewood, satin and silk and set off on a tour of Europe the same year.
The Endeavour's innovation was the quadrilateral genoa, a new type of sail, providing its speed. Its creator was Sir T.O.M. Sopwith, who built his fortune in World War I aviation. The Sopwith Camel fighter, built by his company, downed the Fokker of Baron Manfred von Richthofen -- the Red Baron -- and was the airplane flown by Snoopy in his "Peanuts" doghouse dreams.
After World War II, the Endeavour was nearly scrapped as the fortunes of its subsequent owners declined; it was bought at one point for $:10 by two carpenters. In 1984, Elizabeth E. Meyer, an American yacht restorer and broker, bought the hulk and had it rebuilt at the Royal Huisman Shipyard, the Dutch yacht yard where Mr. Clark's Hyperion was also built and where Peter the Great of Russia once worked incognito.
Ms. Meyer sold the refurbished boat, with a new cherry deck and working fireplace, for an estimated $25 million to Mr. Kozlowski in 2000. "You better charter now, because after the trial he'll take her back," she said.
Through his lawyer, Stephen E. Kaufman, Mr. Kozlowski declined to comment for this article. But at the time of the purchase, he was effusive. "No one truly owns Endeavour," he declared with unaccustomed modesty. "She's a part of yachting history. I'm delighted to be the current caretaker."

LENGTH: 987 words

PERSON: Alan Kligerman 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
An Antiwar Chief (and Proud of It)

BYLINE:  By AMY CORTESE

 BODY:
ALAN KLIGERMAN is the first to say he has had good fortune. He has prospered as an entrepreneur, he says, and appreciates the rights he enjoys as an American.
 "I am for this country," he said in an interview last week. "Nobody should misinterpret that." 
 In that assessment, he hardly stands out among the ranks of corporate executives. But he has distinguished himself in one particularly contentious way: he has been a vocal and unrelenting critic of President Bush and the war in Iraq.
Despite the prominent role that business executives have played in shaping debate on other matters of public policy, from deregulation to tax cuts and labor law, remarkably few have publicly expressed an opinion about the war, either for or against.
Fred Talbott, a professor of leadership communication at Vanderbilt University's M.B.A. program, says chief executives in particular often have perspectives that can be valuable in a national debate.
"Business and other leaders," he said, "seem to be reluctant to speak out at all." The reasons, Mr. Talbott and others say, include a fear of offending their company's shareholders and customers, and of being publicly labeled unpatriotic.
As the founder and chief executive of his company, AkPharma Inc. in Egg Harbor Township, N.J., Mr. Kligerman shrugs off such concerns. He built a small empire creating digestive aids like Lactaid, a brand of milk for people who cannot digest lactose, or milk sugar. He also developed Beano, an enzyme that breaks down the complex sugars that can make beans hard to digest.
He sold the rights to both of those products years ago, though AkPharma makes versions of Beano and Lactaid for pets, as well as several new antacid products, including Prelief, for people.
"The U.S. is a land of unbelievable, unparalleled upward economic mobility for the entrepreneur," Mr. Kligerman said. "That is something I truly appreciate."
Mr. Kligerman was born in Atlantic City and worked in his parents' dairy business near there, delivering milk to customers.
After studying dairy science at Cornell, he started an ice cream delivery service in the late 1950's and later founded a low-sugar ice cream company called SugarLo. From there, he moved into nondairy ice cream and then lactose-reduced dairy products; that business became Lactaid Inc. in 1974.
At the same time, Mr. Kligerman raised five children with his first wife. He is now married to Donna Battista, a pianist, and has seven grandchildren.
Through the Kligerman Foundation, of which he is chairman, he has contributed to nutritional research and other philanthropic causes.
But while praising the United States, Mr. Kligerman does not hesitate to speak out against the Bush administration. He contends that its policies, particularly involving the war in Iraq, are tarnishing the worldwide image of the United States as "a haven for the oppressed, a place of free speech, free thought and free yet governed economic growth."
Mr. Kligerman, who will turn 73 this month, protested the Vietnam War in the 1960's. He supports the Anti-Defamation League and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
He supports Business Leaders for Sensible Priorities, a nonpartisan group of business executives and former military officers who contend that the government's spending priorities, particularly involving the military, do not address the nation's most pressing needs.
Mr. Kligerman's name has appeared in antiwar advertisements that the group has run in newspapers and magazines to warn that war in Iraq will not only take a terrible toll in human life but will also hurt the economy and breed terrorism.
In addition, he has given speeches and written op-ed essays criticizing government positions on the war, energy policy and civil rights. Most of all, he has lamented what he calls the hubris that characterizes the Bush administration.
In debates about the war in Iraq and the country's domestic and foreign agendas, such views are not uncommon. What is unusual is for a business executive to express them as publicly -- and as often -- as Mr. Kligerman does.
He acknowledges that it is easier for him to speak his mind because his company is small and privately owned. Leaders of large, publicly traded companies, on the other hand, generally find it too risky to take a stand on the war -- for or against.
The few who have made their feelings known have been harshly rebuked. Richard Abdoo, the chairman and chief executive of the Wisconsin Energy Corporation in Milwaukee, for example, was pilloried as un-American by talk-radio hosts and criticized in an editorial in The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel after he made a private $250 donation last November to the Not in Our Name Project, a group opposed to the war. Mr. Abdoo's name appeared on the group's Web site, as did the name of his company.
A spokesman for Wisconsin Energy said Mr. Abdoo was trying to put the episode behind him and would not comment on it.
Unlike Hollywood celebrities or other public figures who have been openly critical of the government, corporate executives have a fiduciary responsibility to their shareholders that makes it difficult to separate personal actions from official duties. Not surprisingly, most of the executives who have taken a public stance on the war have been from small or private companies, or are retired.
One notable example is R. Warren Langley, one of dozens of antiwar protesters arrested in mid-March trying to disrupt the Pacific Stock Exchange. Mr. Langley, a former Air Force lieutenant colonel, was president of the exchange from 1996 to 1999.
Mr. Kligerman said he had received no negative reactions to his public comments -- and had no second thoughts about making them. "The Bush administration does not embody America," he said. "America to me is not a country that suddenly suspends constitutional rights, imprisons without charge, without access to legal counsel or family."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alan Kligerman, chief of AkPharma, contends that the war in Iraq is tarnishing America's image worldwide. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
What the Economic Indicators Miss

BYLINE:  By Anthony DePalma 

 BODY:
BACK in his day, former Mayor Edward I. Koch used to stroll the streets of New York City asking "How'm I doing?" It was one way of evaluating his administration, but it gave only a partial picture of what was really going on in his city. 
 It is the same with other measures. Analysts like to quote straightforward numbers like the gross domestic product or the Dow Jones industrial average when they talk about progress. But while such indicators say much about the overall health of the economy, they say little about daily life in a city like New York or about the people like Memon Ahmed who live here. 
 Mr. Ahmed, 36, came to New York from Bangladesh 19 years ago to lead a life that, on the surface at least, conforms to the American dream. He is a banquet waiter in a Manhattan restaurant and he and his wife, Shanjida, own their one-family house in Queens, where they live with their two young children. 
By the standard economic measures of our times, the Ahmeds are doing well. But those indicators miss the part of their story that matters most. 
New York's banquet business has been hit so hard by recession that Mr. Ahmed takes home only a third of the $1,000-a-week salary he was getting two years ago when he worked at Windows on the World, the restaurant atop the World Trade Center, destroyed in the Sept. 11 attack. High heating bills over the winter devastated his household budget, and he has fallen several months behind on his mortgage payment. His wife needs to see a gynecologist but cannot because Mr. Ahmed does not have medical insurance. 
"I used to make good money; I was a spender," Mr. Ahmed said. "But now it's very difficult."
So while some people may watch the Dow Jones average andother economic indicators, Marc Miringoff, director of the Fordham Institute for Innovation in Social Policy, takes a slightly different approach. The problem is not that the Dow and other indexes reveal nothing about the well-being of a society, he said, "It's just that they represent a narrow view of national progress." 
To bridge the gap, the Fordham Institute, in Tarrytown, N.Y., and part of Fordham University, has put out an annual report since 1987 that takes the pulse of the nation by looking at the well-being of its people.
The Fordham index examines an array of social indicators -- including infant mortality, child poverty and health insurance coverage -- and then calculates a single composite number, tracking it over time. The index goes back to 1970. 
Until 1976, social health kept pace with economic progress. Since then they have diverged, with gross domestic product continuing to rise as social health has declined. Mr. Miringoff says he thinks this reflects a change in job composition. Solid blue-collar jobs with stability, ample benefits and salaries sufficient to support a family have been replaced by jobs with relatively weaker salaries, fewer benefits and less stability. 
That transformation has contributed to some troubling situations, Mr. Miringoff said. For example, while the national unemployment rate hit its lowest point in 31 years in 2000, average weekly wages have also declined. That means more family members must work to pay household bills. Or, as in Mr. Ahmed's home, where his wife cannot work, bread and beans take the place of chicken and meat in family meals.
Others who study issues of poverty agree: the standard indexes do not reflect "a significant number of New Yorkers who were not earning enough to survive on their own," said David Campbell, vice president of the Community Service Society of New York, an advocacy group for the poor. The working class poor, he said, have become practically invisible. 
Other trends that Mr. Miringoff considers troubling include big increases in child poverty, teenage suicide and the percentage of workers without health insurance, all problems worsened by low incomes. Making matters worse, he has found that income inequality is growing in several states, including New York, which has a bigger gap between rich and poor than any other state. 
Mr. Miringoff said when prosperity in the United States is measured in traditional terms, the picture is less disturbing than if people like Mr. Ahmed are taken into account. When working-class people are included, he said, it becomes clear that "we have a lot of people who are playing by the rules and simply not making it." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Memon Ahmed, with his wife, Shanjida, their daughter, Mashyat, 6, and son, Ruhan, 16 months, at home in Queens. Mr. Ahmed's income is a third of what it was in 2001. (Shannon Stapleton for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Into the Fray 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE

 BODY:
THE new director of the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art wants the institution, the nation's oldest public art museum, to play a central role in the American art world.
 "The Wadsworth has to matter to Hartford, the region, the country," said Willard Holmes, who has been deputy director and chief operating officer of the Whitney Museum of American Art since 1994, and was named the Wadsworth's director on March 20. 
 Mr. Holmes, who will begin his new post on May 1, has as much experience in the financial and administrative side of running a museum as he does in the curatorial aspects of the job. These are skills that he will surely require. 
Last December, the museum was awash in turmoil. Its director, who had served just over two years, had announced her resignation, and its board chairman and four board members abruptly quit. At the same time, its multimillion expansion and renovation plan was facing criticism that it was too expensive and did not address many of the museum's most pressing problems.
"There's no doubt there is a lot of hard work and difficult decisions ahead in the short and long term," said Mr. Holmes, 54, during a recent visit to the museum to meet with staff members. 
In Hartford, the state's poorest city and one long on urban woes and short on substantial cultural offerings, the Wadsworth is nonpareil. In addition to its world-renowned Hudson River School paintings, the institution houses a collection of impressive depth and scope, ranging from Old Masters canvases to contemporary work. The museum is the unofficial headquarters for the area's financial elite; the machinations of its board and staff are a favorite topic of the chattering classes.
Patrick McCaughey, who was director of the Wadsworth from 1988 to 1996, and is now a senior research fellow at the Yale Center for British Art, said a major challenge for Mr. Holmes would be satisfying the expectations of its board and staff.
"I don't know of any other art museum of which there is such an enormous expectation of what the museum can be and what it can do, from its staff to its board members, while having such an extraordinarily slender base of resources to do it with," Mr. McCaughey said. By "resources," he said he meant finances.
With his bow tie, shaven head and round eyeglasses, Mr. Holmes, has the air of an Oxford don. A native of Canada, he has degrees from the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, and specializes in 20th-century art. He was director of exhibitions and a curator at the National Gallery of Canada in Ottawa, and chief curator and later director of the Vancouver Art Gallery. At the Whitney, his main responsibility was to direct a $50 million expansion project. 
The most visible aspect of Mr. Holmes's new job will be steering the Wadsworth's expansion and restoration plan, projected to cost $120 million, of which $62 million has been raised so far.
The plan, unveiled in June 2002, was proposed by the Dutch architect Ben van Berkel, a member of a team of finalists for the design of the new World Trade Center. Under the plan, access to the museum would be improved, and gallery space increased.
But the proposal has been called too expensive in this economy and too ambitious for Hartford. In addition, its critics say, the project does not address problems that have long plagued the museum, like the lack of a loading dock, and sufficient parking and storage space. Critics also complain that the increase in gallery space is not enough.
"I still feel I need to get a sense of the physical structure and listen to staff to determine program needs before I speak on specifics," Mr. Holmes said, when asked about these issues.
The museum is scheduled to close for two years during the renovation, which is supposed to begin in 2005. But Mr. Holmes said that during this time, it "will not disappear from view."
"I didn't come to Hartford to run a museum that is closed," Mr. Holmes said, suggesting that some of the collection may be loaned to other local spaces, but declining to elaborate.
The closing of the museum would coincide with the opening of Adriaen's Landing, a convention and entertainment center that is part of the $1 billion Hartford redevelopment project. The Wadsworth, which is across the street from the site, has been touted by Gov. John G. Rowland and others as the "gateway" to Adriaen's Landing.
One of Mr. Holmes's most daunting tasks will be to unify the museum's 33-member board. Christopher Larsen, who is acting as the museum's interim director until Mr. Holmes takes over, is also temporarily serving as board chairman.
Mr. Larsen replaced George David, the president of Hartford's United Technologies Corporation, who resigned in December when he did not receive unanimous support on a proposal to keep decisions on personnel issues within certain committees. Several board members wanted the full board to learn more about the departure of the then-director Kate M. Sellers, who announced her resignation last October, citing personal reasons.
Does Mr. Holmes think Mr. David, who gave millions to the museum, can be replaced and harmony restored?
"Any museum needs an approach that focuses on the constellation, not on the stars," Mr. Holmes said. 
Mr. Holmes has four children, ranging in age from 20 years to 20 months. He said his wife, Mary Haus, who has been the communications director at the Whitney, will concentrate on "homekeeping" when the family moves to the area. They plan to live in Farmington, and are negotiating to buy a Modernist home on the same street as Harry Gray, former chairman of United Technologies and a local philanthropist. Mr. Holmes would not disclose his new salary.
Mr. Holmes offers few specifics of where he will take the museum. But he emphasized that it must be "essential."
"This institution clearly has a place in the hearts and minds of so many," he said.

HEADLINE: At Tracks, Wagering on More Than Dogs 

BYLINE:  By GAIL BRACCIDIFERRO

 BODY:
WHEN he takes a client to lunch these days, David Fallon has to drive farther from his small manufacturing plant in Plainfield than he used to do. 
 "In the early days, when the dog track was booming, we had more restaurants here," Mr. Fallon said, referring to the commercial and industrial district just off Interstate 395 near Plainfield Greyhound Park. 
 When crowds jammed the park to gamble on the dogs, he said, business boomed for the nearby restaurants, gasoline stations and grocery stores.
Now, those looking to gamble are most likely heading south from Massachusetts through rural eastern Connecticut on their way to the Foxwoods or Mohegan Sun casinos, which are about a half-hour drive from Plainfield. 
"People don't realize there is a lot of trickle-down effect," Mr. Fallon said of the businesses that once thrived from dog track customers.
Mr. Fallon said that is one reason he joined a group of residents, local business owners and state and municipal officials who support proposed legislation that would allow the greyhound track to diversify. 
Under the proposal, dog tracks in Plainfield and Bridgeport would be able to offer high-stakes bingo and keno games. 
The General Assembly is weighing the merits of the proposal, which was made by State Representative Michael A. Caron, a Republican who represents Danielson, Killingly, Sterling and part of Plainfield.
"The point is to diversify what the tracks already offer because when they want to adapt their business, they must change the law," Mr. Caron said.
As part of the plan, some of the money from the bingo and keno proceeds would be funneled to economic development efforts in Windham and Tolland counties in northeastern Connecticut.
In a region where many towns have not regained the industrial bases they lost when textile mills along the Quinebaug River began closing decades ago, a plan aimed at luring customers back to the track appears to be attractive to many.
The proposal would not only assist new businesses trying to locate in a region where poverty is not uncommon, but it would also keep the 200 employees at the dog track working, Mr. Caron said. 
While Mr. Caron's proposal has received the most attention from fellow legislators recently, other proposals aimed at allowing the track to offer other types of gaming are also pending in the General Assembly. 
In January, a group of eastern Connecticut veterans sought legislative approval to operate high-stakes bingo at the track. 
William Colonna of Scotland, who heads the group, Let's Help a Vet, said his organization had moved bingo and food preparation and vending equipment to the track in anticipation of setting up business. 
But now, since the group does not expect to receive authorization to run bingo, that equipment was removed last month.
Mr. Colonna, however, has not given up. "I'll put that bill in every year until I drop dead," he said.
Another legislative proposal calls for a high-stakes bingo operation at the track with proceeds funneled to the Rocky Hill veterans' home and hospital. 
Senator Anthony Guglielmo, a Republican of Stafford Springs, who co-sponsored Mr. Caron's bill, said the legislative proposals would have two purposes.
"Thetracks are hurting," he said. "And, we're trying to do a little something for the veterans."
But the proposals are likely to face stiff opposition. 
State Attorney General Richard Blumenthal warned legislators in February that proposals like Mr. Caron's could violate the state's compact with the Mashantucket Pequot and Mohegan Indian tribes, which annually add about $400 million to the state's coffers. 
According to the compact, as long as Connecticut bans commercial gambling, the tribes must pay 25 percent of their slot machine proceeds to the state.
Mr. Colonna said the veterans would challenge any entity that might receive state authorization to operate high-stakes bingo.
"I dare them to give a permit to anyone," he said. "It would discriminate against the veterans."
Many legislators, including Representative Jefferson Davis, a Democrat who represents Brooklyn, Eastford, Hampton, Pomfret and Woodstock, oppose the proposals to allow additional types of gaming at the tracks.
"This state, like all states, looked to easy money like gambling rather than take a closer look at how we raise and spend money," he said. "The greyhound park has had its run. It's just like any other industry. I'm not convinced we should keep it going."
In fact, attendance and wagering at the greyhound park began to decline almost as soon as it opened in January 1976. Statistics from the Connecticut Division of Special Revenue that oversees gaming in the state show that attendance and the amount wagered at the Plainfield Greyhound Park peaked in its first full fiscal year of operation.
From July 1, 1976 through June 30, 1977, the dog park had nearly 1.5 million customers who wagered $125.3 million, the division's statistics show. The park maintained an annual attendance of 800,000 to 900,000 from 1980 through 1986, the year the Mashantucket Pequots opened high-stakes bingo. 
Attendance and wagers continued to decline through the late 1980's and fell even more after Foxwoods Resort Casino opened in 1992. 
Between July 1, 2001 and June 30, 2002, the statistics show that the track had 117,171 customers who wagered $14.6 million.
Several calls were made to officials at the greyhound park, but there was no response.
First Selectman David C. Allard of Plainfield said he would like to see business at the track retained. The park is No.8 on the list of the town's top taxpayers and paid more than $124,000 in property taxes last year.
"The dog track has been an integral part of this community," Mr. Allard said. "They have been a good neighbor and assisted in charitable donations and local projects."
Although Mr. Allard said he and many others in Plainfield want to see the track thrive on its 82-acre parcel near Interstate 395, there are now signs that the town is also attracting other types of business development.
Ground is expected to be broken this spring for an $80 million Lowe's distribution center that will bring 400 to 500 new jobs to town, he said. Tax revenues from the center could top $1.5 million when incentives expire, he said.
"Plainfield has had a history of bad luck stories," Mr. Allard said. "But it seems to be turning around."
Stephen Dugas owns an industrial park building as well as a travel plaza that includes a gasoline station, convenience store and fast-food restaurant just off I-395 near the dog track. He developed the travel plaza after demolishing an old house at the site in 1998.
"Business has been growing here," Mr. Dugas said. "Now, we have an option on another property here."
If permits are secured, the 2.5-acre site will be the new home for a 65-unit Super 8 Motel, he said. The motel chain was interested in the location because of its easy highway access and location not far from the casinos, he said.
Mr. Dugas, however, did say he would still like to see more of the gambling stay in Plainfield.
"The best thing that could happen is to diversify at the dog track," he said. "A lot of people travel out of town to work now."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Groups are looking to bring high-stakes bingo and keno to the dog track, above. Stephen Dugas, left, would like to see more of the gambling stay in town, despite his plans for a motel near the casinos. (Photographs by C.M. Glover for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
Nathan's Builds on Its Core Product, Hot Dogs

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
AS a boy growing up in Nyack, N.Y., Wayne Norbitz worked after school, on weekends and during the summer at the Wetson's chain of roadside snack bars owned by his family. In 1975, his family sold the chain, which by then numbered 70 outlets, to Nathan's Famous, and Mr. Norbitz went to work at Nathan's flagship Coney Island restaurant, founded in 1916
 Nathan's moved from Coney Island to Manhattan in 1970 and stayed for 19 years in offices on Broadway. In 1989 the company moved to Westbury, and that same year Mr. Norbitz became president. 
 With a convert's zeal, Mr. Norbitz, now 54, has helped maintain the restaurant's quirky charm, based as much on its Nu Yawk chutzpah as on its all-beef hot dogs and other prototypical fast-food treats. Company research shows that more than 95 percent of New Yorkers recognize the Nathan's name. 
Despite its heritage, Nathan's, whose shares trade on the Nasdaq exchange, has fallen on hard times of late. Over the last four quarters, it posted a net loss of $12.6 million. It also closed nine of its 16 company-owned restaurants and reduced the number of franchised restaurants from 377 to 351. And the company struggled to find ways to revive two struggling subsidiaries acquired in 1999, Kenny Rogers Roasters and Miami Subs. 
Referring to 2002, Mr. Norbitz said, "I know this year does not look like a good year."
So, is Nathan's in trouble?
"Absolutely not," Mr. Norbitz said. "The way we have repackaged, reprogrammed and reinvented ourselves is very successful." 
Although he acknowledged that the company's 2002 financial performance seemed to indicate the reverse, Mr. Norbitz insisted that the red ink reflected compliance with new corporate accounting rules instituted this year.
For example, he said, the company handled the proceeds of a $900,000 property sale to the State of Florida as operational revenues. This was the proper method according to standard accounting procedures, Mr. Norbitz said, but the one-time influx of cash made subsequent sales totals seem smaller by comparison. 
Nathan's acquired both Kenny Rogers Roasters and Miami Subs in a plan intended to expand its geographic reach and product mix by buying companies whose value had decreased in recent years. The plan has had mixed results.
The Kenny Rogers Roasters chain, which the company bought out of bankruptcy court, has been the more successful turnaround project, Mr. Norbitz said. Although Nathan's has closed all but a handful of the Rogers restaurants in the United States, the chain is flourishing in Asia, where a Malaysian company has opened about 90 restaurants there and in the Philippines. 
The Kenny Rogers signature roast chicken and several other menu items live on in the United States, thanks to what the restaurant industry calls co-branding, a strategy in which one retailer pays a licensing fee in order to sell brands other than its own. 
When Nathan's Famous added Kenny Rogers rotisserie chicken to its menu, customers chose Rogers over the house brand, Mr. Norbitz said. So now Nathan's is phasing out its chicken items in favor of Rogers versions. The company is pursuing a similar co-branding tack with seafood, replacing its own line with Arthur Treacher's products, brands owned by the Trufoods Corporation in Lake Success. 
"We thought that people placed high value of the quality of Kenny Rogers chicken and some of the side dishes," Mr. Norbitz said. "Now when you order chicken, the menu doesn't just say, 'chicken sandwich,' it says 'Kenny Rogers Roasters chicken sandwich.' When you order fish, you get Arthur Treacher's."
The Kenny Rogers products cost 5 to 10 percent more. "We thought that there was price elasticity, that customers would be willing to pay more for this brand," Mr. Norbitz said. "We were right."
Miami Subs has presented a tougher problem. Nathan's has closed 26 Miami Subs, leaving about 200, according to Global Foodservice Newsletter. The chain, which in strong in south Florida, as the name implies, sells cheese steaks, chicken wings, hamburgers, gyros and similar items. "You could say it's been a disappointment," Mr. Norbitz said. "We're looking carefully at Miami Subs in an attempt to improve sales and profits. But we have no specific plans."
Despite the closings, sales at the chain have been falling, a situation Mr. Norbitz said was associated with the economic problems caused by Sept. 11. "Tourism in South Florida is way down, and that's hurting us greatly," he said. 
Most of Nathan's business still involves hot dogs, and its real growth has been selling them in some 6,000 supermarkets and warehouse clubs. "That business is doing exceptionally well," Mr. Norbitz said, and it increased by more than a third from 2001 to 2002. 
Mr. Norbitz's challenge is to increase Nathan's business without losing its heritage or allowing it to turn into a nostalgic sand trap.
Customers from the New York metropolitan area tend to associate Nathan's hot dogs with their own growing-up. "In focus groups, people would express emotion when talking about Nathan's, especially about the hot dogs," said Don Raskin, the president of the Manhattan Marketing Ensemble who has worked on Nathan's advertising account since 1990.
"Nathan's has a cultish appeal to its customers," said Mr. Raskin, who lives in Jericho. "Nathan's isn't like McDonald's. In fact, it's completely unlike McDonald's, from start to finish. You don't get the feeling that you're in a fast-food chain. It's less predictable. It's more personable. It's friendlier."
Last year Chock Cafe, a division of the Sara Lee Corporation, signed a co-branding agreement with Nathan's that so far has been paying off, said Gerry Pelissier, the vice president for franchising at Chock Cafe, which traces its roots to the Chock Full o'Nuts luncheonettes founded in Manhattan in 1932. Now both companies sell their products at each other's locations.
"Their heritage is similar to our heritage, and they seem a good fit with our cafes," Mr. Pelissier said. "We get more of a breakfast crowd, and they get a lunch crowd, so the products play off each other well. They seem to be trying to reposition themselves as a premium hot dog. We think that's great, as we're positioning ourselves as a premium coffee."

HEADLINE: A Deal Too Good to Be True? Well, Yes 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

 BODY:
WHEN local developers heard last month that the State of New York had put 370 acres of the former Kings Park Psychiatric Center on the auction block, many of them marveled, though warily, at the $2.5 million asking price.
 The figure, by anyone's estimation, is remarkably low for such a large property on Long Island's North Shore. But prospective buyers don't even have to get to the fine print in the state's offering documents to discover that although the property may be the largest piece of undeveloped real estate in the Town of Smithtown, it has a host of drawbacks. 
 Put aside the covenant to preserve open space that limits development to only about 90 acres of the property, the estimates for environmental cleanup that run upward of $34 million, and the well-known opposition to major development at the site from Patrick Vecchio, the town supervisor who essentially controls zoning for the property. As discouraging as those factors might be, the one thing that has stopped most developers in their tracks is that the state might not even own the property. 
A long-forgotten clause in the 1895 deed for the property, which was drawn up when the state officially received the property from what was then the "City of Brooklyn, County of Kings," essentially states that the land reverts to Kings County if and when the state stops using the property as a mental hospital. Kings County had originally bought the land and opened an asylum for its residents along the rural North Shore in 1885. The deed ceding the land to the state says the property must be used "forever solely for the use of a state hospital for the insane." Since Brooklyn is no longer a city and Kings County is now part of New York City, a letter to potential developers from the state reads, "The property is subject to a reversionary interest by the City of New York."
Vincent Polimeni, a Garden City developer who put together a preliminary bid for the property when it was first offered for sale in 1999 and was later taken off the market, said he wasn't interested in bidding this time. "If the state doesn't have clear title to it, then they're wasting their time," he said. "Because, in essence, they're selling nothing since they don't own it."
Ronald Parr, a Suffolk County developer who is considering making a bid for Kings Park, noted that bidders must submit $250,000 as a down payment on the property. "So if you're lucky or unlucky enough to be the successful bidder, you'd have $250,000 tied up not knowing whether you actually owned it and whether you should spend a dime on it," he said.
When asked about the property, officials from Mayor Bloomberg's office, from the city's Economic Development Corporation and from Brooklyn Borough President Marty Markowitz's office, didn't know where Kings Park was, much less that the city might have a legal claim to the property. City officials were also unaware that the hospital and hamlet of Kings Park were so named because of the connection to Kings County. But given the city's looming budget deficit of more than $3 billion, they said that, at first blush, an unexpected windfall, no matter how small, might be a welcome surprise.
State officials, said, however, that they hoped to settle the problem of the reversion clause quickly. "We're working to resolve that with the city," said Alexander Dudley, a spokesman for the Empire State Development Corporation, the state agency handling the sale. He said the city could legally waive its claim to the property or state legislation might be needed to give the property to the state once and for all. "We're in the process of reaching out to the city, and we hope to have fruitful negotiations," he said.
Given all the problems that come with the site, developers said they thought it was unlikely that the city would actually want to take possession of the property. But they pointed out that the city is now in a position to bargain with the state, perhaps to claim part of the sale proceeds or for something that might have nothing to do with Kings Park.
"Considering the state of the city's financial affairs, I can't imagine that Mayor Bloomberg would be cheering the state on here," Mr. Parr said. "But even if the state has other things to negotiate with, it's certainly not a very good start for the sale of this property. Who knows when it will be resolved?"
The deed dilemma is but the latest obstacle to the redevelopment of Kings Park, the last of three major psychiatric centers on Long Island to be sold. Plans to sell the property have strained relations between the state and town officials. Town leaders accuse the state of reneging on promises and pushing to sell the entire parcel, even if such a sale might hurt the local community. State officials have urged town leaders to be more flexible, since strict limits on redevelopment make the property virtually unmarketable.
Since Kings Park was closed in 1996, several studies on its reuse have been done, and the state has put it up for sale several times but has ultimately canceled each auction. In 1999, it was because the state parks department wanted to examine the site as a possible state park, and more recently it was because of insufficient interest from bidders. In 1999, the state subdivided the parcel, which was originally 567 acres, and created the Nissequogue River State Park, a 153-acre state park on the waterfront piece of the property. The state plans to keep about 30 acres of the property to maintain a nursing home, two adult homes and a nine-acre cemetery.
The number of patients at each of the three psychiatric hospitals on Long Island started to dwindle in the 1970's when the state decided to move the mentally ill from psychiatric hospitals to community-based residences. But while Kings Park and the Central Islip Psychiatric Center were both officially closed in 1996, Central Islip has already been redeveloped with housing, commercial buildings and a golf course. Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center in Islip maintains a mental hospital for about 1,200 patients on a small piece of the original campus, but Gerald Wolkoff, a Brentwood developer, plans to build a $4 billion complex of offices, restaurants, shops and apartments on the remaining 460 acres. Mr. Wolkoff paid the state $20.1 million for the 460 acres. Central Islip was developed in pieces over the years, but the most recent sale of a 44-acre parcel brought the state $2.2 million. 
The comparisons leave Kings Park leaders asking why the sale of their 370-acre property keeps stalling and why the state is offering the property at a fire sale price. The town assesses the value of the property at about $33 million.
"Central Islip was almost a carbon copy of Kings Park, right down to the buildings and the layout," said Charles Gardner, president of the Kings Park Chamber of Commerce. "Demolition and contamination could be no better or worse here than at the other hospitals, so why is it such a flash point for Kings Park and why are there all these barriers to something happening here?"
Desmond M. Ryan, executive director of the Association for a Better Long Island a developers' group, said Kings Park is different because it is not as centrally located and accessible to freeways as Central Islip and Pilgrim State. He also said that site remediation is a bigger problem at Kings Park because the state started demolishing and burying unused buildings in the 1970's, leaving about a million square feet worth of building debris that is laced with asbestos and lead-based paint. So in addition to paying for the demolition of the 46 existing and abandoned buildings on the property, a developer would have to clean up the buried debris as well.
He said the asking price for Kings Park is also low because without the waterfront property, developers have lost the potential value of waterfront homes. Mr. Ryan also said that unlike Smithtown's supervisor, Pete McGowan, the town supervisor in Islip, welcomed new development in his town. "If Pete McGowan were supervisor of Smithtown, you would the development community lined up to find a workable solution," he said. "But in Smithtown, it's almost impossible to do business."
Mr. Vecchio, the Smithtown supervisor, said that the town in recent weeks has been "inundated with calls from developers asking what we would allow there." He would like to see the property turned into parkland with some limited development like a corporate center or housing for older adults. His main concerns, he said, are that traffic and the number of children added to the school district be kept to a minimum.
With at least $34 million in environmental cleanup costs and development limited to 90 acres, he said, "it's clear that no one can develop that without expecting lots of density to make up for the cost." And Mr. Vecchio made clear that zoning changes to increase density would not be forthcoming. "Anyone foolish enough to purchase that land is taking a huge risk because I don't think whatever town board is sitting is going to allow intense development," he said.
Mr. Polimeni said Mr. Vecchio's vocal and adamant opposition was the main reason he has decided against bidding for Kings Park. "I've fought enough battles on Long Island, and I know if Pat Vecchio doesn't want it, it's not going to happen," he said. "You've got to be brain dead to go after it."
Town leaders say that the state's plan to sell off all the property at once and to require a developer to handle the cleanup would solve the state's problems at the town's expense. Mr. Vecchio has said repeatedly that if the state cleaned up the contamination that it has caused over the years, a less intrusive development plan would be feasible for the property.
"The state wants to get rid of everything because it just doesn't want the problem anymore," said Frank DeRubeis, the town's planning director. "But why should we rezone this for a higher density use to basically help the state out with cleanup costs, especially when we're going to have to bear the burden with whatever the final use is?"
But Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said when Kings Park was put up for sale, "by offering to sell this site to a developer who will be required to comply with local zoning laws and the stringent open space requirements demanded by Gov. Pataki, we ensure that job growth does not come at a cost to the local community or the environment."
Many town officials and residents would like to see development at Kings Park to mirror Central Islip, where the property was cleaned up and redeveloped one piece at a time over a period of more than 20 years.
That was why residents and business leaders embraced a plan offered earlier this year by Lynne C. Nowick, a Suffolk County legislator who proposed turning one of the larger buildings at Kings Park into a county office building that would house administrative offices for about 400 county workers. She said her plan would cost about $21 million and could be financed through the county's Judicial Facilities Authority. She said state officials visited the building to consider her plan but since the proposed sale includes the building, the state is clearly not committed to it.
"I have no intention of giving up on this though, because it makes sense," she said, adding that if Kings Park is sold, she would negotiate with the new owner to acquire the building for the county.
Greg Szurnicki, president of the Kings Park Civic Association, said most residents want to see some redevelopment at the site because the closing of the hospital devastated the hamlet's economy when it took away hundreds of workers who regularly shopped and ate in the downtown area. "I know some people want it to be a park, but we can't afford a park unless we have an income and a tax base," he said. "What good is a park if the town folds up?"
He also said that the state's desire to sell off all of the hospital property ignores the long interdependence between the state and town created by the hospital. The state, for example, has not addressed the $800,000 it now pays to the local school district each year as part of an agreement that goes back to the 1920's. The state started making contributions to the school system back then because many hospital workers lived at the hospital with their families and sent their children to local schools.
"If the property is sold for $2.5 million, the tax receipts from it would go down to $50,000 and that shortfall could mean $800 a year more in taxes per homeowner," Mr. Szurnicki said. "But the state doesn't care, it just wants to sell the property as is, where is, and how is."
John J. Flanagan, a state senator from East Northport, said he was confident a balance could be struck to satisfy the concerns of the town and of developers.
"But there's going to have to be strong cooperation from the town, because limiting development to the 50 or 80 homes that would be allowed under the current zoning isn't going to work," he said. 
He and Michael J. Fitzpatrick, an assemblyman from St. James, have said they would work to keep the state subsidy coming, at least until a new development was completed and could pay its share in local property taxes.
Many local officials say that the unanswered question of who actually owns the Kings Park property is emblematic of the state's haphazard approach to the site. Mr. DeRubeis said town officials learned about the reversionary clause about two years ago when some local residents decided to look at the original deed. "It was one of those questions you asked the state about and you never got any good answers," he said.
Leo Polaski, the official historian for the Kings Park Psychiatric Center, said there would be a certain irony if the property were to revert to Kings County. The county, after all, was essentially forced to give the property to the state after years of corruption and patronage scandals at the hospital.
"There were gallons of so-called medicinal whiskey for patients that instead went to workmen, and at one time all the doctors quit because Kings County fired all the attendants so they could put in patronage jobs," he said. "It wasn't unique to Kings Park, though, that kind of thing was happening everywhere in that time."
Kings County eventually lost all connection to the hospital as it became a full-fledged state facility. "It's been state property for more than 100 years," Mr. Polaski said. "But laws being what they are, and goofiness being what it is, maybe it really could revert to the city."
