HEADLINE: A Nervous State Looks to Limit Licenses 

BYLINE:  By YILU ZHAO

 BODY:
PEGGY YARROW wants a driver's license desperately. A single mother, Ms. Yarrow, a Peruvian citizen who has been in the United State for about 10 years, needs it to get to supermarkets for groceries and diapers, to send her daughter, Shaynna Saenz, 2, to preschool, to visit the pediatrician and to find a job to supplement her $600 a month welfare income. But when Ms. Yarrow, who is a permanent resident of the United States, applied for a license late last year at the Stamford office of the Department of Motor Vehicles, she was told she wasn't eligible because she wasn't a citizen.
 "How else am I supposed to live?" she asked. "You cannot live your life here without driving." 
 At least a half-dozen day laborers from Honduras and El Salvador without green cards, but with employment authorization cards issued by the Immigration and Naturalization Service, also said they were turned away this year when they applied for licenses. They said they were told that only permanent residents or United States citizens could apply. 
Connecticut regulations say no such thing, but immigration lawyers said the state has suddenly made it tougher for noncitizens to get licenses, a response, the lawyers said, to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Sixteen of the 19 suicide attackers held valid driver's licenses or non-driver's identification cards from states including Virginia and Florida, and these cards enabled them to board planes, open bank accounts and rent apartments. Now many states, not just Connecticut, are wrestling with the question of whether and how to issue drivers' licenses to immigrants. Bill Seymour, a spokesman for the Connecticut D.M.V., said the department had not changed its policy towards immigrants, but said the rejections may be due to counter clerks just being more careful.
"The driver's license is a de facto identification document," Mr. Seymour said. "We have the primary responsibility to ensure that they are who they say they are. If there is some problem later on, it will be us, not the immigration lawyers, who will get into trouble."
Almost every state has taken measures large and small to toughen the rules, according to the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators. New Jersey makes the licenses of non-immigrants' expire with their visas. New York has started to ask applicants for original Social Security cards or letters from the Social Security Administration explaining the lack of a card. Before, any document bearing the Social Security number was good enough.
The debate has been especially intense in Connecticut, where the Department of Motor Vehicles and a number of state legislators have introduced bills to restrict any immigrant's access to a driver's license, the state attorney general questions the legality of such legislation and immigration lawyers oppose such measures.
Connecticut D.M.V. regulations state that acceptable forms of identification to obtain a license include a certified birth certificate, a green card, a United States or Canadian passport or an employment authorization card, when accompanied by what D.M.V. calls a "secondary document," such as a baptismal certificate or a certified school transcript.
The debate over licenses has come at a time when the United States, receiving roughly 1 million immigrants a year, both legal and illegal, is experiencing the largest wave of immigration in its history, said Professor Marcelo Suarez-Orozco, an immigration scholar at Harvard. Unlike previous waves of immigrants, who landed at large cities as way stations before they moved to the suburbs and farms, more and more new immigrants avoid urban centers altogether. They go where the jobs are, packing meat, picking tobacco, mowing lawns or building houses.
And Connecticut has received its share of the new immigrants. The immigration service estimated that 100,000 legal and 39,000 illegal immigrants settled in the state in the 1990's. The majority of these immigrants were Hispanic, which is the state's largest minority group.
The Connecticut D.M.V. has submitted a bill to the Legislature's Transportation Committee to make the driver's licenses of immigrants expire when their visas do and to grant the department commissioner broad powers to determine the validity of immigration documents that foreign applicants present. The D.M.V. instituted a new regulation last year that made licenses expire with visas, but the regulation was struck down as unconstitutional by Richard Blumenthal, state attorney general. He pointed out that immigrants with valid work authorization but expired visas still have legal status. 
Pablo Peralta, 27, has a valid work authorization card, but still can't get a license. Initially an illegal immigrant, Mr. Peralta, a native of El Salvador, has acquired temporary protected status, a status granted to illegal immigrants from countries ravaged by civil wars or natural disasters. For him, returning to his home country is not an option.
"In my country, no job, no food, no nothing," he said matter of factly. "Too many criminals."
Working for a Stamford-based maintenance company, he paints walls, makes windows, build houses, moves furniture and cleans offices. Making $13 an hour without benefits, he has constantly sent money home and kept his parents and siblings fed and clothed. He needs to get to different work locations and has tried to apply for a driver's license a number of times. He said counter clerks wouldn't accept an application once they discover his immigrant status.
According to D.M.V. regulations, Mr. Peralta, who has an employment authorization card, should have been able to receive a license. 
Facing the prospect of losing his job, Mr. Peralta has bought a blue Honda Civic and drives anyway. "But I am scared, you know, of getting into accidents or being stopped by the police," he said.
Luis Zelada of El Salvador, a good friend of Mr. Peralta's, also is driving without a license after his application was rejected by the D.M.V., despite his having an employment authorization card. Mr. Zelada, 26, does the same job as Mr. Peralta and sends money home every month to support his 4-year-old son. Mr. Zelada knows he is an essential part of the Connecticut economy.
"Without us, the beds won't be made; the houses won't be built; the trees won't be pruned and the kids won't be taken care of," he said.
Jaime Padilla would not have got a driver s license without the help of Locals 1199 and 32BJ, unions for janitors and health care workers. Mr. Padilla, a 28-year-old Honduran citizen, is also under temporary protected status and has an employment authorization card. After Mr. Padilla, a roofing worker, said he was repeatedly turned away by the D.M.V. last year, his union stepped in to help. After multiple attempts, Mr. Padilla received his license.
Olina Lorthe , 59, an immigrant from Haiti, said she was refused a state nondriver s I.D., even though she had a green card last December. She was told she needed to be a citizen to apply. Ms. Lorthe, discouraged, had not applied again. 
It might be even harder for people to obtain a driver's license if the D.M.V.-backed legislation passes. For now, the bill seems to have won the support of the chairmen of the Transportation Committee.
"We are in a war," said Biagio Ciotto, a Democrat representing Wethersfield and Middletown who is a cochairman of the committee. "We should put in some protection for the average guy who gets up to go to work, pays his taxes and does the right thing. I know my cochair feels the same say."
Many immigration lawyers said the D.M.V. selectively enforced its regulations, a practice they said is haphazard and sometimes racist.
"They tell those with work authorization that you need green cards," said Philip Berns, an immigration lawyer in Stamford who has filed appeals for immigrants who were denied licenses. "They tell green card holders you need to be a citizen. They tell citizens you look Hispanic and your documents look fake. But if you are blonde and blue-eyed, no problem. Here is a driver's license."
A blonde British woman, who asked that her name not be used, said she applied for her license in Stamford last year even though didn't have any of the documents immigrants commonly need to receive a license. She got it anyway.
Sometimes, even citizens have a hard time. Nora Garcia, 22, who was born in Texas of Mexican parents, was denied a nondriver's state identification card at a Wethersfield D.M.V. office last September. She said she was told her birth certificate, from a small town bordering Mexico, didn't look real. 
Mr. Seymour, the spokesman for the D.M.V., said he couldn't comment on specific cases; he said counter clerks of the department do make occasional mistakes, but the mistakes are not systematic. 
Elizabeth Leete, who heads the motor vehicle task force in Connecticut for the American Immigration Lawyers Association, questioned the wisdom of limiting access to driver's licenses for both legal and illegal immigrants. For one thing, she said, granting immigrants driver's licenses provides the government a record of who is in the country. Second, D.M.V. workers are unlikely to sort out immigration rules and recognize all the legitimate documents.
In addition, denying driver's licenses to immigrants hardly thwarts terrorism, she argued. Terrorists could use passports to board planes, and they usually have the money to obtain good forged documents.
"It's an emotional issue," she said. "It's not an issue with a solid, rational foundation. Denying immigrants licenses won't make our world safer."
While Connecticut might have become strict in issuing licenses, North Carolina and Tennessee are anything but. Proving legal status in the United States is not necessary, and immigrants, both legal or illegal, are able to get driver's licenses if they can prove residency in those states.
Despite criticism from other states, including Florida and South Carolina, of North Carolina's liberal rules, Wayne J. Hurder, its director of driver's license certification, is firm in his conviction that even illegal immigrants should be able to get licenses from the states where they live.
"The reality is that there are a lot of immigrants and half of them are undocumented," Mr. Hurder said. "If they are going to drive, I would argue it's better for them to buy insurance and follow the rules of the road.
"Historically, possessing a North Carolina license means you can drive safely on our roads, period," Mr. Hurder added. "Our mission is to improve highway safety."
Arguing that allowing illegal immigrants to get licenses and thus enabling them to buy car insurance keeps insurance costs down, Mr. Hurder proudly pointed out that North Carolina has one of the lowest rate uninsured motorists -- 6 percent -- in the United States.
Some legal scholars question the wisdom of using the driver's license as a national identification card at airports, banks and many other places, a practice that became common in this country about three decades ago.
"The problem with using driver's licenses as national I.D. cards is that there is no national standard," said David A. Harris, a law professor at University of Toledo and expert on traffic laws. "That's a very inconsistent way to run an I.D. system."
The American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators, which represents the state agencies that issue licenses, is urging Congress to issue uniform rules regarding granting licenses to illegal immigrants instead of leaving it to each state.
"Motor vehicle agencies are not in the immigration business," said Jason King, its spokesman. "The immigration issue is larger than the motor vehicle agencies."

HEADLINE: All Ideas Are Local. Spirited Debates May Soon Follow. 

BYLINE:  By ALAN BISBORT

 BODY:
THE day after the war with Iraq began, a group of Nobel Peace Prize winners gathered at the Bushnell Theater in Hartford to take part in a public dialogue. Call it perfect timing or simply a fortuitous encounter, the event -- presented by the Connecticut Forum -- turned out to be a welcome haven for all involved, including the man who helped plan it. 
 Opening the proceedings, Richard Sugarman, who, with his wife, Doris, founded the Connecticut Forum more than 10 years ago, said: "I can't think of a place I'd rather be than right here with you tonight. Although it's difficult to stand up here with the war having started, it could not be more important than for us to do what we do, which is to come together and consider ideas." 
The ideas considered as part of this particular event, called "A Nobel Evening," were, as they are at all forum events, intimate and unrehearsed, like a giant dinner party where the conversation is dominated by fascinating guests. The guests this night were Jody Williams, founder of the International Campaign to Ban Landmines and 1997 Nobel laureate; Elie Wiesel, Holocaust "witness," as he calls himself, author, and 1986 Nobel laureate; and Oscar Arias, former president of Costa Rica and 1987 Nobel laureate. Prodded by the moderator Juan Williams, the three expressed conflicting and conflicted feelings about the war that seemed to mirror the sentiments of the full house. There was sadness, anger and, even among these peace activists, one supporter of the war (Mr. Wiesel). There were raucous cheers, horrified gasps, laughter and a few tears. At the end, there were questions from the audience and answers that pleased some and riled others.
In short, it was a typical event for the Connecticut Forum, which has presented four such evenings a year since 1992. Among the forum's stated mission is to encourage the free and active exchange of ideas and to inform, challenge, entertain, inspire and build bridges between people and organizations in the community. Its goals extend beyond the Bushnell stage, through the Forum Community Institute, which is host to monthly Youth Forums and student exchanges involving 40 diverse high schools and distributes topical discussion guides to communities around the state.
But the Bushnell evenings are the forum's marquee event. Each, like "A Nobel Evening," is built around a theme, among which have been "Straight Talk and Honest Answers about AIDS," "Being Black," and "Cruelty, Violence and Morality." More than 230 panelists have participated, including Phil Donahue, Henry Kissinger, Gloria Steinem, Michael Moore, Spike Lee, Anita Hill, Al Franken, Walter Cronkite, Toni Morrison, Frank McCourt, Bill Cosby, Katherine Graham and Norman Schwarzkopf.
But provocation is not the only criterion. 
"A good season is one that balances tough, underreported topics with entertaining programs," said Mr. Sugarman, forum president. "These are not mutually exclusive."
The idea for the forum took shape soon after the Sugarmans moved to Hartford from Richmond, Va., where Mr. Sugarman had been involved in the community mental health field, and Mrs. Sugarman was an accountant. Mr. Sugarman's career change -- to the investment banking field -- brought the couple and their children to Hartford, where they sensed a need for connection among residents as great as their own. 
"There was a sense of disconnect," said Mrs. Sugarman, forum executive director. "Towns are spread out all over the area and the economy was pretty dire around here then. We were new, probably naive in a lot of ways, but people had this hunger, if only someone would initiate this idea."
"We were bothered by how we get information and news, so much of which is spin and is communicated at such a low level," said Mr. Sugarman. "We're talked down to and not respected. People deserve more. So, we sat down with a half-dozen people at dinner, then at the office, and asked everyone if they thought a forum was a good idea. 'Of course,' they said 'Yes.' They might have thought we were crazy, but they kept it to themselves."
Borrowing a cubicle at Mr. Sugarman's office, the Sugarmans began planning their first season of forum evenings with the help of volunteers. The first event, "The Changing Political Landscape," took place Oct. 16, 1992, featuring Ron Brown, Pat Buchanan and Lesley Stahl. 
The response was enthusiastic and the nonprofit forum, then run voluntarily by the Sugarmans, moved into an office above a food court and then into a larger space that is now a restaurant. 
"Only in Year 4, did we hire a staff," said Mr. Sugarman
The forum is now housed in a bank building a block from the Old State House, has a full-time staff of nine (including the Sugarmans, who both quit their other jobs), as well as many volunteers, who help choose and coordinate events.
"All the proposed ideas derive from a volunteer Program Selection Task Group," said Mr. Sugarman. "We also distribute 3,000 ballots to Bushnell audiences and ask them to check their top four ideas. Then we sift through the picks and even with the messages from the audience we are still guided by the overriding question, 'What would make a good forum season?"' 
In the past two years, audiences have sent a message of insecurity. 
"People are not being given an opportunity to talk about their fears, and if we've done a good job of listening and planning, frequently 12 months out, what we've picked is becoming news at the time," said Mr. Sugarman. "We, of course, had no way of knowing that 'A Nobel Evening' would be this timely."
Many other memorable evenings have resulted, said Mrs. Sugarman citing the forum on AIDS as having provided her most moving moment. 
"Arthur Ashe had originally agreed to be a panelist but was too sick to attend," she said. "He made a special tape and sent that ahead. He had died earlier that day and a lot of people at the Bushnell did not know this. We showed Arthur's tape on a big screen and announced that he'd died. There was a collective sigh. That was a special audience."
Mr. Sugarman cites the night Ralph Nader confronted Dan Quayle so aggressively that he thinks the latter ended his presidential run the next day as a result. Or the night Tom Whittaker, who had climbed Mount Everest despite his handicap, took off his prosthetic leg on stage, or the night Beverly Sills talked about the two deaf children no one knew she had, or the night Phish's Trey Anastasio, the Grateful Dead's Bob Weir and Wynton Marsalis closed a show with an improvisation. 
"When we say 'spontaneous,' we mean totally unscripted," Mr. Sugarman said. "Panelists get nothing in advance. For a handful of people we've approached that has been a problem and they've turned down the offer. Most we've contacted are intrigued. They get as tired of the scripted stuff as we do hearing it."
Kevin Phillips, political commentator and author of "Wealth and Democracy," took part in last October's forum, "Anatomy of Power," alongside Erin Brockovich, Gary Wendt and Julian Bond.
"Everyone on the panel liked the experience very much," said Mr. Phillips, who lives in Litchfield. "We were, in fact, more impressed than we expected to be. Over the years, they have come up with a polished product without giving of appearance of trying for polish. It's a unique event."
The Sugarmans are on guard against complacency.
"After 11 years, the temptation is to stop being adventurous, to go for the tried and true," said Mr. Sugarman. "We want to always be taking chances. We've never shied away from tough issues and never had a corporate sponsor influence or tell us not to take on something. You can imagine the pressure for that. Our mission drives everything we do, and that's the part that feels good to us. Even though we're not an institution, we are secure. We've created something that will last after us."
The final event in this season's Connecticut Forum is "The Forum Food Fest," on May 1. Tickets are $25, $40 or $50. Connecticut Forum season ticket pricings for next season are at three levels: $180 for the season (4 shows) in the orchestra; $140 in the mezzanine; and $80 for the balcony.
For more information, go to www.ctforum.org.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Newark Museum Says State Is Backing Out of a Deal

BYLINE:  By Ronald Smothers; Ronald Smothers reports from Newark for The New York Times.

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
One of the more striking aspects of the state's budget crisis was Governor McGreevey's proposal to slash the state's assistance to the arts. Like one of the bunker-busting bombs hitting Baghdad, the move had the predictable effect, throwing dance companies off balance and shattering the silence in libraries, symphony halls and museums.
 A vocal bunch, the cultural institutions and their network of corporate and foundation supporters shrieked until administration officials admitted a miscalculation and said they would restore half of the $18 million that had been going to the Council on the Arts while hinting that further restorations were just around the corner. 
 But missing from the administration's attempts to quiet the criticism was a promise to restore several smaller but crucial contributions. One recipient is the Newark Museum, which since 1969 has received about $2 million a year from the state, or about a third of the budget for the 94-year old institution. 
Mary Sue Sweeney Price, executive director of the museum, explained that the annual contribution dated to 1967 -- just after riots battered Newark and the city was struggling. The museum, which had been spared from the flames and the looting that devastated much of the city that summer, was faced with the loss of the city's financial support as officials sought to funnel scarce funds to the pressing business of rebuilding the city and public safety imperatives.
There are those who suggest that the museum's patrician -- and largely white -- board was quietly debating whether to flee to the suburbs like so many others, though Ms. Price dismisses those accounts. "Those were just rumors," she said. "The city and the museum have been entertwined since its creation by John Cotton Dana."
Nevertheless, city officials -- getting wind of the talk -- cut the museum out of its budget. It took the intervention of Gov. Richard Hughes, and a promise from him that the state would assume of one-third of the museum's annual operating budget to get city officials to continue their support. 
"I was there when we went to see Dick Hughes less than a year after the riots," said Kevin Shanley, the museum's board chairman and vice president and chief operating officer of Atlantic Health Systems. "The governor recognized that the city couldn't afford to carry the museum as it had been and that the state should kick in."
For the next 35 years, the state contribution to the museum acquired the validation of history -- and perhaps more importantly -- political history. It became a fixture in the budget polices of the five governors who followed Governor Hughes. Ms. Price, who has been at the museum since 1975, could recall no similar or even serious threat to that contribution -- until now.
"The understanding has always been that since the museum drew students from all parts of the state to its shows, collections and attractions, then one-third of its annual operating budget should come from the state," she said. "It was recognized that we served others as well as Newark among the 340,000 students and seniors who come here every year."
Newark is not as hard-pressed fiscally now as it was in the late 1960's though it, too, is facing serious budget problems. Still, Mayor Sharpe James has insisted that the city will not decrease its financing of the Newark Museum, and he vowed in an interview to make sure the McGreevey administration also would not.
"The lights of the theater don't dim in a depression, and every army is led into war by a marching band and its musicians," the mayor said. "We think the governor should fully fund the arts, and we are really talking about peanuts in a multibillion-dollar budget."
Mayor James -- who is also a Democratic state senator and whose vote is likely to be crucial in the evenly split Senate -- said flatly that he would not support a state budget that did not restore the money for the museum's operating budget as well as the $18 million that the Council on the Arts received last year.
Other leading Democrats like Essex County Executive Joseph DiVincenzo have been equally vehement about restoration of the arts funds.
Yet Mr. Shanley, chairman of the museum board, insisted that in the end it would be common sense and not politics that would save the museum's operating money as well as the other money for the arts.
"We are there for the public, and we do the showing up," he said. "It is disingenuous to ask, as some editorials do, whether we should feed the children or feed the arts. We do feed the children, and I just don't understand what the governor is doing. It's like cutting off your nose to spite your face."

HEADLINE: CITIES; 
Hope for East Orange

BYLINE:  By RONALD SMOTHERS 

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE 

 BODY:
STRUGGLING to revive itself after years of decline and misfortune, this tattered town in the shadow of Newark is placing a number of chips on a long shot.
 Last month, the East Orange City Council unanimously approved a developer's plan to build a 168-room Hampton Inn and Suites hard by Interstate 280 as it gouges its way through this once-elegant city of more than 69,000. The plan is to combine the inn, part of a national hotel-motel and conference-center chain, with a training school for entry-level jobs in the hospitality industry, making East Orange a testing ground for a combination of functions rarely found outside the university. 
 The residential training program would be run by the 15-year-old American Hospitality Academy, a for-profit organization based in Hilton Head, S.C. The plan for the inn and the training was put forward by the Evergreen Hotel Group, a partnership of P.J. O'Neill & Associates, a builder in Monroe Township, and the Unibuild Group, a Miami-based marketer. 
"This is a hybrid development that seeks to be a success both as a conference center and a campus for job training," said Maurice Hoo, president of Unibuild, which along with the O'Neill firm would build and operate the $18 million complex on Evergreen Place, about a half-hour from Newark Liberty International Airport.
Mr. Hoo's recent presentation at City Hall sidestepped direct mention of the challenge of building such a project here, especially as the travel and hospitality industry struggles and as business travelers become more interested in quality and dependability than in saving money. 
"I think it is a marvelous idea," said John Kasarda, a sociologist and director of the Kenan Institute of Private Enterprise at the University of North Carolina. "But there are many hurdles to such pioneering efforts. And they always say that the pioneers get the arrows while the settlers get the land."
Joseph McInerney, president and chief executive of the American Hotel and Lodging Association, a trade group, said that it was unusual to house a training center with classrooms at a functioning hotel. Chains do that sort of thing off the premises, he noted. He also said that few projects were getting financing now.
Still, Gary Carr, a spokesman for PKF Consulting, a hotel research and consulting firm, called the pairing of the hotel and training school "a creative way to finance a hotel" -- particularly when most financing is scarce.
He said that a recent study by his company found that although the supply of hotel rooms was at its lowest level in 20 years, demand was also low, a result of a flat economy and overbuilding in the late 1990's. In addition, he said the site's distance from the airport made it an unlikely choice for conferences by business people flying in.
"The hotels that are doing the best in the conference business are those located right at the airport," he said. "Plus, they have to overcome the image of the community because most business leaders tend to be risk averse and want really safe locations for their meetings."
All these hurdles have done little to diminish the enthusiasm of Mayor Robert Bowser of East Orange. To him, the interest of the developers is further proof of how far the city has come. 
Mr. Bowser attributed the interest of the Evergreen group not only to the city's proximity to the airport, but also to the fact that East Orange has increased its tax base to 94 percent of its residents from 76 percent five years ago, and last October convinced fiscal monitors from the state that after two years of supervision it was ready to oversee its own finances.
In addition, several successful land auctions recently returned seized properties to the tax rolls, and work is nearly complete on a new residential and commercial development called Dr. Martin Luther King Plaza on a downtown corner long scarred by desolation.
For the first time since 1985, , Moody's Investors Service recently gave a favorable investment-grade rating to the city's general obligation borrowings, whose repayment is pegged to local property tax collections. Though the city is still receiving supplemental state assistance under New Jersey's distressed-cities program, it is running its own operations day to day and expects to come out of the program soon.
"I know in my heart that this proposal will work," Mayor Bowser said.
He expects the lodging to attract conference business and church, social and civic groups to use the banquet and meeting rooms. "These groups are always complaining about having to go to airport hotels for their events or to Newark hotels," he said. "They want to stay here for their functions, and this will allow them to do that."
For now, Mr. Hoo conceded that heand his partners were only in the early stages of discussions with the Hilton Corporation, which owns the Hampton Inn chain and operates it as mid-price, low-service accommodations. Kendra Clark, a spokesman for Hilton, confirmed that it was "premature" to comment on the negotiations.
Cindy Reiman, president and chief executive of the American Hospitality Academy, said that she was excited about the prospect of its first resident teaching center. In the past, she said, the group has run training programs for about 60 chains off premises and has supervised management trainees who work as interns."To our knowledge, there is no other training operation like the one proposed for entry-level workers," she said. "What is critical and often overlooked at this level is the importance of building customer service skills, an attitude geared to customer service."
Perhaps the closest thing to what is being proposed for East Orange is the Opportunities Inn in Philadelphia, where the nonprofit Opportunities Industrial Corporation trains local residents in classrooms, mock hotel rooms, kitchens and banquet areas.
Gregory DeShields, a former director of that program who is associate director for industry relations at Temple University's school of tourism, said that the group had tried to create a resident program but that melding it successfully with a profit-making business had proved to be a problem.
Still, Mr. DeShields said that the proposed Hampton Inn and training center would provide a good setting for building a "team concept" among hotel staff workers.
"People might actually get better service in a training setting because there will be a safety net to prevent problems," he said. "Plus, there is a reason that trainees wear badges telling everyone that they are trainees. It sensitizes customers psychologically that it is a learning situation, and they tend to be more forgiving."
Mayor Bowser hopes residents will take advantage of the training to be offered. And he likes the idea of bringing new jobs to the city through a project that is not seeking a tax abatement.
"This sort of development couldn't have happened four years ago," the mayor said, referring to the city's faction-ridden politics of that time, its anti-development ethos and its finances and physical condition. "With this and other things that are happening, I think business will see us as stable and cooperative."

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE; 
Without Health Insurance, Stark Choices

BYLINE:  By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: OSSINING 

 BODY:
AS soon as Dr. Patricia Meyer examined the patient who walked into her office, she suspected he had cancer. The man had inflamed lymph nodes and Dr. Meyer wanted to order a number of tests, including a CAT scan of the man's lungs. But such diagnostic procedures are expensive and, like many of the patients who walk into the Open Door Family Health Center here, the man had no health insurance. Thus began the scramble that is all too familiar for medical professionals trying to care for those without insurance.
 "It's really rough, and you have to be fairly creative to advocate for your patients," said Dr. Meyer, a family practitioner and staff physician at 
 Open Door. "Here you suspect this cancer and they have no way to pay for the tests. They can apply for emergency Medicaid, but they have to wait for up to a month for approval. If you have cancer, imagine the anguish."
Dr. Meyer said the man was lucky -- she used the word with a sense of irony -- becausehe developed trouble breathing and was admitted to the hospital through the emergency room. Once hospitalized, his care was covered by Medicaid. 
Another patient, an elderly man with diabetes, could not afford his prescription medication. Dr. Meyer tried to enroll him in studies, passed along pharmaceutical samples and tried to get specialists to see him at a reduced fee. 
"Recently it got worse and he was going into renal failure, and I had to tell him there's nothing I can do for you until your kidneys fail, and then we'll get you into emergency Medicaid," she recounted.
Advocates for the uninsured have recently been trying to call attention to the increasing numbers of people without medical benefits. There is even a designated "Cover the Uninsured Week," which was marked locally by town meetings and forums in White Plains and Ossining. 
"As a society we really don't think it's acceptable for people to die on the street, but we just have to make sure they are really, really sick before we scoop them up and save them," said Georgeanne Chapin, president and chief executive officer of HealthSource/Hudson Health Plan, a nonprofit health services plan based in Tarrytown. "The true costs of not covering people are mammoth."
Nationally, 41.2 million Americans lack health insurance, according to a report released by the Census Bureau this year. In New York, the percentage of those without coverage is almost 16 percent, higher than the national average of 14.6 percent. Regional numbers are harder to come by. A rate of 15 percent would put the number of Westchester residents lacking coverage at about 150,000 people. But those who serve uninsured patients say that number is a conservative estimate.
"In light of the fact that we have undocumented people in our county, and we think there are big numbers in some communities, and certainly in light of the depressed economy, we think the numbers of the uninsured are something like 17 or 18 percent," said Lindsay Farrell, president and chief executive officer of Open Door, with offices in Ossining, Sleepy Hollow and Rye Brook. Ms. Farrell said that 45 percent of the patients who visit the center have no insurance.
The great majority of the uninsured -- 80 percent -- are members of working families, according to the census. Many lack coverage because they are in low-paying jobs that do not offer health benefits. Ms. Farrell said that her center treated a large Latino population, who work at jobs like mowing lawns, cleaning houses and babysitting, few of which offer health coverage. She also sees a number of self-employed people who can't afford to buy insurance, as well as people who are offered coverage from their employers but who can't afford the payroll deduction, so they opt out. With the economy faltering, a growing number of professionals are also without health insurance.
"The employer-based system is not adequate for the kind of society we live in, which more and more, has people not working, people who don't stay at the same jobs, companies that don't last that long, companies that themselves change insurers, and insurers that go out of business," Ms. Chapin said. "To continue to tie insurance to employment is really just not in keeping with the times we're living in."
Health insurance coverage has long been a patchwork system in this country. Most Americans do get their insurance through their employer, or through their spouse's or parent's employer. Individual coverage is available, though it is very expensive. The government also provides insurance coverage for the poor through Medicaid; for some moderate-income families through Child Health Plus and Family Health Plus, and for the elderly through Medicare.
Child Health Plus offers free coverage to children whose families have incomes above the Medicaid cutoff and do not have private insurance, as well as children who are undocumented residents. Family Health Plus covers adults who do not have health insurance through their employers, yet whose incomes fall slightly above the Medicaid cutoff. 
But the paperwork for applying for these programs can be daunting. Ms. Chapin said that more than 20,000 children in Westchester who were eligible for health insurance lacked it, in part because of the red tape involved in registering for the programs. She added that the bureaucracy requiring yearly recertification for those who do sign up is so complex that HealthSource/Hudson Health Plan lost between 4 and 5 percent of its enrollment in Medicaid, Child Health Plus and Family Health Plus each month.
Ms. Farrell said society was already paying to care for the uninsured. The cost of that care -- which is often expensive emergency care -- is passed along through high insurance premiums, high administrative costs and high doctor's fees.
"As a nation we long ago made the decision to subsidize health care for elderly people and for our poorest citizens," Ms. Chapin said. "It is time to do the same for all people who cannot afford to buy health insurance."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dr. Patricia Meyer, a family practitioner, examines a patient, Reyna Sevilla, at the Open Door Medical Center in Ossining. (Susan Stava for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Personal Business: Executive Pay; 
Have a Specialty? The Job Hunt May Be Short

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS 

 BODY:
THE weak economy and the uncertainty surrounding the war in Iraq are causing more companies to retrench, which means fewer job opportunities for many executives. It now takes an executive six months, on average, to find another position, compared with 4.5 months last year, according to Ira T. Kay, the director of the compensation practice at the consulting firm Watson Wyatt Worldwide.
 And last week, the government reported that companies eliminated 108,000 jobs in March following big cuts the month before, though the unemployment rate held steady at 5.8 percent. 
 Some occupations and industries, however, are faring well -- and still paying well. Chief financial officers and finance executives in general are in strong demand in several industries, career experts say, and many companies in the energy and health care sectors are hiring more people than they did last year. 
Todd E. Noah, a principal of RK Executive Search in Roseland, N.J., says he receives calls almost daily from hedge funds, in particular, looking for chief financial officers.
"The really good C.F.O.'s aren't looking for jobs right now," Mr. Noah said. "All they hear about is how poor the economy is, so they're wary about making a change."
But Charles G. Tharp, a professor of human resource management at Rutgers University, noted that companies of all sizes are under pressure these days to keep costs down and "are willing to pay top dollar for the right person" to help accomplish that. 
"The C.F.O. is quickly becoming the second-highest-paid person" in a company, behind the chief executive, Dr. Tharp said, with salaries of $500,000 or more not uncommon.
Last year, the median total cash compensation for chief financial officers across all industries was $347,200, up slightly from $345,600 in 2001, according to a 2003 compensation survey conducted by Mercer Human Resource Consulting. 
Demand for accounting and finance professionals is expected to be strongest in the manufacturing and health care sectors this year, according to Robert Half International, a company that specializes in supplying staff members for finance and technology companies.
Katherine E. Simmons, the president and chief operating officer of Netshare, an executive job search firm in Novato, Calif., says she has noticed an increase in job listings for high-level finance workers in hospitals. The hospitals "are scrambling to cut costs like never before," she said, adding that a skilled chief financial officer "can almost name his price."
Anthony E. Altig, 47, who was a chief financial officer at an Internet portal company in San Francisco, found that his skills were in demand when he moved to San Diego last August to be closer to his family. Mr. Altig said he had not even started his job search when he received a telephone call from a friend who had worked for Maxim Pharmaceuticals and encouraged him to apply for the vacant position of chief financial officer there. After two rounds of interviews, he said, he was hired in October, and at a salary that was commensurate with that of his previous job.
Was he surprised to have landed a new position so quickly? Not really. "Truthfully," he said, "I was more interested in finding the right job than finding a job." 
Many executives in the energy industry are also finding that jobs are plentiful, especially for those who have a background in petroleum engineering or geology. Because fewer college students are majoring in those areas these days, the industry is reaching "a crisis point for top talent," said David E. Preng, the president of Preng & Associates, an executive search firm in Houston that focuses on the energy industry.
Mr. Preng said that it was difficult to recruit managers from other industries. "It's not like we can pull someone out of Procter & Gamble to run Shell Oil," he said. "We pretty much have to rely on home-grown talent." 
Mr. Preng says executives with law degrees and international business experience are also considered ideal candidates. 
Over all, pay in the energy industry was expected to climb 4.1 percent this year, according to Mercer Human Resource Consulting.
The median salary for petroleum engineers is now $78,910, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, but pay is substantially higher for those at management levels. In the past two years alone, Mr. Preng said that he has placed several people in senior-level positions at major oil companies, with annual salaries of $600,000 to $2 million.
There are also pockets of opportunity for executives in technology, career experts say. The biggest growth in salaries, and in demand for technology executives, can be found in military-related businesses, as well as in the medical, financial services and pharmaceutical sectors, according to Scot W. Melland, the chief executive of Dice Inc., an online job board.
The median total cash compensation for chief information officers across all industries was $274,700 in 2002, up from $264,000 in 2001. Chief information officers in health care earned median salaries and bonuses of $298,600 in 2002, up from $218,800 the previous year, according to Mercer.
Mary Finlay, deputy chief information officer at Partners HealthCare System, a group of hospitals in Boston with more than 30,000 employees, says her organization is still hiring health care information technology executives, although competition has softened of late. Two years ago, Ms. Finlay said, she was forced into bidding wars with financial services companies for qualified candidates. Now, she says, Partners HealthCare can be a little pickier, focusing more on candidates with solid project management experience, particularly in the areas of patient safety, disaster preparedness and system integration.
She said the company was no longer offering sign-on bonuses and other perks, although salaries have remained stable.
MANY health sciences companies are also hiring, especially those specializing in medical equipment and devices and, to a lesser degree, certain biotechnology companies, experts say. Executive pay in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology fields was expected to increase 4.1 percent this year, according to the Mercer study. 
Some experts are predicting even bigger increases in the future. John A. Challenger, the chief executive of Challenger Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm based in Chicago, predicted that as the population ages, companies will continue to invest in product development. The health sciences, he said, will be the main engine of the next period of economic expansion.
"Lots of companies are going to put money into the game, and there's going to be a need for talented executives," he said.
Demand for personnel executives is also rising. Dr. Tharp, the Rutgers professor, said that was partly because companies are developing more sophisticated executive pay plans and have had to manage costs of pension plans more closely and focus on corporate governance issues. Many companies are also hiring so-called chief learning officers, or chief knowledge officers, to help with corporate training. 
Pay for the top personnel job at many companies, according to Dr. Tharp, can reach $300,000 to $400,000, not including stock options and other incentives. 
So how do executives latch onto these high-paying growth areas? Career experts advise professionals to pick a specialty and try to stick with it.
"Some young executives think they need to diversify themselves, so they've got all of these different jobs that don't relate to one another," said Raymond M. Desrochers, the president of Technology Business Advisors, a management consulting firm based in Westford, Mass. "Employers in these fields are being really specific -- looking for candidates that match the job description exactly."
Career experts also caution job seekers to be realistic. Mr. Noah, at RK Executive Search, said he sometimes had to remind candidates in the finance arena, for example, that job offers were no longer likely to be accompanied by sign-on bonuses or company cars. "It used to be that C.F.O.'s would get all of these fringes," he said. "The salaries are good, but some of the other things have gone away. In this economy, I tell people they should just be happy to receive a really nice paycheck."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Tech and Health Care Shares Become Silk Purses

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
THE relatively few stock funds that eked out small gains in a generally money-losing first quarter tended to own health care and technology stocks. Managers of some of the top-performing stock funds talked about the quarter and what they saw for the stock market this year.

Quality Trades
 TCW Galileo Select Equities, with $1.4 billion in assets, was up 4.5 percent in the quarter, taking seventh place among domestic diversified equity funds. 
 Glen E. Bickerstaff, 46, the manager, buys what he calls "long-term, very high-quality businesses with sustainable competitive advantages in their business models." These are the types of companies that investors have been seeking lately, he said.
"In the second half of 2002, selling stocks became, in our opinion, indiscriminate," he said. "Shareholders were selling stocks without regard to their fundamentals."
As a result, he said, valuations dropped to attractive levels. "When investors saw some signs of an economic recovery earlier this year," he said, "they gravitated to high-quality businesses because that's where their confidence was the strongest."
One of the fund's biggest winners was Amazon.com, the online retailer, whose stock rose 37.8 percent in the quarter. "We witnessed in the fourth-quarter holiday season revenues that exceeded investors' expectations," Mr. Bickerstaff said. "We interpret that as indicating that adoption of buying online reached critical mass, and investors are looking for strong results going forward."
Another winner was the Progressive Corporation, the property-casualty insurer. Its shares rose 19.5 percent because of rapid revenue growth and a reduced cost structure, he said. "The company has strong competitive offerings and has been focusing on cutting costs," he said, "particularly in adjusting claims."
Another winner was MedImmune, a biotechnology company in Gaithersburg, Md., whose stock rose 21.3 percent in the quarter, helped by the company's introduction this year of a product called FluMist. "Most flu shots are done through injections," Mr. Bickerstaff said. "An inhaled version is more pleasant."
He calls himself cautiously optimistic, given the economy's resilience. "After the declines of the last few years, stock valuations today reflect the growth potential of a stronger economy," he said.

Star Techies
Baron iOpportunity, a $67 million fund, rose 4.3 percent in the quarter, driven by technology stocks. The fund ranked ninth among diversified domestic stock funds.
The fund focuses on "companies whose future profitability is driven by changes created by the Internet and information technology," said Mitchell Rubin, 36, the fund's manager.
These include new Internet-based companies, older companies moving to an Internet-based business model and service providers to technology companies, he said.
Mr. Rubin generally avoids what he calls "hard-core software and hardware companies." They are typically more volatile because they tend to focus on just one technology, he said.
Technology companies performed strongly, Mr. Rubin said, because "investors looking for profitable businesses and who had ignored the tech-bubble stocks took a second look."
Expedia, the Internet travel agent based in Bellevue, Wash., was one of the fund's biggest winners, up 54.4 percent. The stock price was driven by strong fourth-quarter growth in revenue and profit, he said, and projections of continued growth in 2003. The company and its majority owner, USA Interactive, announced last month that USA would acquire the Expedia shares that it did not already own in a stock transaction valued at $3.3 billion. It is generally tax-free to Expedia shareholders. 
Mr. Rubin made money -- as did Mr. Bickerstaff and Mr. Hyan -- in eBay, the Internet reseller, up 25.8 percent. EBay is the "extraordinary company of our generation," Mr. Rubin said, "and all without significant asset investment, so its profit margins are superhigh, and it has no competition."
The difficult economic environment last year helped accelerate eBay's revenue, he said, projecting that revenue growth should exceed 60 percent this year.
Another winning holding was CheckFree, in Norcross, Ga. Shares of the company, which provides financial electronic commerce products and services, rose 40.5 percent in the quarter. It has benefited as people continue to shift from checkbooks to electronic bill payment, Mr. Rubin said.
Looking ahead, he said, "We think the market unfortunately is driven more by global events than company fundamentals." Because valuations are down, he added, the stock market is positioned for a big rebound when the economy stabilizes.

A Focus on Growth
Spectra, a $220.9 million fund, took 14th place among diversified domestic stock funds with a return of 3.6 percent. It credits its technology and health care stocks. 
The fund buys companies of any size that are experiencing positive changes from new product cycles, gains in market share or expanding markets, said David Hyan, the manager. He also manages two other funds in exactly the same style: the $106.8 million IDEX Alger Aggressive Growth fund, which rose 3.3 percent, and the $559.2 million Alger Capital Appreciation fund, up 3.4 percent.
Spectra's biggest stakes are in health care, at 36 percent of the fund's assets; technology, 25 percent; and retail and similar consumer stocks, 18 percent.
One winning health care stock was Amgen, the biotechnology company in Thousand Oaks, Calif., which rose 19.1 percent. Last year, Amgen introduced second-generation versions of two popular drugs, Epogen, used for treating chronic kidney failure, and Neupogen, for cancer. The new versions created accelerating sales growth rates for both drugs and helped Amgen expand into new markets, Mr. Hyan said.
Another winner was Forest Laboratories, in New York. Its shares rose 9.9 percent in the quarter, driven by a second generation of its antidepressant Celexa. The new drug, Lexapro, was introduced in 2002 and the two drugs combined account for 25 percent of the market for new antidepressant prescriptions, Mr. Hyan said.
Among specialty retailers, his biggest winner was Abercrombie & Fitch, up 46.8 percent. Its sales at stores open at least a year were down the last two years, Mr. Hyan said, partly because "three years ago, it was the hot brand to own, and there was oversaturation." But a rebound in popularity, good inventory control and a fast-growing new line called Hollister, for young teenagers, created positive sales growth in the quarter, he said.
Stocks seem to be in a short-term holding pattern, Mr. Hyan said. "The market is clearly focused on the war now, and business in general is on hold because of the war," he said, "so it's difficult to look ahead."

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Are Rates Aligned in Mortgage Bonds' Favor?

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
THE last year has been a good time for consumers to refinance their mortgages, with interest rates hitting their lowest levels in decades. And it has also been a popular time to invest in mutual funds that buy bonds backed by home mortgages. 
 For people still wary of stocks, the $4 trillion mortgage bond market is attractive, said Jeffrey Gundlach, whose firm, the Trust Company of the West in Los Angeles, is one of the largest investors in mortgage debt. 
 "When interest rates are stable or rising, the mortgage market outperforms other parts of the bond market," he said, and many bond market strategists predict that will be the course of interest rates from here. That would mean lower or negative returns for investors in any variety of bonds, from corporate debt to Treasuries. 
Mr. Gundlach runs the $212 million TCW Galileo Total Return Bond fund and manages $32 billion in mortgage bonds for pension funds and other private investors.
Mortgage bond mutual funds had $83.6 billion in assets as of the end of February, according to Morningstar Inc. More than a third of that, almost $29 billion, was in the Vanguard GNMA fund.
Most mortgage debt is guaranteed by three enterprises that are owned or sponsored by the government: the Government National Mortgage Association, known as Ginnie Mae; Fannie Mae, formerly the Federal National Mortgage Association; and Freddie Mac, formerly the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
They bundle home mortgages they buy from banks and sell bonds backed by clusters of these mortgages to investors. That makes mortgage bonds more complicated than Treasury bonds.
"There is a lingering aura of mystery surrounding the mortgage market," Mr. Gundlach said. "Many investors think the market is incomprehensible."
Investors in these bonds need to calculate what mortgage specialists call prepayment risk, or the odds that a percentage of holders of the underlying mortgages will repay or refinance their debt before it is due.
IT is difficult for individual investors to estimate prepayments, but professionals like Mr. Gundlach construct statistical models for this purpose. Because of the uncertainty of prepayment risk, mortgage-backed securities, on average, yield one or two percentage points more than Treasuries.
When interest rates are falling, mortgage bond returns lag slightly behind Treasuries because so many consumers are paying off their home loans. Mortgage bonds returned 7.19 percent annualized over the last five years through March, slightly behind the 7.64 percent return on Treasury bonds, according to indexes kept by Lehman Brothers.
But when interest rates are stable or rising, fewer consumers pay off their mortgages early. Mr. Gundlach estimates that a record $500 billion in mortgages will be repaid or refinanced in the next three months. But after that, he said, refinancings will decline gradually, which is good for investors in mortgage debt.
"As investors, we want homeowners to pay the highest rates," Mr. Gundlach said.
Between March 10 and March 21, when investors thought the war would end quickly, stocks rallied and Treasury bonds dropped 2.6 percent. But mortgage bonds fell just 0.8 percent during the same period.
Mortgage bond investors fare poorly when rates rise rapidly, because they prefer a certain amount of cash coming in from refinancings.
But the current environment of stable to slowly rising interest rates is ideal, said Kenneth Hackel, chief United States bond strategist at Merrill Lynch. He recommends that Merrill clients put 36 percent of their bond portfolios in mortgage debt.
"Rates are unlikely to go up enough in the short term to hurt mortgage bond returns," he said.
The TCW fund largely avoids debt backed by the 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages favored by most home buyers. The long period before this debt comes due makes it difficult to predict when the debt will be repaid.
Mr. Gundlach prefers bonds for which repayment is easier to anticipate. Close to one-third of his fund is invested in adjustable-rate mortgages, which have a fixed interest rate for 1 to 10 years and then switch to a variable rate.
Because these bonds have a shorter maturity, it is easier to calculate when they will be repaid, Mr. Gundlach said.
Forty percent of the fund is invested in collateralized mortgage obligations, or C.M.O.'s. These are pools of mortgages sold by investment banks to money managers and other private investors. 
The marketers of these pools sell off streams of interest and principal payments to investors. The TCW fund typically buys the portion of a C.M.O. that is the last to be repaid, typically not before 5 to 15 years, Mr. Gundlach said.
Most mortgage bond funds avoid C.M.O.'s because they trade infrequently. "The TCW fund does buy some esoteric securities," said Eric Jacobson, an analyst at Morningstar, adding that such securities tend to yield more because they are less understood.
The TCW fund has returned 1 percent this year through March, compared with 0.74 percent for the average mortgage bond fund, according to Morningstar.
It has had a five-year annualized return of 8 percent through March, compared with 6.29 percent for the average mortgage bond fund. 
Mr. Jacobson favors the TCW fund for another reason: on March 1, the fund cut its expense ratio to 0.44 percent from 0.69 percent and the minimum initial investment to $2,000 from $25,000.
"It's really unusual in an environment like this for a mutual fund to cut its fees," Mr. Jacobson said.

HEADLINE: His Mission: Finding Why People Fight 

BYLINE:  By LISA SUHAY 

DATELINE: WEST LONG BRANCH 

 BODY:
SALIBA SARSAR, who grew up a non-Arab Jordanian in Jerusalem with a personal history at least as complex as that of the Middle East, might easily have followed his childhood friends into a life of hatred and conflict. Instead, as he works academic turf here in suburban New Jersey, his thinking is drawing crowds.
 He was born of a Russian father and a Greek mother in 1955 in the Old City of Jerusalem, which was then a part of Jordan. After the Six Day War of 1967, he was separated briefly from his family and watched the reshaping of Israel. But in a major turning point in 1974, he was one of several Middle Eastern youths brought to New Jersey as part of an effort to foster peace and crosscultural understanding. 
 Now he says he is doing his early sponsors proud by advocating peaceful conflict resolution. 
On Thursday, he and a colleague, Dr. Joseph Patten, are to lead a discussion at a showing of the award-winning film "Kandahar" at the Monmouth University Global Understanding Convention. And last month, Dr. Sarsar presented his roadmap to peace at a three-man panel discussion at Brookdale Community College in Lincroft.
That discussion -- "Conflict Resolution in the Middle East: Is It Possible?" -- was open to the public and drew 350 people, ranging from high school students to the elderly. 
Dr. Sarsar, 48, represented Monmouth University, where he is an associate professor of political science and an associate vice president for academic program initiatives. At Monmouth he has taught comparative politics, Islam and politics, American foreign policy and international relations for 18 years.
His says there can be peace between Palestinians and Israelis if a demilitarized, neutral Palestinian state is created immediately, not in 2005 as President Bush advocates. Last month, Mr. Bush reiterated his support for adoption of a Palestinian state.
Paul Zigo, an organizer of the panel discussion, said of Dr. Sarsar's presentation: "He gave a very common-sensical explanation of the socio-economic impact of terrorism on the common people in the Middle East, not the warriors' or the politicians' views so commonly expressed."
The moderator, Prof. Sherri West of Brookdale, said his presentation prompted the most questions from the audience. "My students came to me in class the next day and said he was the speaker they found the most engaging," she said. 
A fellow panelist found him and his approach unorthodox.
"He was remarkably pleasant," said Richard Immerman, chairman of the Department of History at Temple University in Pennsylvania. "It was somewhat out of step with what I am used to seeing in scholarly behavior. We in academia are cordial, respectful with one another, but that is all. He didn't fit the mold." 
On Dr. Sarsar's political views, Dr. Immerman said: "He is more optimistic on this topic, which is not a quality of most scholars. We tend to be cynics. I tend to study conflict, not its avoidance. It made me want to read more of his work."
Prof. Michael Doran of Princeton University was the third panelist.
Dr. Sarsar does have his detractors.
"He doesn't see the danger the Palestinians represent to the Jewish people," said a former colleague, Marvin Maurer, who retired in 2000 after 30 years as a professor of political science at Monmouth University. 
"He thinks there should be a Palestinian state," Professor Maurer said by telephone from his home in Toronto. "I strongly disagree. There could be some kind of home rule, but definitely not a separate state. I know people in the Jewish community around the university who strongly disagree with Sarsar on this."
Asked about such detractors, Dr. Sarsar said: "I wish I could speak with them. We must continue to try and find common ground in these issues. If we are to succeed we must have dialogue between peoples." 
Dr. Sarsar, a slightly built, balding man who is exceptionally soft-spoken, says he has had complete freedom, without intervention from the university, to teach his theories at Monmouth, here in West Long Branch. But he tells a chilling tale about calls from United States government agents at the time of the first Gulf War, in 1991.
A number of times, he said, he expressed his theories of why Saddam Hussein had taken certain military actions and told his classes what moves he expected Iraq to make.
"No sooner than I returned to my office I received a telephone call from a government agent insisting on knowing how I had known these things," Dr. Sarsar said. "Apparently there were students in my classes who were actually working with or for the government or knew someone in this branch of intelligence and they were reporting my teachings regularly."
Dr. Sarsar said these incidents did influence him to curb his tongue for the duration of that semester. He said he had never again experienced anything like that and has not held back this semester.
Dr. Sarsar lives with his wife, Hiyam, and daughters, NoorEvelyn, 6, and Hania, 4, in Tinton Falls, in a blue and white ranch home decorated with abstract art.
He seemed to hold back little as he sat for an interview at the All Seasons Diner in Eatontown on a recent Sunday afternoon after attending services at St. George Greek Orthodox Church in Asbury Park. 
Dr. Sarsar said his father was born in Russia as Ivan Danilov and was taken as an infant to Jerusalem because his mother feared that her husband's blood connection to the czars endangered their lives in Russia. After a short time, she died of an illness in Jerusalem when her son, Ivan, was only 3. He was then adopted by a Palestinian.
"The woman I call my grandmother was a Christian Palestinian who attended the same church as my Danilov grandmother," Dr. Sarsar said. "She adopted my father and renamed him George Sarsar. My father, the Russian Ivan Danilov, became the Palestinian George Sarsar by adoption."
"People like things to be simple, but in the Middle East, especially Jerusalem, nothing is simple," he said. "I was born in a Protestant hospital on the Mount of Olives. I am Greek Orthodox. I go to church. I was raised in the Old City in an Arab culture, speak Arabic but have no Arab blood."
He added, with a smile, "I live between two worlds."
Though he was only a child at the time, he recalls the aftermath of the 1967 war, when, he says, Israel was in effect "created around us in six days like a hurricane."
Many of the people who were his childhood friends in Jerusalem ended in prison or dead. "I think education made the difference for me," he said.
His father, George Sarsar, was a printer who ran a hand-driven press. His mother was a homemaker. Electricity did not come to their quarter until the early 1960's. A tiny garden, behind a row of attached dwellings, plus large olive and pomegranate trees, supplied most of the family's nourishment.
"The flowers of the Bible grew there: jasmine, rosemary. It was like heaven," he said.
Such recollections have inspired two books of poetry. He has just completed his second, "Seven Gates." The first, "Cross Winds" (Edwin Mellen Press, 1999), derives its name from his own. (In Arabic, "saliba" means "cross." A sarsar is a powerful desert wind.)
He spends his spare time writing poetry, playing with his children and listening to classical music. "I've always had a soft spot for Beethoven and Mozart," he said, adding that he once visited the home of Beethoven in Bonn "to touch where genius walked" and bought a bust of the master that he keeps on his desk at home. 
Dr. Sarsar was the sixth of eight children -- three girls and five boys. One sister still lives as a nun in the Old City of Jerusalem. Another sister moved to Honduras, shortly before the Six-Day War. The other siblings are in the United States. His father, now 90, and mother, 79, still live in the family home in Abu-Tor, a 10-minute walk from the Jaffa Gate in the Old City. 
After the Six-Day War he and his older brother were separated from the rest of the family by military officials and sent to a refugee camp in Jericho. His parents, grandparents and other siblings were sent to a camp in the south of Jerusalem.
"I was 11 then, and for two weeks my brother and I were in the refugee camp and didn't know if we would ever see the others again," he explained. "A boy I played with three houses down was killed. Many of my neighbors also died."
Instead of taking up arms, he made education his life. "I wanted to learn why people aggress against each other," he said. "I needed to understand. I needed to stop it."
After coming to New Jersey he began attending Brookdale and then moved on to study at Monmouth on scholarship, earning a bachelor's degree in political science. He completed a doctorate at Rutgers and began his teaching career there when one of his professors was awarded a Fulbright and needed someone to take over his courses.
"That experience really launched me," he said. "I never had to look for a job. The next year a teaching position came up at Monmouth and I have remained there for 18 years."
His current students sometimes agree with him, sometimes not. 
Lindsay Currie, 19, of Long Branch, says Dr. Sarsar has made her strong dissent from his views on Saddam Hussein and the war with Iraq a part of lessons in the class on Islam and politics.
"We both agree Saddam needs to be gone, but he wants it to happen in a more humanitarian way and I want it quicker," she said. "We spend most of each three-hour class discussing our views on the day's news and there is plenty of room for argument. That's something I like."
Greg Muszynski, 22, added: "He lets everyone get their say and then gives his opinion. Compared to other classes I really learn a lot in his discussions. I don't know why exactly. I just seem to absorb better when he talks. Maybe it's all the discussion and open debate? Maybe he's just a really good teacher."
The professor's skills in the face of conflict are appreciated on the domestic front, too. "Saliba is a true peace maker," said his wife, 40. "Even in daily life, if people we know have personal conflict they often come to him to be the mediator. He just has a very calming way about him, and with this he often helps others to be peaceful."
Dr. Sarsar, who became an American citizen in 2000, says that through teaching he is slowly accomplishing his goal of uniting his worlds in peace and mutual respect. He gives much credit to the Rev. John S. Grauel, a Methodist minister who was responsible for bringing him to the United States and was an activist for the Jewish people and Israel for decades before his death in 1986.
Dr. Sarsar says others helped him, too, including about 30 families in Monmouth County.
"In my work at Monmouth I want to bring about this richness of ethnic diversity that colored my life," Dr. Sarsar said. "I want to show my students those colors. Ultimately it is their decision to partake."

In God's Name
In God's Name
The sun appears 
from behind the rainbow, to dry 
the blood from hearts wasted on
stones wrapped in colorful flags,
moss growing in cracks and veins
on arms and hands that maim,
killing in the name of God, 
of prophets long gone, 
of profits to be made past
prayers of the day, 
the smiling face 
of the moon.
By Saliba Sarsar
