HEADLINE: Fighting Off the Chains 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN WARNER 

DATELINE: MOUNT LAUREL 

 BODY:
NELSON PAGE made his theatrical debut in 1979 when he maxed out his credit cards, borrowed from banks and his partners and sank an inheritance into a lease on the Cedar Lane Theater in Teaneck. Over the next five years, he built a chain of 10 independent theaters throughout the state.
 But there would be no happy ending. Just as Mr. Page was trying to revive the old downtown theaters, gleaming new chain-owned multiplexes began opening all over the state, driving him into bankruptcy in 1985. 
 "The chains beat me," Mr. Page said. "I had neither the money nor the patience nor the stamina to fight the big guys." 
Such huge chains as Circuit City, Sports Authority, Barnes & Noble, Home Depot and Target came into the state with what is known "big box" stores housing vast product lines. Of course, buying from manufacturers in such quantity translated into lower prices for consumers, driving out thousands of small, independent businessmen. Mr. Page was one of them. 
"It was a win-win for the consumer," said Carol Kaufman-Scarborough, a marketing professor at Rutgers University in Camden.
After taking a few years off, Mr. Page returned with a sequel. In 1987 he assumed the lease on a theater in the lower level of the Galaxy condominium complex in Guttenberg that had been closed for 10 years. Mr. Page had learned he could not match the multiplexes screen for screen, so he offered discounts and tracked down a 1920's-era theater organ in Portland, Ore., that he installed in the Galaxy, where he screens first-run films along with classics and silent movies. He applied a similar formula to nine other forgotten theaters - eight of them in New Jersey -- as president of the Galaxy Theater Corporation.
"We've made a success by providing something that the big boys don't give -- showmanship," said Mr. Page, who eventually bought back the Cedar Lane too.
Mr. Page's tale is not that unusual. In the early 1990's, when the economy was slumping, independent businesses found themselves under assault from the chains springing up in shopping centers, siphoning customers from downtown shopping districts and suburban malls alike. But these days, with the economy once again on shaky ground, it is the chain stores that are facing stiffer competition -- from one another as well as from a new generation of independent retailers who have found ways to survive and prosper.
Not that it will not be a struggle. According to Chain Store Age, a trade magazine, of the $2.5 trillion in retail sales in the United States last year -- excluding automobiles but including restaurants -- sales at stores with more than five outlets accounted for about $1.7 trillion. 
"Independents have now been able to identify gaps the chains weren't filling," Ms. Kaufman-Scarborough said. "Many of them have been able to find a well-defined niche market and build their overall strategy around that niche."
For consumers who spend much of their time fielding phone calls from telemarketers, returning merchandise to catalog companies and circling malls endlessly in search of parking spots, Ms. Kaufman-Scarborough said that an alluring niche could take several forms: first-class service, a one-of-a-kind product line or merchandise that meets a particular local demand.
"There's lots and lots of room out there for everyone," said Jerry Shields, a spokesman for Home Depot, who noted that his company and a competitor, Lowe's, accounted for only 20 percent of the nation's spending on home improvements. "The small stores need to find a niche, but they still have a majority of the market."
In addition, Ms. Kaufman-Scarborough said, many of the large chains expanded -- and in many cases overexpanded -- too quickly and experienced a shakeout. She pointed to the discount retailer Caldor, which went out of business in 1999, closing all of its 145 stores on the East Coast, and Kmart, which filed for bankruptcy court protection last year with plans to close seven stores in New Jersey. In addition, Ames closed all of its 327 stores in the region. 
"Even before the downturn in the economy," she said, "many tried to build market strength by volume and did not necessarily have the support."
With that in mind, she said, small retailers have jumped back in.

'A New Confidence'
"It feels almost as if there is a new confidence in the small retailers after seeing a number of the chains misstep," she said. "The cookie-cutter approach to retailing doesn't always work."
Mr. Page still has his battles with the chains -- like the multiplexes in Edgewater and Jersey City. Often, when a hot film is released on a limited basis, his name is not on the short-list. When "Chicago" came out last year, he said, he could not get his hands on a print for a month.
Still, the number of films and prints available has soared in the last 25 years -- a key to his economic survival. In the 1980's, a wide release would include about 400 screens, he said, while today that number is up to 6,000 to 7,000. 
"They built so many screens; they have to fill them," he said. "In the 80's if you had 150 films released domestically, that was a lot. Last year there were more than 500."
Even with more supply, Mr. Page knows his limits. He avoids whole swaths of the state where upscale development is taking place. Rather, his market is abandoned theaters, where he can negotiate cheap rent. For now, Mr. Page said his company had probably peaked, addingthat he might even get out of Hoboken, where he owns the Hudson Street Cinemas, when his lease is up in less than two years because he expects the rent to go up substantially. 
Still, in the past few years, Mr. Page said he had watched many of his multiplex competitors go through bankruptcy. United Artists, the Regal Entertainment Group, Loew's and General Cinema all operated under bankruptcy protection for some period from 2000 to 2002, though all have since emerged after paring back. Another theater chain, Clearview Cinemas, which operates 59 movie theaters in New Jersey, New York and Connecticut, is up for sale by its owner, Cablevision Systems.
"They all thought they were going to corner the market by building a multiplex every five miles," he said. "There is still only a finite number of people who go to the movies. If you saturate the market with screens, you're only going to hurt yourselves."
Gary Reiss, the owner of Suit World, a 60-year-old men's clothing store with three locations in Trenton, concurs, saying that finding a niche is what survival is all about when going up against megastores.
"We give something the big chains don't give, and that's service," Mr. Reiss said. "If somebody comes in and wants a suit with covered buttons, it doesn't take me long to go out and get them a couple suits with covered buttons."
In fact, he insisted that competition from the large chain stores had helped his business. "It made me sharper," he said. "I can move on a dime, where it takes a big chain a while before they can get themselves into gear."
Yet in one sense, Mr. Reiss said, he and the chains are all too similar.
"Nobody can say they're doing extremely well now with this recession," he said. "We need to get our economy working again so people can go back to work and spend on clothes."
Perhaps there is no greater symbol of the retail consolidation in New Jersey than the giant all-night drug stores that sell everything from prescriptions to makeup to lawn furniture in prime corner locations with drive-through windows. 
Terry Malanda started out working as a pharmacist for CVS for five years -- first as a floater and then for branches in Union and Rahway. 
"I hated it," Ms. Malanda, 40, said. "I was looking to go to law school - anything but pharmacy. There was absolutely no satisfaction."
But on her days off she worked part-time at several independent pharmacies in Union County and saw a new world beyond her counter. "It was much more personal," she said. "Patients would actually send you a thank-you note."
So in 1989, after borrowing money from relatives and friends and pooling it with what she had saved while working part time, she and her husband, Edward, mortgaged their house to buy Mandell's Pharmacy in New Brunswick. The store, founded in 1927, came with competition from a chain, Rite-Aid, already in place a block away.
Several years later, Ms. Malanda -- who was was having difficulty becoming pregnant -- began to develop a specialty in fertility drugs at her pharmacy, attracting new customers from a wider area. 
"It just kind of fell into my lap," she said. "If you don't have a specialty or something to distinguish yourself, it's really tough."
(She also had personal success. With the help of fertility drugs, Ms. Malanda gave birth to a son, Eddie, six years ago, and four years ago she had a daughter, Christina, with no pharmacological intervention.)
Ms. Malanda's specialty requires her to carry more costly inventory and involves more headaches with reimbursement from insurance companies, but she says that is the price she pays for her independence.
"It's definitely worth it," she said. "Every time one of my girls get pregnant, I get so happy because I went through it myself."
To be sure, the numbers do not favor Ms. Malanda. Stephen Brandt, executive director of the Garden State Pharmacy Owners, a trade association for independent pharmacies, said there were 1,350 individually owned drugstores in the state in 1993 as against about 650 today. Moreover, Mr. Brandt said the number of chain-owned drugstores had risen to 1,100 from 300 in 1993.
On the other hand, he said, he was surprised to learn that five new independent pharmacies had opened in the state within a month.
Ms. Malanda said she had also noticed a trickle of independent pharmacies opening -- in her view a positive development after many druggists retired in the early 1990's because of the difficulties of dealing with H.M.O.'s.
"I think people just got tired of it," she said, noting that chains were offering cash to pharmacies to close and hand over their patient lists.
These days, however, Ms. Malanda says a new generation of pharmacists have trained in the H.M.O. environment and are used to it. And, she said, more and more pharmacists, like her, have worked for chains and discovered it was not for them.
"I like to have that direct contact," she said. "Otherwise it's just counting pills."

'Our Own Boss'
Exit 4 of the New Jersey Turnpike in Mount Laurel is an oasis of motel chains: Radisson, Days Inn, Red Roof Inn, Econo Lodge and Howard Johnson are among the 25 hotels and motels nestled around the exit, which is a doorstep to Philadelphia.
Less then a mile away sits the Track and Turf Motel, a 40-year-old independent business with 30 rooms that was built to accommodate overflow travelers visiting the Garden State Park racetrack in Cherry Hill. 
"The other hotels are not a problem to us," said Vijay Shroff, who bought the motel with a partner two years ago.
Mr. Shroff charges less than $40 a night for a room that he contends differs very little from those up the road that can cost up to $140 a night.
"Not everybody can buy a Mercedes," he said. "Maybe they buy the Camry. Not everybody wants to pay $140 a night."
Mr. Shroff, who came to the United States from India 10 years ago, is part of a network of Indian entrepreneurs throughout the country who own independent motels. In fact, he borrowed money from the other motel owners as well as his family to go into business.
"We like to be our own boss," he said. "We don't like to work for anybody."
Mr. Shroff said most of the hotels near him -- the ones with the well-known American-sounding names -- were actually operated by Indian-born franchisees who got their start with small independent motels like his.
"We help each other," he said.

Taking On Home Depot
Warren Coupland knew he was heading directly into the Home Depot buzz saw when he bought Quality Paneling in Rio Grande five years ago. The giant orange-colored home improvement retailer had announced plans to build its first store in Mr. Coupland's area of Cape May County, just two miles north on Route 9.
"The prior owner was scared to death," Mr. Coupland, a retired insurance executive, said. "I knew they were coming, but I had confidence in what we could do."
Mr. Coupland, who had been a contractor years ago and had an engineering degree, came to Quality Paneling with a plan.
First, he changed the name to Quality Home Center and Paneling. Then he scrapped much of the basic lumber and hardware business to focus on more sophisticated - and profitable - products like kitchen and bathroom cabinets and fireplace systems. 
When Home Depot opened two years after Mr. Coupland bought his business, revenue at Quality fell 25 percent in the first six months. But by the end of the year it had climbed nearly back to the previous level, Mr. Coupland said. More important, the store was already doing twice the business it had before Mr. Coupland introduced his new strategy.
"Smaller hardware stores in the area were scared," he said. "They stopped making investments. They pulled in their horns, and that ensured they were not going to make it. It only took a couple years, and most of them were gone."
When it comes to marketing, Mr. Coupland cannot compete with the weekly circular that Home Depot puts out. Instead, he has rented a sign on Route 9 -- just before the turn for Home Depot -- boasting about Quality's expert service and free estimates.
"The idea was to really be in Home Depot's face," he said.
Last summer, he adopted his own signature color and painted the outside of his store bright rose.
Mr. Coupland can now look out from his rose-colored store at a tract of land directly across the street. That is where Lowe's, another giant home-improvement retailer, plans to build a store.
"That's not a problem for us," he said confidently. "That's going to be more of a problem for the Home Depot."

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
Shrinking Salaries Hit Home in Argentina

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

 BODY:
WHILE numbers in the United States show that hard times have not been hard of late on the pay of the nation's chief executives, that is not the case in crisis-ridden Argentina.
 Executives there have been feeling the pinch. Four years of bitter recession, a severe devaluation of the peso and surging inflation have effectively wiped out nearly two-thirds of the value of executives' paychecks and put many managers out of work. 
 Last year alone, the economy that was once Latin America's richest shrank 11 percent. Unemployment rose to record levels of more than 20 percent, double the figure when the crisis started in 1999. Multinational corporations have been retrenching, or even leaving the country, while local companies that have managed to survive a huge wave of bankruptcies have been doing much more firing than hiring. 
Now, however, the economy is showing the first, feeble signs of recovery. It is expected to grow this year instead of shrink, and some companies are starting to fill positions again. As a result, the executive job market is slowly coming to life, and Argentina's business analysts are taking stock of what has happened to executive salary packages.
In some successful export industries, which record their revenue in dollars but their costs in devalued pesos, wages are keeping pace with the 40 percent inflation rate. But in most others, mainly sectors in crisis, like banking, telecommunications and utilities, bosses are glad just to keep their jobs, according to executive search companies and management consultants in Buenos Aires.
"Downward pressure on salaries has been enormous," said Jorge Forteza at the Argentine offices of Booz Allen Hamilton, the consulting firm. "In dollar terms, salaries have been destroyed, and even in peso terms virtually nobody has kept up with inflation."
Esteban Calvente, who runs Pratt Pinet, an executive search firm in Buenos Aires, said the average salary of a top executive had fallen from the equivalent of $130,000 in 2001 to just a little more than $50,000 today.
Even chief executives who earned, say, $325,000 a year plus bonuses before the crisis, now might receive only about $130,000 in fixed salary, Mr. Calvente said.
The banking system's collapse has cut executives' access to credit, and much of their savings has been stuck in a 15-month-old banking freeze. As a result, many executives are looking for work abroad or downsizing the way they live.
As the crisis deepened, "for sale" or "to let" signs began to appear outside some of the most opulent houses in the top residential areas of Buenos Aires, according to the J. R. Reynolds real estate agency.
The top-tier job market in Argentina "has become very restricted," said Hernan Repetto, who left his job as chief operating officer of the cable television company Multivision, in Buenos Aires, in 1999, at the beginning of the crisis, to become president of TV Cidade, a cable channel based in Sao Paulo, Brazil. "There are a lot of top-quality executives with nowhere to go." 
"Since then, the situation for executives has gotten worse, much worse, than I expected," he said. "Having to accept pay cuts of 30 percent and more is hard to swallow."
Still, improvement may be at hand. Mr. Calvente said Pratt Pinet was being asked to place 14 executives a month in middle and top management positions, compared with just three a month early last year.
But because the devaluation has helped some sectors while hurting others, pay patterns are distorted.
"A soy oil export manager will cost you a small fortune," said Alejandro Etchart of Spencer Stuart Argentina, the executive recruiting firm, "but if you want to hire someone away from a bank, you can get a bargain."
Argentine companies are not required to disclose chief executives' salaries, and leading businesses are generally reluctant to discuss their pay policies. But "the big groups have tried to protect their quality people," said Mr. Forteza of Booz Allen Hamilton.
Job sweeteners include offers to pay 15 percent to 25 percent of an executive's salary in dollars or, in the case of multinationals, an offer of a stint abroad.

HEADLINE: LOVE & MONEY; 
The Case Against Joint Checking

BYLINE:  By ELLYN SPRAGINS; Ellyn Spragins is a freelance writer in Pennington, N.J. Her column about money's influence on relationships appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: loveandmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IF my children ever turn to me for marriage advice, I won't tell them that humor matters more than passion, or that true love conquers unemployment and infidelity. I will tell them to ban joint checking accounts from their married lives.
 What? Put asunder what our marriage vows and the American banking industry have brought together? 
 Yes, because I have concluded that joint accounts lead to a common, but often undetected problem in marriages: the secret money stash. Think cookie jars and underwear drawers, not Swiss bank accounts and lockboxes filled with gold bullion. Think of women, and men, quietly diverting grocery money, a health insurance reimbursement check or part of a bonus to a private stockpile that their mates know nothing about. 
Such stealth wouldn't be necessary with separate accounts, because men and women would not feel that every nickel they spent was subject to scrutiny and criticism.
Like public companies, good spouses are supposed to keep their finances open. "In marriages, money often becomes an instrument to work through the emotional piece of what's wrong in a relationship," said Lili A. Vasileff, a divorce financial planner in Connecticut, with offices in Woodbridge and Greenwich. 
Ellyn Bader, a therapist in Menlo Park, Calif., who studied spousal deception in her book "Tell Me No Lies: How to Face the Truth and Build a Loving Marriage" (St. Martin's Press, 2000), said secret stashes are common among couples headed for divorce. "The more hostility there is in a marriage, the more entitled a person feels about coming out of the marriage with cash -- and the more likely they'll start hiding money," she said.
Clearly, revenge-driven cash stashers flunk the good-marriage test. But what about minor offenders? How bad is your marriage if you pocket, say, a $140 insurance company check or keep a roll of $20's entombed in a Baggie and stuffed into the corner of the freezer? Are these marriages also doomed to fail?
Apparently not. Many men and women occasionally or even habitually divert marital cash to a private cookie jar. Of those I spoke to, most have been married 20 years or more. It wasn't a surprise when I came across a 73-year-old woman who lives near Boston and collects income from a separate investment account that her husband of nearly 50 years doesn't know about. She was raised in a time when women rarely earned their own income. "I believe a smart woman doesn't give away all her secrets," she said.
It was surprising, though, how common secret caches still seem to be. One 53-year-old woman who lives in Northern California and has been married for 25 years has been keeping a stash of money in her underwear drawer since she stopped working 20 years ago to become a homemaker. By skimming a little bit at a time from household funds, she sometimes has as much as $5,000 nestled in her lingerie.
"You sort of lose that financial independence when you don't have a paycheck," she said. "I wasn't used to having my spending scrutinized." She said her husband would think that the jewelry she loves to buy with her stash is a waste of money. Sometimes, she pays for part of a necklace out of their joint checking account and the rest from her underwear drawer.
Under the strictest interpretation of the what's-yours-is-mine-and-what's-mine-is-yours doctrine that seems to govern most couples' finances, this is an absolute violation. Secrets, this theory holds, are like hungry worms hollowing out your relationship until only a fragile husk remains. 
They also put a spotlight on your glaring deficiencies or most unshakable fears. The California woman says she also thinks of her stash as emergency money in case her husband decides to dump her and take up with a younger woman. Four of her friends, she said, have had that happen in their marriages in recent years. 
In our bare-all culture, the routine prescription is to confess everything. Be honest and be healed. But that approach only perpetuates a fiction that no couple can live up to: we agree on everything. Who does? And who really wants to? It's too bad that carving a few dollars out of the grocery money for a personal indulgence, or to soothe a fear, should make you feel like a sneak. 
"Not every dollar that comes into the house has to be stamped 'ours' and put into the system," said Steven Carter, author of "This Is How Love Works: Nine Essential Secrets You Need to Know" (M. Evans, 2001). "It's nice to have some relief from the we-ness."
Secret stashes may be a way to carve out your autonomy -- until you're found out. An acquaintance who lives in a New York City suburb has discovered her husband's small private stashes several times during nearly 30 years of marriage. As the family bill payer who sometimes had to postpone sending in a utility bill until their separate paychecks refilled their joint account, she felt duped. "Here I am, feeling short funded and he not only has money we need, he never experiences any anxiety," she said. Each breach also sets off wider suspicions. "It makes you wonder if there are other things you can't trust," she said.
I BLAME the tyranny of the joint checking account. It assumes that you'll both be perfectly consistent to financial policies to which you agreed as a couple. Wouldn't it be better to assume that you're both going to be inconsistent, except for the most important household expenses and goals? In other words, shouldn't you have separate checking accounts with, perhaps, one joint account for mutual expenses? 
Yes, that suggests that you are (gasp!) two different people with divergent desires. But that realization may do far more for your relationship than overseeing each other's spending.

HEADLINE: Executive Pay: A Special Report; 
A Remix in the Grants of Options and Stock

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN

 BODY:
BEING an American chief executive means seldom having to make a financial sacrifice.
 As stock prices remained submerged, many experts expected companies to compensate their top officers with more stock but fewer stock options. Last year, companies came through on the first part. They handed out more stock over all in the form of restricted shares, helping their executives lock in some value. 
 But almost all of them also continued to give out options, according to a survey of 200 companies by Pearl Meyer & Partners, a pay consulting firm in New York. Although the average value of the grants fell along with the tumbling market, more than 40 percent of the companies giving grants raised the number of options they awarded, which could mean lucrative returns for their holders in a big market turnaround. 
"We're not seeing much of a cutback at all" in equity compensation, said Ann Yerger, deputy director of the Council of Institutional Investors in Washington. Though some executives are earning less incentive pay based on performance, she said, companies are making up for almost all, if not all, of that decline "with restricted stock awards and continued options grants." 
At the Clorox Company, G. Craig Sullivan received $3.75 million in restricted shares. He did not receive any in 2001. But he also received three times as many options in fiscal 2002, a year in which the company's profit was little changed. Mr. Sullivan received 1.1 million options with an estimated value of $14.4 million, up from 325,000 options, worth $4.9 million, in fiscal 2001, according to Pearl Meyer. 
Delta Air Lines gave Leo F. Mullin $2 million in restricted shares; he, too, did not receive any in 2001. He also received 963,000 options with an estimated value of $9 million, compared with 200,000 options in 2001, estimated to have been worth $3.8 million. 
At Abbott Laboratories, Miles D. White received $11.5 million in restricted stock and 635,000 options worth $11.2 million. All told, the company's proxy statement shows, the five highest-paid executives at Abbott received restricted shares worth a total of $31 million, up from $2.6 million in 2001. Together, they also received options on 1.7 million shares, up from 1.2 million in 2001. Abbott's shareholders, meanwhile, suffered a loss of 27 percent last year.
OF the 200 large corporations surveyed by Pearl Meyer, more than half, 104, gave their chief executives restricted shares last year. Slightly fewer than half, 97, did so in 2001. 
All told, the restricted shares and other long-term incentives handed out last year were worth $185 million, up from the $177 million in 2001. The average value received by each chief executive was $1.7 million, down from $1.8 million in 2001, but the share of total pay it represented rose to 16.3 percent, from 14 percent.
Shareholders have long criticized restricted stock as "free shares," given with no link to company performance. A decade ago, such stock was even less popular with shareholders than options are now, consultants said. The shares, which usually vest gradually over several years, drew scorn because they rewarded executives even if the stock price fell and did not recover.
Restricted stock is making a comeback because some executives, feeling burned by an overreliance on stock options, want a less risky form of pay. At many companies, restricted shares also offer a steady dividend stream. Holders of restricted shares earn dividends on them even before they can claim ownership of the shares.
And some reformers also came to see virtues in restricted stock, because the executives lose when the shares fall, just as shareholders do. That better aligns the interests of shareholders and executives, supporters have asserted.
Some companies did make a big shift away from options last year. Bank of America gave its chief executive, Kenneth D. Lewis, 164,624 restricted shares worth $11.3 million. He received none in 2001. Each of those shares currently pays a quarterly dividend of 64 cents, making the grant worth an additional $421,437 in annual dividends to Mr. Lewis. His options grant was reduced to 200,000 from 750,000 in 2001, a drop in estimated value of more than $10 million, according to Pearl Meyer.
Bank of America wanted "to really create transparency around executive compensation and how it's tied very specifically to performance and shareholder return," said Eloise Hale, a company spokeswoman.
Still, 176 of the 200 companies gave their chief executives stock options last year, compared with the 104 that gave restricted stock. That was about the same ratio as in 2001.
With the stock market down, the average estimated value of those grants declined to $6.3 million, from $9.1 million in 2001, and the average number of shares granted slipped about 4 percent, to 516,030. But 76 of the 176 companies that granted options gave more than the year before.
For the most part, options values are theoretical at the time the grants are made. Options give their holders the right to buy shares at a set price, usually the price of the underlying stock when the options were granted, during some future period. If the stock price never rises above the exercise price, the options should expire worthless.
Many of the options granted in recent years cannot now be exercised at a profit, a condition known as being underwater. A backlash from executives and employees holding these soggy pieces of paper has added to shareholders' growing opposition to options as a form of compensation.
"Options have been used excessively in an economic sense," said Ira T. Kay, national director of compensation consulting at Watson Wyatt & Company. In many cases, he said, large numbers of outstanding options have created the specter of significant dilution of companies' existing shares. "The shareholders are reacting to the high levels of dilution in a very negative way," he said.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. has made executive compensation, and the use of stock options in particular, a centerpiece of its shareholder activism this year, said Richard L. Trumka, secretary-treasurer of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Labor unions have called for votes at several annual meetings this spring asking shareholders to ban the use of stock options altogether, Mr. Trumka said. At more than 100 others, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is asking companies to limit options to those that have value only if the company outperforms a group of its peers, he said.
Doing so, Mr. Trumka said, would prevent executives from being automatically enriched "if the market would float up again and drag everybody upward."
Those sentiments help to explain the reduced frequency of exceptionally large grants of stock options to chief executives, pay consultants said. Of the 200 companies surveyed by Pearl Meyer, none gave its chief executive options worth more than $50 million in 2002. In 2001, four did.
THE days of exceptionally large grants should be over, said Joseph R. Rich, a compensation specialist at Clark/Bardes Consulting in Barrington, Ill., although he said the retreat from using options as pay may be gradual. Generally, he said, his clients, which are mostly technology companies, have shifted the mix of stock-based pay for chief executives to 35 percent restricted shares and 65 percent options, from a 20-80 blend in 2001.
"If you see a decline in the average grant this year, I think it will be because of a substantial decrease in megagrants of options," Mr. Rich said. "The governance world has created some concerns about the megagrant."
But it has not disappeared. The directors of Cisco Systems gave John T. Chambers six million options for the second consecutive year. But Mr. Chambers forfeited two million of them, leaving him with four million new options worth $43.9 million. The six million options he got in 2001 were worth an estimated $141 million, according to Pearl Meyer. Scott G. McNealy, chief executive of Sun Microsystems, got 3.5 million options worth $25.9 million, compared with 1.5 million options worth $15.3 million in 2001.

HEADLINE: Truly, Madly Driven: City Car Owners 

BYLINE:  By NANCY HASS 

 BODY:
FOR 90 minutes each weekday morning Steven Haft, a film producer, casts himself in the role of Modern American Dad. At precisely 7:15 a.m., he pulls his Mitsubishi Montero out of the garage and loads up his three children, ages 6 to 14, for school. "I feel very Ward Cleaver about it," he said.
 One small difference though: The Beaver lived in the suburbs, where ferrying the brood around in an S.U.V. has become an avocation for many parents. Mr. Haft, 50, on the other hand, lives in an apartment on East End Avenue in Manhattan, a city famous for potholes, tedious traffic, roulette-style street parking and $25-an-hour garages. 
 His morning excursion, which involves drop-offs on both sides of Manhattan as well as Riverdale before arriving at his Midtown office, would give the average highway-only driver heart failure and inspire derision from New Yorkers who consider a Metrocard a badge of honor. But Mr. Haft is unbowed. He will do anything for the pleasure of driving. In fact, one of the things that convinced Mr. Haft to move three years ago with his wife, the humorist Lisa Birnbach, from an apartment closer to the Lexington Avenue subway line was "having a really great excuse to have to take the car everywhere." 
It turns out that Mr. Haft is not alone in his determination to drive in a city that seems to taunt those who long for the open road. As most Manhattanites compete for taxis and subway seats, a small but quietly defiant group of Manhattanites drive their cars daily, going to great lengths -- and often great expense -- to construct a life that mirrors suburbia in its veneration of the automobile.
Bruce McCall, the writer and illustrator who chronicles the purgatory of Manhattan driving and parking with a Blakian intensity, cut his teeth in Detroit as a copywriter for car companies. "I am wedded to the automotive solution," he said. 
Every weekday Mr. McCall drives his wife 15 blocks to work, and usually drives himself to lunch. He has not been on the subway in 15 years, and as for cabs, he said: "Every time I take one, it's an admission of defeat. I don't know what the principle is but I seem to be defending it fiercely." 
Traffic experts suspect that an increasing number of Manhattanites are using their cars as a primary means of transportation. Although tracking studies are not up to date, Sam Schwartz, a private traffic consultant, said he believes that the number of drivers has risen significantly over the last decade as the result of the liberalization of parking regulation in the Giuliani era, an influx of affluent people and fear of terrorism after Sept. 11, 2001.
Mr. Schwartz said that as of the mid-1990's, at least 12 percent of the cars that venture each day into the city's central business district -- defined as Manhattan below 60th street -- were owned by people who live in the borough, often less than a mile or two away. "It could be above 12 percent now, but even that is not insignificant," he said. "If there was a 12 percent reduction in traffic, you would really be able to feel it."
Drivers, however, are entrenched. "I consider using my car unnecessarily as one of the great joys of my life," said Peter Boyle, the actor, who, like Mr. Haft, lives on East End Avenue. Mr. Boyle starts most days with a stroll to the bank for a roll of quarters (he considers it unsportsmanlike to use a garage when he is out and about). He takes his Mercedes station wagon everywhere, even to Elaine's, which is only a block or two away from his home. "Being dedicated to your car here is a test of your patience and cunning," he said. "And there's better radio reception than in the house."
Whatever their reasons, Manhattan drivers do seem to have one thing in common -- most grew up in places where cars meant freedom.
Judy Hart, who is married to a screenwriter, decided to "live like a suburban housewife with a Ford Explorer," even though her home is in the East 70's. To that end, she drove her two children to and from private school for 12 years. A legend in the elite school set, Ms. Hart developed a ferry service for others as well. Her children's schoolmates would wait at designated corners for the "Hartmobile." "It was much nicer than the bus," she said, "I brought juice and water for them all."
Many Manhattan car enthusiasts acknowledge that theirs is not the most civic-minded of urban pursuits. Ms. Birnbach, conceded that she feels "politically terrible" about how much she and her husband drive in town. "Being a good New Yorker is merging with people," she said, "being a bad New Yorker is being isolated in your car." But driving her children around -- she takes over for Mr. Haft when he's not around -- gives her time with them that is often hard to find. "When you're in someone's cab, your kid may not say what she's really thinking -- there's the radio and the guy is on the cellphone," she said. "But when you're alone with her in your car after school and they're sort of exhausted, they vent."
John Kaehny, executive director of Transportations Alternatives, a nonprofit traffic watchdog group based in Manhattan, is not sympathetic. "It's outrageous, snobbish behavior and a huge imposition on society as a whole," he said of those who insist on driving. "Economists estimate that each vehicle in Manhattan does $1.50 a mile of damage in noise and congestion, not to mention how it weakens the infrastructure. This is not what Manhattan is about. It degrades everyone's quality of life." 
A spokesman for the city department of transportation, Tom Cocola, said that Manhattanites wed to their cars add to a congestion problem that in the long run hampers the city economy. "We can understand instances where people opt for cars, such as parents dropping their children off to school," he said, "but nonetheless we encourage Manhattan residents to follow Mayor Bloomberg's lead and take mass transit. Other options include bicycling and good old-fashioned walking."
According to anecdotal reports from mechanics and garage attendants, Manhattanites who rely on their automobiles fall roughly into three groups: those who can afford the more than $300 monthly fees for a garage, entrepreneurs who use their cars for work as well as play (their flexible hours help them avoid rush hour) and budget-minded drivers who park on the street, their vehicles often held together with baling wire and duct tape. 
The upscale drivers seem to live largely on the Upper East Side, with a high percentage in areas like Sutton Place and East End Avenue, far from public transportation and near garages. The plucky street parkers tend to cluster in neighborhoods like the East Village or far west Chelsea and Clinton. These neighborhoods, also far from the subway, have fewer meters and fewer parking regulations than more crowded areas.
"If you're crazy enough to really use your car in Manhattan, you're either a rich car lover or the mellow type who looks like they miss the 60's, driving around in a heap all day that you should have gotten rid of years ago," said Michael Bagwin, an owner of Bagwin Brothers, a Queens repair shop popular with Manhattanites. "Basically there's no one in between, no regular Joes."
It's not hard to figure out what category Andrew San Marco fits into. A 38-year-old commodities trader who lives on Fifth Avenue and 68th Street, Mr. San Marco keeps three of his five Mercedes in the city and drives to his office near Wall Street each morning. He leaves his uptown garage at precisely 6:45 a.m. and pulls into his downtown garage "exactly 14 minutes later," he said. "I catch the same lights every day. It's down to a science."
While many New Yorkers wince at the idea of subjecting a new car to potholes and the manhandling of garage attendants, Mr. San Marco has bought 25 Mercedes in the last four years for his personal fleet, he said, trading them in every eight months or so. "I know I'm a nut, but the fact is that even if I have to go just a block," he said, "I still take my car. I feel naked without it."
Caleb MacArthur, a 27-year-old writer who lives in a studio on Avenue C near Seventh Street, belongs to the other end of the spectrum. When he agreed to move with his girlfriend to Manhattan from Portland, Ore., last year, keeping his 1983 Subaru hatchback was a nonnegotiable demand. So instead of bartending to pay the bills, which he had done in Portland, he took a job using his car to deliver for a wholesale florist on West 26th Street. "I've had that car since I was 16 and I just don't feel whole without it," he said. "For me, it's like having a pet. You don't just dump it when you move to an inconvenient place."
Generally, he said, he is able to find an overnight parking spot within seven or eight blocks of his apartment. Every morning by 5:30 he pulls up in front of the shop and puts on the hazard lights. Within minutes he is back with five or six plants to be delivered. "I virtually never park, at least not in a legal space," he said. "But I'm very fast. I drop off the stuff and I fly." In the last year he has received only nine tickets, he said, with obvious pride. He calls them the "the price of doing business." One day he plans to pay them.

GRAPHIC: Photos: CRUISING -- Bruce McCall, unrepentant Manhattan driver and longtime chronicler of urban cars, puffs a cigar as he heads for the bank. Left, Judy Hart tools along on the Upper West Side. (Photographs by Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hummer H2: An Army Of One 

BYLINE:  By JAMES G. COBB 

 BODY:
LIKE an Art Deco skyscraper or a top 40 dance hit, a car is a time capsule for the age that produced it. Is there a better symbol of the naive optimism of the Eisenhower years than the 1959 Cadillac Eldorado, its exuberant, erotic tailfins puncturing the homogenity of the 50's, pointing toward a new era of space exploration, sexual liberation and technological revolution?
 When future generations look back, they may well see the Hummer H2 as the four-wheel icon of our time. With troops at war and gasoline prices gyrating, with civilians stockpiling gas masks and duct tape to ward off unseen perils, with capitalists and environmentalists squaring off over the attractions and evils of S.U.V.'s, these hulking quasi-military utility vehicles are hardly irrelevant to the national discourse. 
 For a world full of danger, the H2 girds you in armor -- in appearance, if not in fact -- for highways where road rage may get you if terrorists do not, where the gridlock of aggressive utility vehicles make it every woman (or man) for herself (or himself). Driving a Hummer makes a unilateral personal statement in sync with a unilateral foreign policy. 
"Drive defensively" signs in some states say, but Hummers are proactive and pre-emptive. The H2 reminds me of a Barron's cartoon I keep on my desk: a genteel couple are checking out a towering S.U.V. in a showroom. "Drive this baby," the salesman assures them, "and most of the rules of the road won't apply to you."
Certainly, some rules do not apply, like fuel economy regulations. The Chevrolet Tahoe, with which the H2 shares many parts, must display its mileage rating, but the Hummer goes unrated because its loaded weight exceeds the 8,500-pound threshold.
Hummers are so mighty that they scare away the tax man! One New Jersey dealership has been heavily promoting a first-year tax deduction of $36,524 that small-business owners may claim if they buy an H2 or another equally heavy S.U.V.
For General Motors, which bought the rights to Hummer in late 1999 (though American General builds the vehicles in Mishawaka, Ind.), the H2 is a bright spot in a dim market. Hummer dealers say the war in Iraq has increased showroom traffic, lifting sales of both trucks and trinkets. It is no coincidence that Hummers were the sole exclusions to the lavish buyer incentives G.M. announced last week, including five years of interest-free financing.
"Nothing screams 'American' like driving a Hummer," Tom Bowlin, product manager of a dealership in Cerritos, Calif., told Automotive News. In the Persian Gulf, it is the H2's stepbrother, the military Humvee, that screams American, in a war that has, at the least, a tangential connection to world oil supplies and American gasoline prices.
With more Hummers on the road, ample supplies will be needed. With mileage estimated at 10 to 13 m.p.g. on average -- though I barely exceeded 11 m.p.g. while driving two H2's a total of 2,000 miles -- Hummers are among the least fuel-efficient passenger vehicles sold in the United States.
No one buys a Hummer for its mileage, of course, and to many of the new customers the vehicle's considerable off-road capabilities are incidental, too. Often, the H2's mission is to attract attention, an assignment it handles with ease.
I first drove an H2 last summer, when they were quite rare, then used one to make a New York-Detroit round trip in January in near-blizzard conditions. They received all the attention they deserved, including shouts of "Yo, Schwarzenegger!" as I rolled through Harlem. (An understandable case of mistaken identity.) What I hadn't expected was to find women, usually in their 30's with children in tow, admiring the Hummer nearly every time I parked it in upstate New York. Several times they stood waiting, questions ready, for the driver to appear.
Indeed, more than a quarter of H2 buyers are women, and many others play a role in the purchase decisions of men. This has not been lost on Hummer's marketing department, which introduced heavy artillery into the war of the sexes with an ad that suggested, "Threaten men in a whole new way."
Intimidation is part of the package, and this is not necessarily a bad thing. Manic cabbies don't mess with Hummers, which are also persuasive against left-lane road hogs on the Interstate. Drivers who dawdle in the passing lane, refusing to move right no matter what, eventually take the hint when a taxi-yellow H2 fills their mirrors.
The H2 is plenty big, though it looks larger than it is -- partly because all the components were set on or above the frame, partly because the windows are shallow and the sides are vertical. The truck is actually shorter and not much taller than a Tahoe, and the lack of overhangs beyond the tires is a boon to off-roading; you can roll right up and over a 30-inch wall. The H2 can ford 20 inches of water and climb over 16-inch rocks.
The H2 has little in common with the original Hummer, the H1, beyond their look. Both wear a seven-bar grille (one that DaimlerChrysler unsuccessfully tried to stop G.M. from using, asserting that it infringed on a Jeep trademark). The H1, a somewhat civilized version of the military Humvee, costs more than $100,000 and has a diesel engine with awesome pulling power; the $50,000 H2 borrows its 6-liter gasoline V-8 from various G.M. trucks. The H2 also has a sophisticated electronic four-wheel-drive system that offers five driving modes, including a low gear range with a locking rear differential.
While H1 is cramped and noisy, H2 is comfortable and reasonably quiet. But first you must get in, and the first step up is a 25-inch doozy. Unless you play professional basketball or don't mind ripping your inseams, the optional running boards are essential.
Once the driver has clambered onto the overstuffed captain's chair -- with individual armrest and multiple power adjustments -- he or she can practically look long-haul truckers in the eye. In keeping with the big-rig theme, the H2 has clearance lights around the roof.
Although spacious and plush, the cabin is no more subtle than the exterior. The focal points are huge round vents that protrude from the dashboard, including a pair in the middle reminiscent of the cone-shaped bras that Madonna used to wear. The shift lever for the four-speed automatic, the only transmission offered, is a wide, thick bar of the sort that Buck Rogers might have used to engage warp drive.
The controls work well enough -- save for the antiquated multifunction turn-signal stalk that G.M. won't let go -- though there are lots of bits and pieces to the interior, in the company's usual fashion. And the quality of the dash materials, especially plastic panels with an unconvincing metallic look, are unlikely to age well.
Like other big G.M. utilities, the H2 drives well enough for its size, and it seems to shrink as you roll up the miles. The steering has quite a bit of free play, like a Jeep's, but that is a boon if you crawl over boulders. An electronic air suspension can raise the rear of the vehicle two inches over the normal ride height, also useful for off-roading.
Writing for these pages last year, Cheryl Jensen described how well the H2 handled a 1,000-mile trip, entirely off road, down the Baja peninsula. That is certainly more of a workout than I gave my H2 test trucks, and more of an adventure than most owners will seek out.
Towing capacity is an impressive 7,000 pounds, which is a good thing, because there is not a lot of room for cargo inside the cabin. The gargantuan spare tire takes up nearly a third of the space behind the second seat, and the optional third-row jump seat is wedged in beside it. Fortunately, Hummer has begun to offer an outside mount for the spare.
And the company promises a more comprehensive solution to the shortage of cargo space: a pickup version of the H2, to be called the H2 S.U.T., is due to arrive in a year. A line of smaller, less expensive vehicles, the H3, seems likely, too -- Hummers for hoi polloi.
H1's are selling slowly now, as their prices have risen and their novelty has worn off. Too, the H2 may be stealing some of its older brother's thunder. The H2 factory is working hard to keep up with demand, and since that plant can turn out 40,000 H2's annually, you can expect to see a lot more of them -- on urban streets, in hip-hop videos, in the stadium lots where professional athletes park their trophy cars. The crime scene investigators on "CSI: Miami" have one, helping them cope with the challenging driving conditions of sunny South Florida.
Some customers will surely take their H2's over the hills and into the woods, but for many the image is everything. The H2 is larger-than-life proof that motor vehicles continue to evolve into fashion accessories. You can wear Armani or camouflage, a Mini car or a maxi truck.
Already, some Hummers are being personalized with flashy megawheels and ultra-low-profile tires, rendering these off-road brutes barely capable of coping with a pothole.
Decadance takes many forms, and a low-rider Hummer is surely one of them. If today's scary world doesn't quite make sense, perhaps it follows that what we drive may not make a lot of sense, either.

INSIDE TRACK: A big fat moving target in the S.U.V. war of words.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
If Chiefs Are Fed Up, Why Do They Stay?

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT

 BODY:
SO much for the idea of the reluctant chief executive.
 After the business scandals last year, executives -- along with the headhunters and pay consultants they hire -- predicted that top corporate jobs would lose some of their appeal. Rather than face new scrutiny, some executives would simply retire, while some up-and-comers would shun the corner office, the theory held. 
 "The chance to run a public company used to be most executives' dream," The Wall Street Journal wrote in June. "Now the thrill is gone." 
David F. D'Alessandro, chief executive of John Hancock Financial Services, told The New York Times last year that the leader of another company talked to him about feeling sullied by the scandals, even though his company was healthy. "My God, what a terrible time to be a C.E.O," the chief executive said, according to Mr. D'Alessandro. "I'm thinking of actually getting out, retiring. I didn't sign up for this."
But the theory was never very convincing. Think about it: if you had nothing to hide and only had to answer some tough questions, would you quit a job that allowed you to shape the future of communities and make millions of dollars?
It turns out that the nation's chief executives wouldn't, either. Of the nation's 200 largest companies, only 11 have made a change at the top since July, according to Pearl Meyer & Partners, a pay consulting firm. Seven of the departing executives were ousted by the board or resigned under pressure, according to news reports. An eighth, Richard Jay Kogan of the drug maker Schering-Plough, quit after announcing a sharp fall in profits.
Another chief executive completed a long-planned succession, and John W. Snow left CSX to become the Treasury secretary.
Only Dean O'Hare, of Chubb, the insurance company, comes close to fitting the image of the fed-up executive, but he is hardly a perfect example. After 14 years on the job, Mr. O'Hare left in the midst of a personal controversy in which his neighbors in New Jersey had complained to newspapers about his habit of using loud machinery to do yard work late at night. They even tried to pass a new noise ordinance. Mr. O'Hare has said his resignation was not related to the dispute.
So the theory of the reluctant executive has little factual support. But there are reasons for its continued popularity.
During the roaring economy of the late 90's, chief executives said their enormous pay increases were fair rewards for their stewardship. After three years of weak profits and falling stocks, however, the pay-for-performance explanation is less credible.
In its place has come the notion that only a rare few can manage a company under current conditions. Lose a leader, and a company might just buckle, some argue.
Cooper Industries, the manufacturer, and Union Pacific, the railroad company, were apparently so afraid of losing their chief executives that each awarded multimillion-dollar retention grants last year. H. John Riley Jr. has been in charge of Cooper since 1995 and Richard K. Davidson has led Union Pacific since 1996. In each case, the company's share price is lower now than on the day the executive took over.
MANY other boards have given big stock grants to executives whose fortunes had already been closely tied to those of their companies. Pay for the median chief executive rose 6 percent last year, according to Pearl Meyer. 
The law of supply and demand does not explain this. By any measure, boards should have gained leverage in the last few years and reclaimed some of the outsized pay packages on behalf of shareholders.
But unlike the rest of the economy, where wages have stagnated, the market for chief executives bears little resemblance to a free market. Instead, many boards -- made up largely of other executives -- allow executives to help decide how they will be paid. It is a welfare system of sorts, where pay increases regardless of supply and demand.
In better times, executive pay could be dismissed as a sideshow. That is not as true now, with corporate America trying to convince investors of its credibility.
Investors "continue to doubt the quality of internal governance and external oversight, as well as the reliability of the information corporations provide," William J. McDonough, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, said recently. Those doubts are restraining growth, he said.
They will not disappear until executives come up with a more convincing explanation for their paychecks -- or take the radical step of allowing those paychecks to be set by the rules of capitalism.

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds Report; 
Bonds Eclipse Stocks in Emerging Markets

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
IVESTING in emerging stock markets has always been risky for mutual fund managers, but finding rising markets has become even more challenging lately.
 Eleven of 28 emerging markets rose in the first quarter, but some markets were so small that many fund managers missed them entirely. Only 7 of 133 emerging-markets mutual funds tracked by Morningstar rose in the quarter, and 41 percent fell more than the Morgan Stanley Capital International index for this sector, a widely used benchmark. 
 The war in Iraq and a weak global economy are likely to make it more difficult to choose winning stock markets, and buying emerging-markets bonds, which have performed better, may require greater skill.
"I do believe you need to be fairly selective," said Geoffrey Dennis, an emerging-markets equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. He likes Brazil and Mexico because they would benefit from a revival of the American economy. The prospect of lower oil prices makes him less interested in Russia. South Africa, a good defensive play, is a bet only if the world's developed markets continue to stumble, he said. 
Philip Ehrmann, head of Pacific and emerging markets at Gartmore Investment Management in London, agreed. "It will not be a case of a rising tide lifting all boats," he said. "That is why I am not saying that the whole asset class will go up in one fell swoop."
Mr. Ehrmann is also avoiding Russia and is wondering how much tourism in markets like Thailand will be hurt by the respiratory illness known as SARS, that was discovered in Asia. He said the Czech Republic, although a good performer, is too small and only a "one- or two-stock journey" for him.
Emerging-markets bonds, on the other hand, have been reasonably easy pickings, in part because of a big rush of new money this year into emerging-markets bond mutual funds, which have performed well the last several years. According to AMG Data Services, $581 million has flowed into those funds through last week, or 108 percent of the total inflows for all of 2002.
Mohamed El-Erian, head of emerging-markets portfolio management at Pimco, which had the best-performing emerging-markets bond fund last quarter, said he expected the good performance to continue because yields were attractive and many investors were hungry for them. But he said that choosing among these markets would test money managers. 
"You have to differentiate because some countries have gotten to unattractive valuation levels," he said, citing Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic. He also said that some markets, including Turkey, Venezuela and Argentina, were just too risky to bet on.
In the first quarter, five of the seven emerging-markets equity mutual funds with positive returns focused on China, Morningstar said. Twelve of the top 25 performers, with an average return of 0.7 percent, concentrated on Asia and the Pacific. Nine others focused on Latin America, with an average decline of 1.2 percent. The average return for emerging-markets mutual funds over all was a decline of 6 percent.
The Gartmore Emerging Markets fund, of which Mr. Ehrmann is co-manager, had 13 percent of its money in Taiwan at the end of January and 9 percent in Brazil. Both were up for the quarter. But its biggest bet was 20.3 percent in South Korea, where the MSCI emerging-markets index in dollar terms plunged 19.1 percent. Over all, the fund had a 5.3 percent decline in the quarter, less than the 6.8 percent decline for the MSCI index.
MANY of the better-performing markets are so small that they rarely pop up on managers' radar screens. The best performer, Argentina, up 19.1 percent in dollar terms for the quarter, is such a tiny part of the MSCI index -- 0.57 percent -- that it would not play a big role in many broad emerging-markets portfolios.
Israel had been in the red until March. But as war in Iraq became a certainty, the market rebounded, just as Wall Street did. Israel's market was also helped by the Bush administration's sudden focus on reaching an Israeli-Palestinian settlement. The MSCI index for Israel rose 7 percent for the quarter, but many managers missed this late surge.
That left three bigger emerging markets -- Brazil, Taiwan and China, the new powerhouse -- to carry the ball for many money managers. Brazil's market was down in local currency, but rose 3.7 percent in dollar terms because of the weakening of the dollar against the real. Taiwan, the third-largest market in MSCI's emerging-markets universe, stumbled on the quarter's last day, turning a 1.1 percent gain to a 2.8 percent loss.
China also plunged on March 31, producing a quarterly loss of 1.5 percent. China is still a difficult country for many managers because many of its stocks are not available for sale to foreigners, though that is expected to change soon. Mr. Ehrmann now buys stocks of Chinese companies that trade in Hong Kong. When Chinese companies do become available to foreign investors, he said, many are likely to be too expensive to be immediately attractive.
For the quarter, emerging markets, on average, still fared better than developed stock markets outside the United States.
Over all, the MSCI emerging-markets index fell 6.8 percent last quarter, versus a 8.8 percent decline for a widely used benchmark for developed markets, the MSCI Europe, Australasia and Far East index, or EAFE.The last quarter was the sixth in the last eight in which emerging markets outperformed developed foreign markets.
Investors may have expected the weak dollar to improve the returns of their overseas investments, by reducing their losses or increasing their gains when translated back into dollars. If so, many people were disappointed. Although the foreign currency news focused on the dollar's 2.8 percent decline against the euro in the first quarter, it was stronger against 11 of 28 emerging-markets currencies and essentially unchanged against four others.
The dollar helped investors the most by falling 11.3 percent against the Argentine peso, turning a 5.6 percent gain into the 19.1 percent surge. But the dollar's rise against the South Korean won increased a 14.4 percent loss to 19.1 percent decline. The dollar's climb against the Mexican peso doubled that stock market's loss to 6.4 percent.
On the other hand, emerging-markets bonds brought overall returns of 6.6 percent, according to J. P. Morgan's index, with Ivory Coast, 34.8 percent, and Ecuador, 31.2 percent, leading a long list of positive total returns.
Of the 31 countries in that J. P. Morgan index, only four had negative quarterly returns: Turkey, Venezuela, Uruguay and South Korea.
Turkey's bond market had a loss of 9.9 percent, in part because Turkey shares a border with Iraq and refused to let the United States use it as a base for military operations in northern Iraq. Venezuela, where the return on bonds was a negative 6 percent, is still reeling from the strike that shut its oil industry.
The emerging-markets bond funds followed by Morningstar had an average return of 8.2 percent in the first quarter. They were led by Pimco's Emerging Markets Bond fund, up 10.5 percent.
"That is the difference between buying the index and being selective," said Mr. El-Erian of Pimco's performance.

HEADLINE: Domestic Security: The Line Starts Here 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
ONLY three months in town, and Charles E. McQueary has found himself just about the most popular man in wartime Washington. Powerful lobbyists and corporate executives track down his new telephone number and call him unannounced; strangers buttonhole him in the halls of Congress, hoping for a few precious minutes of his time.
 Dr. McQueary, a former executive of General Dynamics and Bell Laboratories, is the newly confirmed undersecretary for science and technology in the Department of Homeland Security. In that job, he will influence how the giant new agency and the rest of the federal government spend tens of billions of dollars on technology to defend American soil from terrorist attacks. 
 A genial, Texas-born engineering Ph.D., Dr. McQueary is now the government's chief contact with the scientists, technicians and entrepreneurs who are searching for ways to help their companies profit from the public's understandable fixation with keeping their families and communities safe from terrorism -- a threat that probably has grown as a result of the war with Iraq. 
Dr. McQueary got a taste of his newfound celebrity when, seconds after he finished testifying at his Senate confirmation hearing last month, he was approached in the hearing room by an entrepreneur who wanted to promote data-mining software that might help in the government's hunt for terrorists.
"I gave him an e-mail address," said Dr. McQueary, who has established a special e-mail account for dealing with the sudden crush of lobbyists, corporate executives and hand-to-mouth entrepreneurs who want to pitch their domestic-security wares. (science.technology@dhs.gov).
"Through my whole professional career, I always answered my own telephone, but it's rapidly getting to the point where that's not feasible anymore," said Dr. McQueary, who says he is more excited than beleaguered by his assignment. "I don't know if inundated is the right word, but we certainly are hearing from a number of people with ideas. And some of them are very good ideas."
The domestic-security industry may be new, a legacy of the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks and the widespread fear among intelligence agencies that Americans will be a central terrorist target for years to come.
But most components of the industry are well established; the largest players include major military contractors, giant electronics makers and private security companies looking for new markets for their expertise.
HOWEVER defined, the domestic-security market is huge -- and growing. There are as many different sales forecasts for the industry as there are research groups doing the estimating. But all of the industry's multibillion-dollar forecasts are bullish.
An industry-supported institute called the Homeland Security Research Corporation, in San Jose, Calif., predicts that overall public and private spending on domestic security will jump to $120 billion to $180 billion in 2008 from $65 billion this year.
Another trade group, the Government Electronics and Information Technology Association of Arlington, Va., says its tabulation shows that federal spending on domestic-security technology will reach $13 billion in the current fiscal year and rise to $14.6 billion in the 2008 fiscal year, a figure that does not include inflation.
Critics have said the Bush administration is devoting too little money to the Department of Homeland Security, the new superdepartment that is consolidating the work of 22 federal agencies. The White House is seeking an overall budget forthe department of about $38 billion next year, a 7 percent increase.
Lawmakers from both parties seem determined to spend billions more on domestic security, especially given the renewed worries about terrorism threats, and the administration seems likely to bow to their pressure.
Beyond Washington, state and local governments face similar huge demands to increase security spending, as does private industry, which is confronted with billions of dollars a year in new security costs, especially for companies considered likely terrorist targets, like airlines, chemical manufacturers and nuclear power generators.
"The money is just beginning to flow," said Bruce Aitken, a Washington lawyer and lobbyist who is president of the Homeland Security Industries Association, a trade group that has signed up more than 100 companies as members since it was incorporated in July. They include the giant government contractors Lockheed Martin, General Dynamics, Bechtel and Fluor.
"We think that the United States is extremely vulnerable to terrorist attack," said Mr. Aitken, who is about to announce the establishment of a political action committee to promote the industry's interests on the campaign trail. "We've got a lot of weak links, and it's going to take a lot of money to get that changed."
No military contractor is as closely associated with the war in Iraq as Raytheon, which makes the Tomahawk and Patriot missile systems; the war began last month when dozens of Tomahawks slammed into targets in Baghdad. But the company, based in Lexington, Mass., is eager to be seen these days as the government contractor of choice when it comes to dealing with enemies who might strike closer to home.
WITHIN days of the terror attacks in September 2001, Raytheon announced Project Yankee, a companywide effort to determine how its military expertise and products might be converted to use in domestic counterterrorism. In June, the company took the next step, formally creating a new division based in Falls Church, Va., outside Washington, to oversee its domestic-security business.
Its first major product is now arriving on the market, a $250,000 command-and-control vehicle called the First Responder, which is a Chevy Suburban sport utility vehicle packed with communications equipment and antennas allowing emergency-response agencies to communicate with one another even if they use different radio frequencies.
Raytheon officials say that in a major terrorist attack, the vehicle would overcome some of the logistical problems that hampered the disaster scenes in Lower Manhattan and the Pentagon on Sept. 11, 2001, when emergency workers using different, incompatible communications equipment poured in to help from cities and towns hundreds of miles away.
"The First Responder is just coming off the assembly line," said Dale Craig, a retired Army communications specialist who joined Raytheon after 30 years in the military; he is now directing the First Responder program. "This is a product whose time is here."
The first of the vehicles is bound for the Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department, and Raytheon said it was in negotiations with almost 300 potential buyers, including many police and fire departments around the country.
Another military contractor, Northrop Grumman, is working with a small high-technology company in Bedford, N.H., Imaging Automation, to promote security systems that would allow the federal government to quickly authenticate passports, visas and other documents presented at security checkpoints.
The Imaging Automation system, which usesa small glass-top metal box on which a document can be scanned in seconds for signs of forgery, has already been sold to the governments of Hungary and Australia, to the British airports authority and to Logan Airport in Boston, where it is used to verify documents presented by potential employees.
Imaging Automation, which has 60 employees, is a private company and does not release its financial results. But Bill Thalheimer, the chief executive, said he expected sales to double this year over last, and to triple next year from this year. "And that's all exclusive of what the federal government might want to do," he said.
In an age of terrorist threats and fears, the opportunities of the market reach beyond high technology, and companies that make basic home security and alarm systems are also poised to benefit.
Anyone who visited a supermarket or hardware store in early February, when the White House raised the color-coded terrorism alert and urged the public to stock up on basic survival supplies, understands that American families are willing to spend freely on their own protection.
After a year of corporate scandal and criminal charges against executives, the employees of Tyco International were probably entitled to a little good news, and they got it as a result of the February alert. Tyco is one of the world's largest makers of duct tape, and demand was so strong for its Nashua-brand tape that it switched the production line at its Kentucky plant to making residential duct tape instead of the commercial variety.
WHILE much of the early business of the Department of Homeland Security seems likely to go to large government contractors that have the track record and lobbying muscle to make themselves quickly known to the new agency, the department says it wants to serve as an incubator to innovative small and midsize companies.
"We're going to find there are some real good ideas from small companies," said Dr. McQueary, who is expected to spend much of his first several months at the department deciding on technology to help secure border checkpoints to block the entry of terrorists and their weapons.
He said he was trying to set aside time each week to meet with small, creative inventors who had domestic-security ideas that big contractors might have overlooked. "I had an individual come by to see me the other day with an idea for a secure manhole cover," Dr. McQueary said. "I was happy to give him 15 minutes. It's a manhole cover that couldn't be easily lifted out of its recess, and so terrorists couldn't easily get in and hide. Not a bad idea."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
It's Time to Land This Reward System

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IMAGINE a world where columnists are treated like chief executives. Instead of relying on my sense of professional responsibility -- and my need for continued employment -- the publications I write for would ensure my first-rate performance by showering me with an annual compensation package that would make Croesus blush.
 Then imagine the heights of punditry I could reach if only somebody gave me thousands of stock options every year, not to mention a huge salary, a personal assistant or two and lavish perks. Thus incentivized, my output of profound insights and shimmering prose would make H. L. Mencken seem a minor leaguer. 
 But in the real world, unfortunately, a writer's pay is somewhat more modest, and so we carelessly fling around jargon like "incentivized." Is it any wonder? 
If the notion that columnists need millions of dollars of motivation is ridiculous, so is the corporate practice of granting boatloads of stock options to chief executives and other top managers. In fact, the whole system of performance-based compensation for senior management is a mockery and ought to be abandoned. If these people can't do a decent job for a few hundred thousand dollars a year in cash, they ought to be fired, just like the rest of us.
The latest evidence that the system has derailed comes to us on the wings of the airlines. (This is just the kind of mixed metaphor you get when a columnist isn't properly incentivized). The main qualification for running an airline, it seems, is a willingness to demand federal aid. The airlines enjoyed a $15 billion federal bailout after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, and now they're back in Congress demanding more.
Although it may seem logical to compensate the chief executives with a percentage of whatever they can get out of Washington, the industry clings to the old-fashioned system, which means high pay and stock options. When times are good, airline chief executives, like their counterparts in other industries, are paid a fortune. When times are bad, they still become rich. 
Consider Delta Air Lines, which lost $1.27 billion last year. It recently disclosed that Leo F. Mullin, its chief executive, received a pay package in 2002 worth about $13.8 million. Mr. Mullin magnanimously reduced his salary, which is only a small part of his total compensation, by 10 percent effective March 1, to demonstrate what the company has called "his commitment to share the burden of Delta's cost reduction goals." On Thursday, Mr. Mullin went further, cutting his pay by $9.1 million. One can only imagine the belt-tightening that will be required to live on the remaining few million. 
Continental Airlines, which lost $451 million last year, awarded its chief executive, Gordon Bethune, a pay package worth $7.6 million excluding options. Mr. Bethune apparently is not easily motivated, because the company felt it was necessary to add options that can be valued at $7.1 million.
How can airline executives be paid so much when the industry is losing money, shedding workers and appealing for government aid? Pearl Meyer, a veteran executive-compensation consultant, tells astory about a single day in which she visited two companies.
First, there was a fast-growing high-technology company that wanted a chief executive in keeping with its aggressive image of itself. How much did it want to pay? "In the 75th percentile," came the answer. Then Mrs. Meyer visited an industrial company struggling with decline. Executives there sometimes had the unpleasant task of closing plants and letting workers go. They also needed a chief executive -- and they were convinced that the job was so tough that they had to pay in the 75th percentile.
All this high pay notwithstanding, the chief executive is probably less important than corporate directors seem to think. 
Rakesh Khurana, a professor at the Harvard Business School whose book "Searching for a Corporate Savior" (Princeton University Press, 2002) is subtitled, "The Irrational Quest for Charismatic C.E.O.'s," says 30 to 50 percent of a company's performance depends on the industry it is in, while another 20 percent depends on the economy. Both factors amount to luck. That seems to be one thing that America's chief executives have in spades.
